query: SELECT Z_PK AS RECIPEID, ZNAME AS RECIPENAME, STEPID, ZORDER, STEPTYPE, ZLABEL FROM ZRECIPE, (SELECT Z_PK AS STEPID, ZORDER, ZTYPE as STEPTYPE, ZRECIPE, ZLABEL FROM ZRECIPESTEP) WHERE RECIPEID = ZRECIPE
rows: Grate 1 cups radishes into small pieces.
Watch little chef as they grate radishes.
Chop the chives or green onions.
In a medium bowl, mix together the butter and cream cheese. Mix in grated radishes, 2 tbsp chives or green onions and salt, combining thoroughly
Warm the oil in a large pot on medium heat. Add the onion and garlic. Add the beef and allow it to brown on the outside.
Add 4 tbsp paprika and stir till meat is covered.
Add 3 tbsp Wondra flour and tomato paste just until the juice is soaked up.
Add the water make sure it covers the meat completely and add extra water so it can cook well.
Mix flour in well to remove all the lumps.
Add salt and pepper. Bring to a boil.
Place diced bacon in large pot on medium heat and cook until crisp.
Add onions to the bacon and cook until the onions are clear (for about 5 minutes).
Add potatoes, water, salt and pepper to the pot. Bring to a boil and cook for about 15 minutes in medium to low temperature or until potatoes are very tender.
Then add the butter and the cream. Drain the clams and reserve the liquid left aside.
Then stir the clams into the soup and cook for another 5 minutes. Use the remaining water to dilute the cream if necessary (it’s up to your personal choice of creamy).
Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add potatoes, and cook for 15 to 20 minutes, or until tender but still firm.
Preheat the oven to 325 F degrees and spray a non-sticking pan with non-sticking spray.
Mix all ingredients together in a big bowl. Make sure that there are no bumps when mixing!

Now that the mix is ready you can pour in the pan and put it in the oven for 30-45 minutes. To see if the cake is ready, put a toothpick of the cake. If it comes out clean, it's ready! If it comes out with batter on it, leave it in for a little longer.
Take the cake out of the pan and let it cool. In the meantime, make the a frosting of cream cheese, butter, sugar and vanilla.
Salmon Fish Sticks with Thai Basil Dipping Sauce
Salmon Fish Sticks with Thai Basil Dipping Sauce
Combine all dry ingredients (including grated parmesan) on a plate and set aside.
Salmon Fish Sticks with Thai Basil Dipping Sauce
Whip up the egg in a bowl until frothy and set aside.
Salmon Fish Sticks with Thai Basil Dipping Sauce
Pat the 3-4 inch salmon sticks dry.
Salmon Fish Sticks with Thai Basil Dipping Sauce
Dip the salmon sticks in the dry mixture, then into the beaten egg, then back in the dry mixture.
Salmon Fish Sticks with Thai Basil Dipping Sauce
Place the sticks on a well-oiled baking sheet and then drizzle the fish sticks with olive oil.
Salmon Fish Sticks with Thai Basil Dipping Sauce
Place the fish sticks in the oven and bake for 15-20 minutes until nice and golden brown.
Defrost the 8 empanada wraps (if purchased frozen).
Wash and chop the 2 onions in small pieces.
Cut the bell pepper and dice into small cubes.
Heat the 4 tbsp butter in a small saucepan over medium heat.
Sauté the onions for 5 minutes or until golden brown.
Add the peppers and sauté for an additional 5 minutes.
Add the 1/4 cup of flour to the cooked vegetables and cook until bubbling (about 3 minutes) .
Add the 1 cup milk slowly while whisking constantly, bring to a simmer, stirring constantly.
Add the 1/4 tsp paprika, 1 tsp nutmeg and salt and pepper.
Stir in the 2 cups corn and 1 tbsp parsley, return to a simmer and cook until corn is warmed through
Scrape the filling into a bowl and cool completely before calling in the Little Chefs to fill the wrappers .
Moisten the edges of 1 of the empanada wrappers with a fingertip dipped in warm water.
Put ⅓ cup of the filling on the center of the wrapper.
Bring the sides of the wrapper together to meet over the filling and pinch the sides together to seal and form a half-moon shape.

Lay the half-moon flat on the kitchen counter. Work your way around the edges, bringing about 1/2-inch of the bottom layer of dough up and over the top layer, to make a mini-pleat (half moon). Press as you go to seal the pleats.
Repeat with remaining wrappers and filling.
Grease two pans with a brush and olive oil.
Place the empanadas on the baking sheets and give the pans to the Big Chef
Once the Little Chefs are done with their duties, bake until the empanadas are light golden brown, about 25 minutes.
Cut 3 eggplants in half lengthwise, leaving stem ends intact. Give to Little Chef.
Mix the minced garlic and olive oil in a small bowl and give to Big Chef.
Combine oregano, basil, thyme, paprika and red pepper flakes in separate bowl and stir to mix.
Sprinkle cut side of eggplants with dried herb mixture and salt and pepper to taste. Give eggplants to Big Chef for cooking.
Lightly brush cut sides of eggplants with garlic-oil mixture and grill, cut side down, until lightly browned, about 3 minutes.
Lightly brush skin sides with oil mixture.
Flip eggplants and brush cut side again with remaining oil.
Continue cooking eggplants, cut side up until very tender, 6-8 minutes, or as needed.
Add 2 cups dulce de membrillo (quince paste), 1/4 cup pineapple and 1/4 cup raspberry jam to a small pot with 1 or 2 tablespoons of water, and cook at low heat, stirring frequently.
Remove pot from heat and let it cool.
Mix the dry ingredients (2 cups flour, 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1 tablespoon baking powder and 1/2 cup sugar) in a bowl using a whisk.
Cut the butter into small pieces and mix into ingredients until well blended.
Add 2 tbsp milk, egg and egg yolk to the dry mix. Make sure mix is not too wet or too crumbly; you can add an extra tablespoon of flour or milk to adjust.
Wrap dough in plastic and chill for about 30 minutes.
Roll about ¾ of the dough on a floured surface and make it a circle big enough to cover all of the pie dish, place in buttered dish.
Spread the filling prepared by Big Chef into the dish.
Roll the remaining dough into a circle and cut thin strips of dough.
Along with the Little Chef, make a lattice pattern over the top of the tart
Cook in the oven until golden brown (about 30 minutes).
Wash and cut the 2 lettuce heads.
Cut the crust from the bread.
Mix the mayonnaise and the ketchup in a bowl.
Add a thin layer of the mayonnaise and ketchup mix on 10 of bread slices.
Add the corn to the rest of the ketchup mix.
Add a spoon of the corn with the mix, a slice of lettuce, a slice of cheese and cover with the clean 10 slices of bread.
After sandwich has been made push them down and make two diagonal cuts (from corner to corner) to create four triangles
Put on a small amount of water to boil, and preheat oven to 350° F.
Measure out the 1 cup of oats,1 cup flour, 1 cup sugar, and 3/4 cup flaked coconut into a bowl and mix them together with a wooden spoon.
Measure out 1 teaspoon of baking soda into a mug or small bowl.
In a small saucepan on low heat, melt the butter and syrup together. Add the boiling water to the baking soda, mix, then add to the butter mixture.

Pour the butter mixture into the bowl of dry ingredients and mix with a spoon. When the mixture is cool enough to touch, you can let the Little Chef knead the mixture with his/her hands until everything is mixed in well.
Grease the cookie sheet with butter or cooking spray so the cookies don’t get stuck.

Make little balls out of the dough that are about 1 inch thick (about one heaped teaspoon each), and place them on the cookie sheets. Make sure you leave an inch or two between each one so they don’t get stuck to each other.
Put the cookies in the oven for 10-15 minutes, or until golden brown.
Wash all the carrots and celery, and then chop up the onion, celery, and carrots.
Grate ginger and lemon rind (from lemon).
Sauté onion, garlic, celery, ginger, carrots, and lemon until onions are transparent.
Pour in broth, 1 tbsp vegemite, salt & pepper, and simmer until carrots are soft (about 20 minutes).
Pour into food processor or blender and blend until smooth. Add hot water until soup is desired consistency.
Peel and cut up the mango into cubes.
Peel and slice the onion thinly.
Grate the carrot and slice avocado.
Rinse the lettuce, shake the extra water off, and place in a big bowl
Sprinkle the grated carrots and purple onion on top first.
Sprinkle on the nuts, seeds, and raisins.
Place a wok or large skillet over high heat, and pour in 1 tablespoon vegetable oil. Cook the 1lb pork, stirring frequently, until no pink is showing.
Remove pork from pan and set aside. Drain grease from pan, leaving a thin coating.

Cook the 2 cloves of garlic and 1/2 cup of chopped onions in the same pan for 2 minutes. Stir in the cooked pork, 1/2 cup minced carrots, 1/2 cup sliced green onions, and 1/2 cup cabbage. Season with pepper, salt, garlic powder, and soy sauce.
Place three heaping tablespoons of the filling diagonally near one corner of each wrapper, leaving a 1 1/2 inch space at both ends.
Fold the side along the length of the filling over the filling, tuck in both ends, and roll neatly. Keep the roll tight as you assemble.
Moisten the other side of the wrapper with water to seal the edge. Cover the rolls with plastic wrap to retain moisture.
Slide 3 or 4 lumpia into the oil. Fry the rolls for 1 to 2 minutes, until all sides are golden brown. Drain on paper towels.
Let big chef finish their tasks.
Chop the tomato, eggplants, onions, and bitter melon.
Trim the ends of okra and green beans.
Weigh the ingredients on the food scale.
Heat the oil in a large pot over medium heat.
Cook and stir the onion and garlic until translucent for about 5 minutes.
Add the pork and stir until browned for about 5 to 7 minutes.
Add the prawns and the shrimp paste and stir until the prawn turns orange.
Add the tomato and cover the pot for about 5 minutes.
Add all the vegetables and cover the pot, let it cook for about 10 minutes or until the vegetables are tender.
Heat oil in a wok or large skillet over medium heat. Saute onion and garlic until soft.
Stir in 2 cups chicken breast, 2 cups cabbage, 4 chopped carrots and 1 tsp soy sauce. Cook until cabbage begins to soften.
Place the rice noodles in a large bowl, and cover with warm water. When soft, drain, and set aside.
Toss in noodles, and cook until heated through, stirring constantly.
To cook the rice, add 4 cups of water and the 2 cups of rice to a large pot. Bring to a boil, stir, and cover the pot until the rice is cooked, about 20-25 minutes.

In a wok or large skillet, fry the 1 lb of pork until crisp. Remove the pieces of pork from the wok and drain on a plate covered with a paper towel. Leave about 2 Tbsp of the pork fat in the wok to cook the vegetables, pour off any extra.
Chop 1 cup carrots, 1 tbsp onion, 1 tsp garlic, pepper, and cabbage.
Add the pepper, onion, cabbage, carrots and garlic to wok . Stir-fry 3 minutes.
Stir in peas and soy sauce. Cook 30 seconds.
Sauté the 3lb ribs, 2 tbsp garlic, 1 tbsp onions add salt to taste until brown.
Add the tomato and cook on medium heat for 40 minutes.
Add the 2 small taro and cook it for another 10 minutes.
Add the Daikon Radish and the Bok Choy and cook for another 10 minutes.
In a separate large pot fill with water.
Add the sinigang tamarind soup packet.
Pull tails off of the cooked shrimp, if purchased with tail-on.
Add oil, garlic, and seasoning to the shrimp.
Squeeze lemon juice onto the shrimp.
Cut the bell peppers, onions, and zucchini.
Add the shrimp and vegetables to skewers and give to Big Chef.
Soak macadamia nuts in a bowl of water for 2 hours.
Puree the macadamia into a paste, using a food processor or blender
Add the macadamia nut paste, tomato, basil, olive oil and garlic to a bowl and mix together.
Season the dip with salt, pepper, and lemon juice.
Cut bell pepper into strips, removing the seeds.
Place peppers on a plate and place the dip next to it.
Preheat oven to 350° F if using a metal pan, 325° F if using a glass pan.
Place flour, carob powder and salt in a large mixing bowl and thoroughly combine. Set aside.
In another large mixing bowl (or in the bowl of a stand mixer), combine the butter and sugar. Mix until fluffy and white. Add eggs and vanilla and beat until combined.
Add dry ingredients to wet ingredients and nuts (if using). Beat until wet and dry ingredients are just combined.
Scrape brownie mixture into prepared baking pan.
Bake for 25 minutes if using a metal pan, or 35 minutes if using a glass pan.
Take the cubed potatoes and put them into a pot. Using a measuring cup, add enough water to completely cover the potatoes.
Cook potatoes after Little Chef has put them in the pot, until potatoes are soft when a fork is inserted.
While the potatoes are cooking, melt the butter in a large saute pan over medium heat.
Put garlic, onion and leeks into the saute pan. (Careful, the edges of the pan are hot!)
Cook garlic and onion until it becomes a little soft, then add the leeks and saute until everything is just translucent.
Add the cream and stock and simmer for 10 minutes.
Drain the onion mixture, reserving the liquid. Set the onion mixture aside. Pour the reserved liquid back into the pan and cook until reduced by half, about 5 minutes.
Mix the onion mixture and potatoes together in a large bowl.
Once the Little Chef has mixed the onions and potatoes, return them to the pan with the cream and stock.
Season to taste with salt and pepper.
Rinse the endives in cold water, removing any damaged outer leaves.
Dry the endive leaves with paper towels.
After the Little chef has rinsed them, slice the endive leaves crosswise, about 1/2 inch thick.
Place the endives in a wide salad bowl after the Big Chef has cut them.
Quarter the apple and remove the core and then thinly slice.
Place in a bowl of water with 1 tablespoon lemon juice.
Add the walnuts, gruyère, parsley and tarragon.
Whisk together the vinegars, lemon juice, mustard, salt, and pepper. Whisk in the oils.
Drain the apple slices, dry on paper towels and add to the salad bowl.
Taste the dressing and adjust seasonings.
Cut off and fleshy inside scooped out with a teaspoon and left upside-down to drain for ½ hour.
Thaw the shrimp ahead of time.
Add the egg yolk and mustard to a medium-sized bowl.
With a whisk, very slowly add oil to the egg yolk mixture, starting with just a few drops at a time, until the mixture emulsifies.
Add the shrimp to the dressing and mix.
Warm the milk to 105-110ºF. Sprinkle the yeast over the warm milk and let it sit until it begins to get foamy. About 5 minutes.
In the bowl , stir together the butter, sugar, salt, and egg.
Pour in the milk/yeast mixture and the flour and make sure to mix at the same time.
Knead for about 5 minutes until it forms a soft sticky dough. The mixture will seem quite wet at first, but will form a smooth soft dough once kneaded.
Pour in all of the sugar cube pieces. Mix until evenly incorporated.
Place the dough in a clean bowl with a towel or loose plastic wrap over it and allow to rise to double in size. About 1½ hours.
Break the dough into small pieces, about 2½ oz each. You should get about 10-12 pieces.
Heat your waffle iron up. Remember, sugar begins to burn at temperatures above 350ºF.
Remove the waffles from the iron with a spatula (caramelized sugar is really hot!) once the waffle is golden, puffed, and crispy.
Use a vegetable peeler to peel the skin off the outside of the butternut squash.
Use a spoon to scoop out the seeds of the squash, after the Big Chef has cut it in half.
Tear the parsley into small pieces.
Melt butter in a pan over medium heat. Add the onion, tomato, garlic, and crushed red pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, for about 10 minutes.
Add the squash, beef stock, salt, pepper, and sugar.
Help to add the squash and squash
Bring to a boil. Lower the heat and simmer, covered for 30 min, or until the squash is soft and tender.
Puree the mixture in a blender. Once it is well blended, place it back in the pan and let it cook for another 5 minutes until smooth and consistent.
Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).

Melt the sugar in a heavy saucepan over low heat, stirring constantly. Once the sugar becomes a golden brown syrup after about 10 minutes, pour it immediately into a round baking dish, swirling so that the syrup coats all sides of the dish. Set aside to cool.
Place the egg yolks into a blender and blend on medium for 5 minutes, then add condensed milk,  milk, and egg whites. Continue to blend until all ingredients are combined.
Pour egg mixture into the baking dish with sugar and cover with aluminum foil.
Line a roasting pan with a damp kitchen towel. Place baking dish on towel, inside roasting pan, and place roasting pan on oven rack.
Fill roasting pan with boiling water to reach halfway up the sides of the baking dish
Bake in the preheated oven until a knife inserted 1 inch from the edge comes out clean, 45 to 50 minutes. The center of the flan will still be soft.
Chop spinach, tomatoes, garlic, and onion
Mix all the ingredients together in a bowl, but the egg whites.
Beat the egg white to a firm consistency.
Gently with a spoon add the egg whites.
Once Little Chef has completed their duties, bake it in a buttered pan at 375 degrees for 30 minutes.
If you are using a fresh yucca, peel the skin and the pinkish layer. Give to Big Chef to cut.
Cut yucca into thin strips or pieces (or any desired shape and size.)
Once yucca has been cut, put them on a baking sheet and toss with the olive oil to coat.
Season with salt, pepper, and dried cilantro (or other herbs) and toss to make sure evenly distributed.
Put tray of yucca fries into oven. Fries are done when they are crispy on the outside and still soft on the inside.
After cooking, add additional salt, pepper and herbs, to taste.
Cut the garlic, onions and mangos.

Heat some olive oil in a large stew pot over medium heat. Add the garlic, bay leaves, and crushed birdseye peppers and cook for about 3 minutes. Add the onions and cook until translucent, about 5 more minutes. Set aside.

Add more oil if needed, then cook the meat in a single layer until lightly browned on all sides, about 6 minutes. Repeat until all the meat has been cooked (you will likely have to do several batches). Add the onion mixture back in, stirring to combine.
Add enough water to just barely cover the meat. Bring to a boil, then lower to a simmer, cover, and cook for 1 1/2 hours, stirring occasionally.

After the meat has been simmered stir e. Cin half of the sliced mango, bulgur, saffron, allspice, salt, black pepper, and chipotlontinue simmering, covered, for another 45-60 minutes, until the meat is tender.
Remove the bay leaves, and stir in the remaining sliced mango.
Cook 2 cups of rice and fry chicken if not already cooked.
In a small bowl, beat 1 egg with water.
Melt 1 tbsp butter in a large skillet over medium low heat.
Add egg and leave flat for 1 to 2 minutes. Remove from skillet.
Cut the 1 onion and 2 tbsp ginger.
Cut the eggs into small pieces.
Heat 1 tbsp vegetable oil in same skillet; add onion and saute until soft.
Add rice, 2 tbsp soy sauce, 1 tsp pepper and chicken to the skillet.
Stir fry together for about 5 minutes, then stir in egg.
Cook 1 cup of rice using 1 1/3 cup of water in a rice steamer or pot.
After 5 minutes, take rice off the stove when finished. Leave there for 2 minutes before serving.
Cook 250g chicken and broth in a pan.
Chop the ginger, coriander, and green onions.
Mix cooked chicken, 1 tsp of  grated ginger, 2 tbsp of coriander, and 2 chopped green onions together.
Make dumplings by scooping mixture into wonton wrapper and seal.
Rinse the chicken and pat dry.
Chop 2 scallions into thirds, lightly smashing the white sections. Peel and slice the ginger.
Measure 1 cups soy sauce, 2 tbsp sugar and 1 tsp five-spice powder.
Combine the dark soy sauce, sugar, five-spice powder, 2-3 slices of ginger and the 2 chopped scallions.
Place the chicken in a large resealable bag and add half the soy sauce marinade. Reserve the remaining half. Seal the bag and squish the bag around to fully coat the chicken with the marinade.
Marinate the chicken in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours (overnight if possible), turning the bag occasionally so that the chicken is evenly marinated.
After the chicken has marinated, preheat the oven to 450 degrees Fahrenheit.
Take the remaining 4 scallions and tie into a knot. Give to Little Chef, along with remaining ginger slices.
After the chicken has marinated, take the knotted scallions and the remaining sliced ginger and place it under the skin of the chicken.

Reduce the heat to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius, gas mark 5). Roast the chicken, basting frequently with the reserved marinade, for another hour or until it is cooked. To check for doneness, pierce the chicken in the thickest part of the thigh. The juices should run clear. If using a meat thermometer, the temperature should read 170 degrees Fahrenheit (76 degrees Celsius) in the thickest part of the thigh.
Zest the 2 oranges, make sure to get as much as possible.
In a big bowl, pour the flour (32 oz.) and the 2 tsp. baking powder and mix with a spoon.
In a second bowl pour 8.5 oz. olive oil and corn oil, 14 oz. sugar, 2 tsp. cinnamon, 1 tsp ground cloves and the grinded orange peel and mix well.
In a third bowl pour the orange juice and add the baking soda. (Notice how the mix will rise so make sure to use a big bowl).
Pour the juice mix into the oil mix, then use a whisk to stir well.
Gradually add the flour mix, combining slowly until an oily and soft dough is formed.
Pinch a portion of dough off about the size of a walnut. Shape in your palms into a smooth oblong shape, and place on cookie sheet.
Bake the cookie for 25 minutes, until crispy.  Let cool down completely before adding the syrup.
While the cookies bake prepare the syrup. Have chef koochooloo measure ingredients into a pot, and cook on medium heat.
Put all the syrup ingredients in a pot.
When the mix starts to make bubbles, continue cooking for another 3 minutes.
Remove it from the stove and pour it over the melomakarona.
Peel the potatoes and give them to the Big Chef.
In a large pot of boiling water, add potatoes (from Little Chef) and boil until easily pierced with a fork. Allow to cool and then cut into ½-inch pieces and give to Little Chef.
Mash the potatoes once they have been cut by the Big Chef.
Mix the fish roe, shallots, lemon juice, and olive oil into the potatoes.
Sprinkle the olives and cilantro on top of the fish spread as a garnish.
Wash the tomatoes, the peppers and the zucchini thoroughly
Wash the parsley and the dill thoroughly
Cut the top of the bell peppers while the Big Chef cuts the top of the tomatoes
Slice off the top of the tomatoes
Use a spoon remove the flesh of the tomatoes and keep it in a bowl. Try to leave the vegetables as thin as possible, leaving just a little of the flesh, but be careful not to poke through their skin
Remove the seeds and membranes of the bell peppers and discard
Arrange the hollowed peppers and tomatoes in a baking dish that fits them about right with the hollowed sides facing upward
Add the tomato flesh to a food processor and puree.
Add the onions to a food processor and puree.
While the Little Chef is filling the vegetables, preheat the oven at 360 F.
Chop the zucchini in small cubes.
Chop finely the parsley and the dill.
After the Big Chef has pureed the tomato flesh and the onions, add them in a bowl along with the chopped zucchini, the chopped parsley, the chopped dill and the tomato sauce and the olive oil
Add the rice to the mix.
Add salt and pepper and mix well.
Use a spoon to fill the tomatoes and the peppers with the mix
After all vegetables are filled and in case any filling mix is left add it to the baking dish
Pour 2 cups water in the baking dish.
Sprinkle 1-2 tbsp olive oil over the vegetables.
Bake the stuffed vegetables for 45 min.
Wash and drain the chopped spinach very well. If using frozen spinach, thaw completely and squeeze out excess water. Spinach should be dry.

Heat the half cup of olive oil in a deep saute pan or large dutch oven. Saute the onions and green onions until tender. Add the spinach, parsley, and dill and cook for 5 to 10 minutes until the spinach is wilted and heated through. Add the nutmeg and season with salt and pepper.
Remove from heat and set the spinach aside to cool.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the feta, eggs, and ricotta (cottage) cheese. Add the cooled spinach mixture and mix until combined.
Combine the melted butter with the olive oil in a bowl. Using a pastry brush, lightly grease two 9 x 12 rectangular pans.

Carefully remove the Phyllo roll from the plastic sleeve. Most packages come in 12 x 18 inch sheets when opened fully. Using a scissor or sharp knife, cut the sheets in half to make two stacks of 9x12 inch sheets. To prevent drying, cover one stack with wax paper and a damp paper towel while working with the other.
Layer about 10 sheets on the bottom of the pan making sure to brush each sheet with the butter/olive oil mixture.
After the 10 layers add half of the spinach mixture in an even layer and press with a spatula to flatten.
Layer another 10 sheets on top of the spinach mixture making sure to brush well with butter/olive oil mixture.
Repeat the process with the second pan.
Before baking, score the top layer of phyllo (making sure not to puncture filling layer) to enable easier cutting of pieces later.
In a large mixing bowl, combine all of the ingredients and mix well.
Cover with plastic wrap and allow mixture to sit in the refrigerator for at least an hour.
Line a baking sheet with aluminum foil and lightly grease with either the cooking spray or brushed on olive oil.
Roll the meat mixture into balls about the size of a walnut.
Place the balls on a greased baking sheet about an inch apart.
Bake in 375 degree oven for about 40 minutes, turning the meatballs midway through the cooking time.
Place carrots in pot, cover with water, and bring to a boil. Simmer 30 minutes, or until tender. Drain.
Preheat oven to 375F. Coat 6 crème brûlée dishes or 1 1-qt. gratin dish with cooking spray.
With adult supervision purée carrots in food processor until smooth. Add eggs, bread crumbs, onions, salt, pepper and cumin, and pulse until combined.
Spread mixture in prepared dishes, and hand to big chef.
In a mug, dissolve 1 packet (instant) yeast in 250 ml water.
In a bowl, combine 300 g sifted flour with 1/2 tsp salt.
Add the yeast and water to it and stir thoroughly (if it is very sticky, add a little bit more flour).
Work the dough with a wooden spoon or with your hands until the dough is smooth and no longer sticks to the bowl.
Leave the dough in the bowl, cover with a clean cloth and let it rise for 30-40 minutes or until it has doubled in size.
Let the pieces rest for another 30 minutes on the floured surface.
Once it is rested, carefully tip out the dough onto a floured surface, stretch it out into a square and cut out about 10 cm (3,93 inch) round shapes with a big glass (a big cookie cutter also works).
Stretch out each piece with your fingers into a round shape with the centre being thinner than the edges.
In a saucepan, heat sunflower oil. Place the lángos into the hot oil, fry it on one side until golden brown then turn. Repeat with the remaining lángos dough.
Sprout the Green Gram Moong (if not making green sprouts, skip to step 6.)
Cover and soak the beans with 3 inches of water overnight.
After the beans have soaked overnight or for 8 hours, strain them in a large colander and rinse under cold running water.
Cover the colander with a kitchen towel and set aside for another day.

Every 8-10 hours rinse the legumes and let the water run out, then cover again with the kitchen towel and reset. Once you see tiny little white shoots developing, allow for them to sit another day, continuing to rinse and drain, until the shoots are bigger.
Finely chop the 2 small or medium onions.
Peel and chop the potatoes in small pieces.
Chop the 4 medium size tomatoes and 1 bunch of coriander leaves into small pieces.
Mix all the chopped ingredients with the sprouts in a bowl.
Season it with rock or black salt as desired.
Add a few drops of lemon juice and 1/2-1 tsp of chaat masala (optional).
Drain the soaked lentils, leave it in strainer for sometime so that all the water would be strained.
In a mixing bowl add 1/3 cup strained Moong Dal, 1/4 cup grated coconut, 2 tbsp chopped coriander and 1 grated carrot.
Just before serving add salt & lemon juice and mix well.
Tempering the salad (In a small pan heat oil and crackle mustard seeds. Now, add Urad Dal and fry until it turns golden brown. Add curry leaves and asafetida and fry for few more seconds.)
In a pan add little oil and sauté onions, beans and carrots till they are cooked.
Peel and mash the potatoes in a big bowl.
Mash the beetroot and peas in the bowl as well.
Add the sautéed onions, beans and carrots in the bowl.
Chop cilantro in small pieces and add them in the bowl
Add salt, red chili powder, pepper, cumin powder and salt to the mash and mix it well.
Place small quantity of mash between 2 bread slices and put the sandwich on the grill.
Peel and cut mango if fresh; thaw mango slightly if frozen.
Measure 2 cups of the plain yogurt and add to blender.
Measure 1/2 cup of milk and pour into blender.
Measure 6 tsps of sugar or agave nectar and pour in blender.
Measure 1 cup of ice and add into blender.
Once Little Chef has completed their duties, blend on smoothie mode or until well blended.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Cut tops off of the peppers.
Remove seeds from inside of the peppers
Chop onions up, but makes sure to separate 1 onion for stuffing and 2 for the sauce.
Measure out the ingredients for sauce and hand to big chef.
In a skillet over medium heat, saute 1 chopped onion until tender.

Heat oil in a large saucepan over medium heat, Saute 2 chopped onions until soft and translucent. Stir in tomatoes. Season with 3 whole peppercorns, 3 whole allspice berries, 1/2 tsp ground allspice, 1 tsp oregano, 1 tsp marjoram, salt and pepper (personal preference). Cook on medium heat for 15 to 20 minutes. Pour over peppers in roasting pan.
In a large bowl, combine the ground beef, the sauteed onion, 1 cup cooked rice and 1 egg. Season with 1 tbsp parsley, salt and pepper. Mix well, and stuff into peppers. Place in a large roasting pan.
Cover, and bake in preheated oven for 1 1/2 hours. Remove peppers, and transfer sauce to a blender.
With supervision puree sauce until smooth, and pour back into pan.
After sauce is pureed put pan back in oven to reheat.
In a small bowl, combine the yeast with the water. Set aside.
In a large bowl, cream together 1/4 cup butter, 1/4 cup shortening, and 1/4 cup sugar until the mixture is light and fluffy. Mix in the 2 egg yolks, 2/3 cup milk, and 1 tsp salt, combining well.
Stir in the dissolved yeast and 4 cups flour, and mix until the ingredients are thoroughly blended into a soft dough.
Cover the dough with a towel, and set the dough aside to rise to about double in size, approximately 1 to 1 1/2 hours.
After chef koochooloo has made balls set them aside to double in size again, about 45 minutes to one hour.
Pinch off pieces of dough about the size of a golf ball, flatten the balls slightly, and transfer them to the baking sheet.
After fluffed up gently indent the top of the dough with your thumb, fairly deep.
Preheat oven to 400°F , butter a baking dish or line with baking paper then set aside.
Cut the bread into large cubes or slice into the desired shape.( For the bottom layer use long slices,  and for the top used cubed bread.)
In the large bowl lightly beat 2 eggs, 3 tbsp milk, 2 tbsp sugar and some of the spices until well combined.
Mix the bread cubes/slices into the bowl making sure that they are all well coated with the egg mixture.Keep in bowl and set aside.
Peel and grate the apples into the bowl.
Sprinkle the spices and raisins into the grated apples. Using your hands or a spoon mix the spices into the apples until everything is well combined.
(Now you will need the soaked bread and the baking dish) Make a bottom layer on the baking dish with some of the soaked bread, but you’ll need to reserve enough bread for the top layer.
Once the bottom bread layer is in place evenly spread the grated apple mixture on top. Make sure to keep a little to top it off.
Lastly cover the apple layer with another layer of soaked bread cubes.
Place in the center of preheated oven and bake for 25 minutes allowing for both the top bread layer to brown and the bottom layer to have solidify.
Mash apricots, stir in 2 tablespoons of sugar and let filling cool. Set aside.
Cream butter and cream cheese until fluffy; add ¾ cup sugar and beat well.
Combine apricots and water in a heavy saucepan and cook covered over medium heat until apricots are soft, then cook for 10 minutes uncovered.
Shape dough into a ball and chill for 1 hour.
Turn dough onto well-floured surface, working with only half the dough. Roll into 1/8 inch thickness and cut into 2 inch squares.
Spoon 1/2 teaspoon of apricot filling into the center of the square. Bring four corners to center, pinching to seal.
Bake at 400° F for about 15 minutes.
Peel all vegetables (carrot, tomato, potato, zucchini, onion, and garlic cloves) and chop into medium size pieces.
Fill up half a medium deep pan with water. Add lentils, carrot, tomato, potato and garlic.
Open the can of chicken broth using safe can opener.
With the help of a grownup mix all cooked veggies and lentils together using a hand mixer
Add butter over strained vegetable mix, and season using salt, pepper and cumin.
Boil over high heat for 20-25 minutes.
Peel and wash the shrimp, then pat dry.
Place shrimp in large self sealing plastic bag.
Prepare the couscous according to the package, substitute the chicken broth for water.
Add a tsp. of oil, the garlic, tarragon, thyme, and Old Bay seasoning in the bag, and then seal it.
Gently turn and “massage” the bag to coat the shrimp. Refrigerate for 1 hour.
Combine lemon juice and butter (1/4 cups) in a bowl, set aside.
Divide the spinach among individual bowls.
Spoon the couscous onto the spinach.
Sauté the shrimp in a large skillet with the marinade over medium heat for 3 to 5 minutes.
Pour half of the butter over the shrimp.
Arrange the shrimp and the couscous.
Pour remaining lemon butter over everything.
Peel and cube the eggplant, then soak in salted water for 15 minutes.
Cut lamb into 1-inch squares and sauté in butter until brown on all sides.
Add onion and eggplant, seasonings and consommé to the casserole.
Fry onion in the skillet, until golden brown.
Brown raw rice in a dry skillet and blend with canned tomatoes (2 cups) and their juice.
Bake until lamb is tender, about 90 minutes
Pour over the contents of the casserole
Slice peppers (3 sweet peppers green, yelow, red) in half from stem to bottom and remove stem
Remove seeds and membranes, set aside
Add onion, corn, sausage, breaking it apart with a spoon or spatula, and cook until the sausage is no longer pink.
Add crumbled corn bread (2 cups) or a little water if the mixture seems too dry
Divide filling among peppers evenly and top with shredded cheese.
Bake peppers at 350F, covered, for about 30 minutes, or until the cheese is melted and peppers are tender.
After Little Chef has peeled the potatoes, boil them in a pot of boiling salted water.
After the Big Chef has boiled the potatoes, combine potatoes with salt, and melted butter.
Melt the butter in a pan, add the cooked potatoes and then sprinkle with the salt.
Boil bratwurst, frankfurters, or knackwurst sausages for five minutes.
Sprinkle with the fresh chopped parsley, shake the pan to distribute the parsley and serve immediately.
Cover baking sheet pan with parchment paper.
Coat a medium size casserole dish with cooking spray or butter.
Combine squash, brussel sprouts, shallots, spice blend, oil, salt and pepper. Toss to coat well, then scatter into a single layer on parchment covered sheet pan.
Whisk eggs. Stir in cheeses, parsley, and lemon zest. Add salt and pepper to taste. Fold into spaetzle mixture in the casserole.
After Little Chef has spread squash mixture on to baking sheet, put in oven and bake for 30 minutes, take out and out to side.
Add in the cooked spaetzle to casserole dish.
Bake the spaetzle mixture until browned on top.
Bring water to a boil.  Cook the 1lb elbow macaroni according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.
Grate the 1 cup sharp cheddar cheese.

In a large mixing bowl, combine the 3/4 cups mayonnaise, 1/4 tsp garlic powder, 3 tablespoons of pineapple juice from the canned tidbits, salt, and ground black pepper.  Mix well and then taste.  Adjust the taste if necessary.
Add the carrots, macaroni, corn, onion, raisins, and pineapple tidbits in the mixing bowl.  Toss thoroughly until the ingredients are well distributed.
Cover the mixing bowl with a cling wrap and refrigerate for about an hour.
Blot the asparagus (5 stalks) dry with a clean kitchen towel, then cut into 1/2-inch slices with child-safe scissors.
Fill a large skillet with 1 inch of hot water and bring to a boil. Add asparagus. Partially cover and cook the asparagus until tender-crisp, about 3 minutes. Drain; refresh under cold water.
Coat six 10-ounce ramekins with butter and add fine bread crumbs.
Place ramekins on a large rimmed baking sheet.
Position rack on lowest level of oven; preheat to 375°F.
Heat 3/4 cups milk in a small saucepan over medium heat until hot.
Get the milk mixture from the Big Chef and whisk in 1/4 teaspoon each of salt, pepper and nutmeg.
Whisk in 4 egg yolks, one at a time, and truffle oil, and stir in the asparagus and cheese.

Place 8 egg whites in a large bowl. Beat with an electric mixer, slowly increasing the speed, until they begin to foam. Add the remaining 1/4 teaspoon salt and continue to beat until the whites hold their shape.

Using a rubber spatula, gently stir one-third of the whites into the egg yolk mixture to lighten it. Gently fold in the remaining egg whites just until blended. Divide the soufflé mixture among the prepared ramekins, filling them almost to the top.
Melt butter in a medium saucepan over medium-low heat.
Whisk in flour and cook, whisking often, for 2 minutes.
Turn off heat and slowly whisk in hot milk.
Return the heat to medium-low and continue whisking until the mixture is thickened, 3 to 4 minutes. Remove from heat and put in a large bowl to give to Little Chefs.
Once the Little Chefs have finished their duties, bake the soufflés on the bottom rack until puffy and golden, about 20 to 25 minutes.
Slice fennel into very thin pieces.
Cut off the tops and the bottoms of the grapefruit and oranges. Slice off the peel and the white pith, and cut in into segments.
In a small bowl, beat the 3 eggs, 2/3 cup milk, 2 Tbsp. melted butter, and 1/4 tsp. salt until well combined-about 20 seconds
Sift the 1/3 cup flour into a medium size bowl or a 2 quart measuring cup, then add the liquid mixture, beating until well combined-about 1 minute.
After chef koochooloo has finished cover mixture loosely with plastic wrap; let stand for at least 1 hour refrigerated or at room temperature.
Brush butter on the bottom of a crepe pan or skillet.
Stir the batter well, pour 2 tablespoons of batter into the skillet, and quickly tip it back and forth so that the batter evenly coats the bottom.
Cook until the crepe edges are golden brown-about 1 minute. Slide a spatula under the crepe, flip it over, and cook for about 30 seconds.
Trim the cauliflower & break into small florets.
Boil in salted water for 10-15 minutes or until just tender.
Drain in a colander and then place in a buttered ovenproof baking dish.
Heat and whisking with a wire whisk continuously until the sauce thickens, boils and is smooth.
Add the 1.33 ml. milk, 3 Tbsp. flour and 1/2 cup butter to a saucepan.
Add three-quarters of the grated cheese, mustard, a pinch of nutmeg and seasoning.
Allow to simmer for a further 2 minutes. Allow chef koochooloo to add cheese.
Cook for further minute stirring well.
Pour the sauce over the cauliflower.
After sauce has been poured over cauliflower add the remaining cheese, and breadcrumbs, over the top.
Bake for about 15 to 25 minutes until golden brown and bubbling.
In a large skillet, melt the butter over medium heat; add the chicken and cook for 6 to 8 minutes per side, or until browned on both sides.
Measure and add the remaining ingredients.
Cover, reduce heat to low. Cook for 5 to 10 minutes, or until the chicken is fork-tender and no pink remains.
Wash and cut the rhubarb in 3 cm (2 inches) chunks and place in a sieve sitting on a bowl.
Butter and flour a 23 cm tart tin, cutting out the excess pastry around the rim.
Preheat the oven at 360 degrees F
Place the drained rhubarb in a fry pan and sauté on high heat for a few minutes until just softened.
Mix the eggs, cream, sugar, ground almond and almond essence for 20 seconds on speed 3 (medium speed).
Sprinkle with the 1/2 cup of sugar and let it soften for 2 hours so the water drains out. Remove the pre-made pastry from the fridge while you are waiting.
Roll the pastry and place in the tin.
Pour over the rhubarb chunks and bake for 30 minutes.
Reduce the reserved rhubarb juice in a small saucepan and brush over the tart while it’s still hot. Let the tart cool down before taking out of the tin.
Cut the pomegranate in half and remove 1/2 cup seeds. Keep the seeds and throw away the rest.
Carefully whisk 2 1/2 cups yogurt or curds.
In a large bowl, combine the pineapple, yogurt, and pomegranate.
Add 2 tsp sugar, 1 tsp cayenne pepper, and 2 tsp cumin powder. Add salt to taste.
Refrigerate for at least 1 hour before serving.
In a small bowl, whisk together 1/4 cup olive oil, 3/4 tsp coriander powder, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1/2 tsp salt and pepper.
Brush each potato slice with a layer of the spiced oil.
Add 1 lb. Potatoes and onions in baking dish.
Bake for 30 minutes or until potatoes are golden brown.
Warm up Indian Bread (Rotis) to go with the Potatoes.
Measure the salt, 1/4 tsp black pepper, and 1/2 cup vegetable oil.
Mix potato, onion, eggs, crackers, salt, and pepper together in a large bowl

Pour enough vegetable oil into a skillet to fill about 1/2-inch deep; heat over medium-high heat. Drop spoonfuls of the potato mixture, first pressing potato mixture against the side of the bowl to remove excess liquid, into the hot oil; slightly flatten the latkes into the oil with the back of your spoon so they are evenly thick.
Cook in hot oil until browned and crisp, 3 to 5 minutes per side.
Drain latkes on a plate lined with a paper towel.

Place prunes and apricots into two separate pots filled with water and bring to a rolling boil over high heat. Cook the fruit, uncovered, stirring occasionally, until the fruit is tender, about 15 minutes. Drain fruit in a colander and mash together in a bowl using a fork. Set aside.
Chop almonds and apricots in a food processor, with a few dashes of lemon juice. Chop pecans and prunes in a food processor, with a few dashes of lemon juice.
Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Mix 6 oz prune and 3 oz pecan pieces in a bowl. Mix 6 oz apricot and 3 oz almond pieces in another  bowl.
Whisk eggs, 1 cup sugar, oil, 1 tbsp lemon zest, and orange zest together in a bowl and set aside.
Mix flour, almonds, baking powder, and salt. Blend & cut in butter until mixture is crumbly. Combine egg, lemon juice, and water only to incorporate.
Roll out dough to about ¼ inch in thickness on a lightly floured surface. Cut circles out using a 3 inch cookie cutter or the rim of a large drinking glass.
Place a teaspoon of this filling in the center of a circle of cookie dough.

To fold the cookies, first take the left side of the circle and fold it towards the center to make a flap that covers the left third of the circle. Then, take the right side of the circle and fold it towards the center, overlapping the upper part of the left side flap to create a triangular tip at the top of the circle. A small triangle of filling should still be visible in the center. Grasp the bottom part of the circle and fold it upward to create a third flap and complete the triangle.
Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, about 20 minutes. Cool in the pans for 10 minutes before removing to cool completely on a wire rack.
Cook the couscous according to the package directions. Drain the cooked couscous and rinse with cold water to stop the cooking process. Help the Little Chef with their duties.
Cut the cucumber in half and using a spoon, scoop out the seeds and discard. Finely chop the cucumber, discarding the ends.
Squeeze the lemons and measure out 2 tablespoons of lemon juice.
Finely chop the parsley and mint.
In a large bowl, add the ½ cup olive oil, chopped shallot, and lemon juice. Whisk to combine.
Add in the cooked couscous, cucumber, tomatoes, parsley and mint.
Add salt and pepper, to taste.

In a large pan add 1 Tbsp. olive oil, onions, red pepper, tomatoes, mushrooms and zucchini and sauté all the vegetables until the onion has become translucent and the mushroom is cooked, about 5 minutes. Set vegetable mixture aside.

Take a large bowl and mix the other ingredients, 3 Tbsp. flour, 1/2 Tbsp. baking powder, 6 eggs, 3/4 cup milk, salt, pepper, 1/2 cup cheese (or not, depending on your dietary preference). Once you have this mix is time to add the vegetables and combine until everything is mixed perfectly.

Take your pastry dough and spread it out in a round baking dish, ensuring it is covering all surfaces. Pour in the vegetable mixture and put it in the oven for 40 to 45 minutes. It is ready when a toothpick comes out clean from the center.
Let cool for about 5 minutes and you are ready to serve! Enjoy.
Assist with peeling the potatoes and placing them into the pot.
Use a measuring cup to help pour enough water into the pot to cover the potatoes.

Preheat the oven to 350 F. Place the potatoes in the pot, cover with water, and bring to a boil. Cook for about 20 minutes, or until the potatoes are easily pierced with the knife. Remove from the heat, drain, and let sit until they are cool enough to handle. Cut the potatoes into small dice and set aside.
When potatoes have cooled and have been cut by the Big Chef, help place potatoes in a bowl to be set aside.
In a sauté pan, cook the bacon over medium to medium-low heat until browned. Remove the bacon from the pan, placing on a plate lined with paper towels.
Put paper towels on a plate to use with the cooked bacon.
Drain most of the bacon grease from the pan, leaving 1 tablespoon of fat in the skillet and add the onion. Cook over medium heat for about 5 minutes, until golden brown.
Add the bacon and wine to the onions and cook for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add the potatoes and season with salt and pepper, to taste.
Help to season the potatoes with salt and pepper.

Remove the potato mixture from the heat and place half of it in an ovenproof dish. Have the little chef spread half the cheese slices atop the potato mixture. Cover this with the other half of the potato mixture. Top with the remainder of the cheese.
Bake in the hot oven for 20 minutes, or until golden brown and bubbling.
In a bowl, mix together the flour,almond milk, salt, and vanilla extract.
Whisk in 1 egg yolk and 1 whole egg, one at a time
Whisk the batter so that it runs smooth.
Give the bowl to big chef.
Melt butter in a medium saucepan over medium-low heat.
Cut bananas into circular pieces for topping the crepes.
Whisk the whipping cream in a bowl to make peaks.

While Little Chef cuts the bananas and whisks the cream, pour 2 tbsp of batter into the pan and rotate the pan so the batter coats it evenly. Cook the crepe for about 30 seconds on one side and then flip it to cook the other side. Serve hot.
Broccolini and Carrot Bisque with Feta, Cherry and Pecan Crumble
Wash the onions, broccolini, and carrots.
Broccolini and Carrot Bisque with Feta, Cherry and Pecan Crumble
Roughly chop the vegetables (depending on the Little Chef’s age).
Broccolini and Carrot Bisque with Feta, Cherry and Pecan Crumble
In a bowl, separate the egg yolks from the whites.
Broccolini and Carrot Bisque with Feta, Cherry and Pecan Crumble
Measure out the broth, spices, feta, cherries, and pecans.
Broccolini and Carrot Bisque with Feta, Cherry and Pecan Crumble
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. While the oven is preheating, chop up all of your vegetables, pecans, and dried cherries and set aside for later.
Broccolini and Carrot Bisque with Feta, Cherry and Pecan Crumble

On medium low heat, melt 1 oz. of butter and 1 tsp. of olive oil. Once melted, add 1 oz. of tapioca flour, stirring constantly. You are making a roux for your soup! Keep stirring for about 5-7 minutes until a somewhat khaki color is achieved.
Broccolini and Carrot Bisque with Feta, Cherry and Pecan Crumble

To the roux, slowly add 2.5 cups of broth while stirring constantly. Once added, add 1/2 tsp. coarse black pepper, 1 tsp. of turmeric, 1/2 tsp. of allspice or ground cloves, 2 tsp. of garlic powder, 1 cup of broccolini STEMS (NOT florets), 1 cup of chopped carrots, and the 2 chopped red onions.
Broccolini and Carrot Bisque with Feta, Cherry and Pecan Crumble

Let this simmer for 20 minutes. While the soup is simmering, in a baking sheet drizzle some olive oil and toss 1 cup of chopped broccolini florets, 1/4 cup of dried chopped cherries, 1/4 of chopped pecans, 2 oz. of crumbled feta, 1/4 tsp. of all spice, 1/4 tsp. sea salt, and 1/4 tsp. black pepper.
Broccolini and Carrot Bisque with Feta, Cherry and Pecan Crumble
Bake this mixture in the oven at 350 degrees for 5-7 minutes, depending on your oven.
Broccolini and Carrot Bisque with Feta, Cherry and Pecan Crumble

Remove the soup from the heat and pour the pot’s contents into a high-powered blender and add the 3 egg yolks. Blend the soup until a uniform appearance has been achieved. Add salt to the soup to taste.
Broccolini and Carrot Bisque with Feta, Cherry and Pecan Crumble
Ladle some of the soup into a bowl, top it with the broccolini floret crumble mixture, and enjoy!
Cut/peel the outside of the pineapple.
Mix the wet and dry ingredients together.
Place the mixed ingredients into the baking dish.
Place the baking dish into the oven.
After 20 minutes pull out Clafoutti and let cool for 5 minutes.
Toss your diced bread in two tablespoons olive oil, 2 cloves minced garlic, 1 teaspoon salt and 1/2 teaspoon pepper.
After chef koochooloo does step 1 bake for 10 minutes until golden brown.
Whisk together remaining 1/3 cup olive oil, 2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar, lemon juice, paprika, and 1 teaspoon salt.
Cool bread and toss with tomatoes, cucumbers, red onion, pine nuts and cilantro. Then combine with dressing.
Open chickpea cans, drain liquid to a bowl and keep for later.
Place chickpeas and garlic in workbowl of a food processor and pulse until chickpeas are roughly chopped.
Add in tahini, lemon juice, olive oil, and 1/4 cup of reserved liquid from cans of chickpeas.
Puree until smooth, stopping to scrap down sides of workbowl as needed. Thin hummus with additional reserved liquid if necessary. Add salt and pulse to combine.
Grind the poppy seeds in a coffee grinder in batches for about 15-20 seconds per batch, till they are ground soft and powdery.
Melt the butter in a saucepan over medium heat. Whisk in the milk, sugar, honey and salt. Bring to a simmer, stirring occasionally, till the sugar dissolves and the honey melts.
Beat the eggs using a whisker.
Pour about 1 cup of the butter mixture into a cup.
Gradually begin drizzling the mixture into the beaten eggs, whisking constantly until all of the hot liquid is integrated into the eggs. Do not pour too quickly, or you will scramble your eggs.
Slowly pour the egg and butter mixture back into the saucepan, whisking constantly.
Continue to whisk and cook for 3-5 more minutes over medium heat till the mixture thickens and turns light yellow. It is ready when it thickly coats the back of a spoon and remove from heat.
After the butter mixture is removed from heat whisk the ground poppy seeds into the buttery liquid and stir well to blend all ingredients.
Allow filling to cool to room temperature before using.
Sprinkle the flour over the meat.
Heat half of both the butter and oil in a frying pan.
As soon as the butter foams, add the meat and brown it very quickly on all sides and set aside on a plate.
Add the rest of the butter and oil to the pan and sauté the onion, garlic and sage for a few minutes.
Stir well and when the mushrooms start to soften, continue cooking for about 5 minutes longer.
Add the wine to deglaze the bottom of the pan, using a wooden spoon to scrape away any crust that has formed.
Add the veal and cook, stirring, until the wine has evaporated.
Turn the heat down to low and cook for another 10 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 375° F, and grease a 9 inch pie tin.
Roll out two-thirds of the pastry and use it to line the pie tin.
Bake the pie crust for 7-10 minutes.
Melt the butter in a frying pan then add the onion and bacon. Fry over a low heat for 3 minutes.
Add the chopped onion and the bacon to the butter in the frying pan.
Add the meat in the frying pan.
Prepare the beef boullion, and add the bouillon with the wine in the pot.
Add the salt, marjoram, and paprika to the mixture.
Simmer for 5 minutes, let cool, spread into crust, then roll remaining pastry dough.
Brush the edges with beaten egg.
Heat the rice milk to a very warm temperature and add the margarine.
Whisk together the dry ingredients, flour, yeast, sugar, and salt-in a large bowl.
Mix the rice milk and margarine mixture with the dry ingredients until it forms dough.
Remove the finished dough onto a flat surface and knead it for about 5 minutes.
Let the dough rise and double in size. Cover with a dish towel or a plastic wrap. Leave for about 30 minutes.
After 30 minutes of the dough rising, divide the dough into 6 pieces. Use a rolling pin to form oval shapes about 15cm/6 inches long.
Use a sharp knife to cut four slits into each piece.
Carefully stretch and place the rolls on a baking sheet. Let them rest for around 30 minutes.
Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until golden brown.
Brush the melted butter over the rolls with a pastry brush.
Set a large pot of salted water (approx. 5 liters) to boil.
Cut the bread into 1-inch thick slices. Give to the Little Chef.
After the Big Chef has sliced the bread, put the pieces on a baking sheet. Drizzle the bread with olive oil.
After Little Chef has put olive oil on bread, cook in the oven for 10 minutes. Once bread is done, set aside to cool.
Wash basil and pat dry. Tear the basil leaves into small pieces.
Place tomatoes, basil, salt and pepper in a bowl and drizzle with olive oil.  Stir to combine all ingredients.
After the bread has cooled slightly, rub the garlic on the toasted bread.
Put a spoonful of the tomato mixture on each piece of toasted bread.
In a large pot of boiling salted water, cook pasta until al dente, about 13-15 minutes.
Wash parsley and pat dry. Take parsley leaves off the stems.
Tear parsley leaves into small pieces.
Meanwhile, in a large skillet, heat olive oil and cook garlic for 30 seconds. Add cherry tomatoes, oregano, salt and pepper. Cook on low heat for 10 minutes.
Add penne, olives, parsley and parmesan to skillet and toss to combine.
Preheat the oven to 400ºF and line a large baking sheet with parchment paper.
Dice the eggplant into bite-sized cubes and toss them onto the baking sheet.
Drizzle the eggplant with olive oil and sprinkle with salt and fresh cracked black pepper.
Roast the eggplant for 20 to 25 minutes, rotating the baking sheet half-way through the roasting time.
Make the pasta according to package directions.
Make the arrabiata sauce by heating a large pan over medium heat.
Add to the saucepan 2 tablespoons olive oil, then add the minced garlic and cook for 3 minutes until it is golden. Add the crushed tomatoes and red pepper flakes.
Bring the sauce to a simmer and let it cook for 20 minutes.
Once the eggplant is done roasting, add it to the arrabiata sauce, tossing to coat.
Spoon the eggplant arrabiata sauce over a bowl of pasta and serve.
Heat oil in heavy large pot over medium heat. Add onions, pancetta, prosciutto, and garlic and sauté until mixture begins to brown, about 10 minutes.
In a large bowl, dissolve yeast in 1/2 cup warm water. Add the sugar, shortening, salt, egg, remaining water and 4 cups flour; beat until smooth. Stir in enough remaining flour to form a stiff dough.

Turn onto a floured surface; knead until smooth and elastic, about 6-8 minutes. Place in a greased bowl, turning once to grease the top. Cover and let rise in a warm place until doubled, about 1 hour.
Punch dough down. Turn onto a lightly floured surface; divide in half. Shape each portion into a loaf. Place seam side down on greased baking sheets.
With a sharp knife, make four shallow diagonal slashes across the top of each loaf. Cover and let rise until doubled, about 1 hour.
Bake for 37-42 minutes or until golden brown. Remove from pans to wire racks to cool.
Slice Italian bread in thick slices.
Butter bread slices after it has been cooled and cut.
Cook bread in pan until both sides are golden brown.

Put 1 oz of the dried red dulse seaweed and 1 oz. of dried green wakame seaweed in a large bowl and cover with cold water. Let soak 5 to 10 minutes, until softened. Drain in a colander, pat dry and place in a serving bowl.
Watch over little chef, help slice the vegetables.
Cut and slice 1 cucumber, 1 avocado, handful of baby tomatoes, and 4 red radishes.
To make the dressing, whisk together 2 tbsp. vinegar, 2 tsp. sugar, 2 tsp. soy sauce and 1 tbsp. oil in a small bowl.
Spoon half the dressing over the seaweed, add the juice of 1 lime and toss gently. Taste and add salt to taste if necessary.
Mix the salad with the sliced radishes, tomatoes, cucumber and avocado. Season them lightly with salt and drizzle with the remaining dressing.
Finely chop the onion, and mince the garlic clove.
Heat 1 tbsp. of vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the onion and garlic and cook them for 3 minutes, stirring often.

Add .75 lbs of beef and use a wooden spoon or a spatula to break it up while it cooks, until it is no longer red, about 3 minutes. Stir in 1/2 cup of the salsa, 2 tsp. of chili powder, and the 1/2 tsp. salt and 1/4 tsp. of pepper.
Top each tortilla with 1/4 cup of the beef mixture, spreading it to an inch from the edges. Sprinkle cheese evenly over the beef.
Roll up the tortillas and place them on a foil-lined baking sheet with the seam sides down.
Brush the taquitos lightly with vegetable oil, then bake them until the filling is heated through and the tortillas are lightly browned, about 8 to 12 minutes.

In a bowl, combine 1 tsp. of chile powder, 1 tsp. of salt, 1/2 tsp. cumin, 1/2 tsp. onion powder, 1/4 tsp. of garlic powder, 1 tbsp. of cornstarch, 2 tbsp. of lime juice, 1/4 cup of water, and 2 tbsp. of olive oil.
Cut the 5 avocados, dice 1/4 of a small red onion, and mince 1 garlic clove.
In a large bowl, mash together the avocados, onion, garlic, 2 tbsp. of olive oil, juice from 3 limes, and salt and pepper – to taste.
Cut the pomegranate in half, then tear the halves into smaller pieces.
Pick out all the seeds and discard the flesh from the pomegranate.
Fold a small handful of pomegranate seeds and a small handful of cilantro leaves, roughly chopped into the guacamole.
Cut the 4 avocados in half and take the seeds out.
Cut the avocados, 2 tomatoes, 1 purple onion, and 2 cloves of garlic.
In a large bowl, mash the 4 cut up avocados.
Add the cut onion garlic and tomatoes, 1 bunch of cilantro, 2 chile  peppers (optional),  juice from 1 lime, and salt and pepper – to taste.
Add 1 cup of cream cheese, diced bell pepper, 2 cans of tuna, small bag of thawed vegetables, and 1 tbsp. of mayonnaise to a large bowl and stir to mix. Give the bowl to the Big Chef.
Put all ingredients in a blender and mix until well combined.
Remove the crusts of the bread and cut into shapes, if desired.

Lay out 6 slices of bread. Take the blended ingredients and spoon an equal amount on to each piece of bread. Put one slice of cheese on each sandwich and top with another piece of bread. The sandwiches are ready to serve.
Heat butter in pan until melted.
Add onion to pan with melted butter.
Chop and press garlic cloves and add to pan.
Add risotto rice to the pan, cook gently stirring all the time until rice becomes translucent.
Boil tomatoes for 5 minutes or until skin starts to break. Take tomatoes out of boiling water, wait for them to cool off and remove skin.
Boil 800 ml of water and add Maggi Vegetable Broullion stock. Dissolve and add to the risotto. Simmer for about 25 minutes until rice is ready.
Fry bacon slowly in a pan until crispy. Remove from heat and let little chef dry with paper.
Cook & shred the chicken beforehand, or buy pre-cooked, shredded chicken.
Cut cucumbers, tomatoes, and cheese into thin slices.
Chop up the celery into small pieces.
Lay out 12 slices of bread and spread butter thinly on one side of each slice.
Put 2 layers of cucumber slices on top of half of the bread.
Sprinkle the cucumber slices with salt.
Put a plain slice on top of each slice with cucumber.
Lay out 12 slices of bread and spread mayo thinly on one side of each slice.
Put the chicken, mayo, onion, celery and salt in a bowl and mix well.
Put ¼ cup of chicken salad on top of half of the bread slices.
Put a plain slice on top of each slice with chicken salad.
Lay out 12 slices of bread and spread butter thinly on one side of each slice.
Put a layer of cheese on top of half of those slices.
Add a layer of tomato slices on top of the cheese.
Put a plain slice on top of each slice with cheese & tomato.
After the sandwiches are assembled by the Little Chef, cut the crusts off and slice each sandwich into 4 triangles.
Hull the strawberries, removing the leaves and stems.
Place the strawberries in a colander and rinse well.
Place the strawberries in a dessert bowl or cup.
Pour in cream to your liking.
Get yourself a wide, casserole-type pan and fill it with boiling water from the kettle. Bring it to a light simmer over a medium heat.
Depending on your pan, a really soft poached egg should take around 2 minutes and a soft to firm one will need 4 minutes.
Crack one of your eggs into a cup and gently pour it into the water in one fluid movement.
Repeat with the rest of the eggs.
Finely chop the kumquats and oranges and combine.
Using a mug, measure them into a large pot.
Add one mugful of sugar to the pot for every mugful of the fruit mixture. Mix in the lemon juice, about 4 tablespoons.
Using a coffee mug, add 3 mug full of water per each mugful of fruit. Give to big chef.
After chef koochooloo has prepared orange and kumquat mixture, let stand in a cool place for 12 hours, or overnight.
Bring the fruit mixture to the boil, reduce heat and simmer until the rind is very tender. Remove from heat, and measure cooked fruit.
Put the nuts into a food processor ahead of time until it ends up in a chunky powder.
Add cinnamon and lemon zest into the nut powder.
Mix the butter, honey, and vanilla into a separate bowl.
Combine the dry ingredients with the wet ingredients.
Roll little balls out of the dough that you made.
Chop the onion and cut the clove of garlic in half.
Heat a large dutch oven or pot with a drizzle of the olive oil. Add the onion, garlic and a cup of broth. Cook until the onion has softened. Remove the garlic.
Chop the carrots, red bell peppers and artichoke hearts. Slice the mushrooms. Give all to the Little Chef. Let the Little Chef complete their duties before continuing.
Add the carrots, bell peppers and snow peas to the pan with the onions. Cook until softened
Stir a little, then salt to taste and add the arborio rice
Add artichoke hearts and mushrooms, continue to cook and add broth as needed.
Add the lima beans, more broth and cook for 10 minutes.
Add the tomato puree, any remaining broth, and the saffron and paprika.
Stir one last time. (Note: It is important not to over stir.) Cook on high for 7 minutes. Reduce temperature to medium and cook for 10 more minutes.
Grill the eggplant and peppers and tomatoes for 4-5 minutes or until needed, the tomatoes may need less time and can be pulled off the grill sooner.
Remove the skins and seeds of the vegetables once they have cooled. Cut up the grilled vegetables.
Mix the vegetables, garlic, and parsley in a bowl.
Mix vinegar, olive oil, and salt into a small bowl.
Add the bowl of seasoning to the chopped vegetables.
Place the pomegranate juice in a medium-size pot.
Chop and dice onions, tomatoes, and peppers.
Heat the butter in a pot, sauté the onions for a couple of minutes.
Add the meat, once all sides are brown, add in peppers.
Add tomato paste and stir for another couple of minutes.
Add tomatoes and cook for another 5 minutes.
Add the hot water and let it simmer until the meat is tender, it will take around an hour.
Wash and prick the eggplants with a fork on at least two sides.
Place the eggplants on a gas burner or under a broiler, turning them frequently until the eggplant is collapsed and the skin is charred.
Let them cool, then peel the eggplants and discard the stems.
Mash the cooked eggplants together with the back of a fork, in a bowl, and then mix with the lemon juice.
Heat the butter in a pot. Add flour and stir constantly to make a roux on low heat.
Warm the milk and add slowly. Whisk to make the mixture smooth. Simmer for 4-5 minutes.
Add the eggplant puree and mix well.
Add some salt, black pepper, and cheese. Mix well. Simmer for another 2-3 minutes.
Cut the crust off of the 4 slices of bread.
Flatten the slices of bread with a plate or a rolling pin. Do not flatten one edge so we can combine the bread slices.
Combine the bread with a rolling pin or by using your fingers.
Place the slices of ham and cheese onto the bread.
Place the spinach on top of the ham and cheese.
Roll the sandwich lengthwise( the longer way) and make sure to pinch closed.
After chef koochooloo has done the tasks place the sandwich into the fridge for 1 hour.
Take out and cut into pieces.
Cut the onion in half and add to the water, along with the bay leaves.
Fill a large soup pot with water, enough to completely submerge the octopus.
Bring the water to a boil, and submerge the octopus 3 or 4 times to scald it.
Bring the water back to a boil and place the octopus in the water, leave it in there.
Reduce the heat to a simmer, and cook for about 20 minutes, larger ones may take up to 45 minutes.
Remove the octopus from the water.
Cut the cooked octopus into ovals.
Place the bread slices in a medium bowl topped with a fine mesh sieve.
Squeeze the tomato halves over the sieve to remove the seeds and allow the juices to run into the bowl with the bread.
Place the tomatoes into the pitcher of your blender as you work.
Press the seeds and any pulp through the sieve using a rubber spatula or your hands.
Allow the bread to soak in the tomato juice, will take 20 to 30 minutes.
Use the blender and process the tomatoes, the bread and the rest of the ingredients on the highest speed until it is smooth.
Once the blender is done, use a whisk to bring all of the ingredients together.
Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 2 to 3 hours.
In a bowl, beat the 8 egg yolks with the sugar until they are blended.
Add the corn flour to yolks and beat for 2 minutes.
Cook the 2 cups of milk over low heat with the lemon zest and the cinnamon stick.
Once milk is hot remove the cinnamon stick.
Gradually add the warm milk to the mixture of yolks and sugar without stopping to beat.
Continue to mix until the mixture thickens.
Let it cool, put in the fridge for 3 hours.
Sprinkle a tablespoon of brown sugar on the top of the cream and burn it with the blowtorch to make the caramelized layer.
Beat 4 egg whites to soft peaks, adding a pinch of salt towards the end.
Beat egg yolks and sugar until light yellow. Add 500ml milk and 1 cup of flour, a little at a time to avoid lumps.
Fold in egg whites. Let the batter rest for about ten minutes.
Chop up the 2 small cabbage, 1 cup of onion, and garlic clove.
Set out 4 shallow pans (pan 1 for flour, pan 2 for mixture, pan 3 for breadcrumbs, and pan 4 for parchment paper).
Line pan 4 with parchment paper (alternatively, you can just use a cutting board instead of pan 4).
Fill pan 2 with 2 eggs, 1 tbsp cream and lemon juice (squeeze 2 lemon wedges).
Fill pan 1 with 1.2 cups flour and fill pan 3 with 1 cup breadcrumbs.
Heat oil in a large skillet at medium heat until it reaches 350- 360° F.
Season the 6 cutlets on both sides with salt and pepper as desired.
Use tongs to dredge the cutlet in the flour of pan 1,being sure to evenly coat both sides.
Use tongs to coat the cutlet in the mixture of pan 2 and use tongs to coat the cutlet in the bread crumbs of pan 3.
Press down the bread crumbs into the cutlet on both sides.
Move cutlets to a cutting board or to a pan lined with parchment paper (pan 4) to sit for 15 minutes while they dry.
Mix all the meatball ingredients together and roll into balls, 2-1/2 inches in diameter, firmly packed.
To make the broth, heat 3 tbsp oil in a pan or soup kettle, add 2 sliced onions and 1/4 tsp turmeric, and stir-fry over moderate heat until light brown, about 3 minutes.
Add 1 cup chopped tomatoes and 1 tsp salt to broth mixture and stir-fry for 2 minutes more.
Add 5 cups water and bring to a boil.
Take each herbed ball and roll it firmly; add the balls to the broth very carefully, one at a time, so that they do not not fall apart
Cover the pan and cook over moderately low heat, without stirring, for 45 minutes.
Add 1 cup green peas and cook for 10 minutes more.
The broth will reduce somewhat, the balls swell considerably due to the expansion of the rice.

Measure and wash 3 cups rice in cold water, make sure that you have it a bowl with enough room to cover it with water and repeat this 2 or 3 times, then add some salt to it, and leave it to soak for 2 hours.
Roll the ground turkey into small circular balls.

Take the sour cherries and place them in a saucepan, add 1/4 cup sugar, stir and simmer for about 15 minutes at medium heat. After this take the cherries and with a colander separate them from the juice. Return the drained juices to the pot and let them boil and medium to low heat for about 10 minutes more. (We will use this juice later).

Fry the turkey balls in a saucepan lightly oiled, add 2 tsp turmeric, 2 tsp cinnamon, cardamom, cloves, 1 tsp rose water, 1 tsp cumin, ginger and stir. After you have this mix turn off the heat and add the cherries. Be sure to mix properly in order to coat the cherries with the seasoning mix.

Let the rice boil on medium heat for about 8-10 minutes, until soft (but not cooked all the way) and drain the rice. In the same pot, add 1 tbsp saffron, grape-seed oil and enough water to cover the surface of the pot.

Then add the first layer of basmati rice.Take a few spoons of your cherry/turkey mixture and spread on top of the rice while mixing gently. Repeat this process with the remainder of the rice and your cherries. Cook on low, very low heat for another 50 minutes to an hour.

Now we are almost at the end. To add the finishing touches, heat 2 table spoons of oil in a small sauce pan and add the reserved cherry syrup you made before and add 1 teaspoon of cumin. Pour this over the rice as you serve it.
Chop 2 green onions in small pieces
Add 1/4 cup milk and whisk until well mixed
Add vegetable oil to a frying pan and transfer the mixture into the pan.
Fry the mixture over medium heat, flip when hardened.
Rinse and soak 1 1/2 cups barley in cool water for an hour.
Arrange the chopped onions at the bottom of the stockpot, add the chicken, 2 stalks celery, 1 garlic, bay leaf, 1/4 turmeric, salt and pepper. Add enough water to cover all of the ingredients.
After all ingredients in pot bring to a boil on medium-high. Reduce the heat, cover and cook on medium-low heat for about 45-50 minutes or until the chicken is fully cooked.
Remove the pot from the heat and let cool. Drain the soup and pour into a bowl for later use. Separate the chicken from the bones and shred into small pieces.
Place the soaked and drained barley in a large pot, add the strained chicken soup and enough water to cover up to 3 inches.
Bring to a boil for a couple of minutes on medium-high heat, reduce the heat, cover leaving the lid a little ajar and cook for 45 minutes.
To the pot add the shredded chicken and the shredded carrots. Add more hot water if needed. Cover and cook for another 40- 45 minutes on medium-low heat.
In the last 15 minutes of cooking add 3 tbsp lemon juice, taste and adjust the seasoning.
Add water to the oats and let them soften for 20 minutes.
Wash and cut apples in small pieces.
Juice the lemons into a small bowl.
Add the sweetened condensed milk to the oats and stir.
Sprinkle the lemon juice over the apples.
Add the grated apples to the oat mixture.
Let it bubble for 2 minutes, then remove from the heat and serve.
Bake for about 40 minutes until golden brown.
Add green beans to pan and stir-fry until cooked.
Finally add green beans and bacon to Risotto.
Stir risotto gently while mixing with rest of the ingredients until ready to serve.
Add penne and potatoes to the salted water. tir to make sure pasta doesn’t stick together.
Cook until tender, about 15 minutes. Drain penne and potatoes.
Heat butter/oil over medium-low heat in a frying pan.
Add onions to the pan and fry them until golden brown and put onto a plate.
Combine nestle creamer with salt and pepper.
In an ovenproof casserole dish, place 1/2 of the penne and potatoes.
Sprinkle with 1/2 of the grated cheese over the penne-potatoes.
Top with the remaining 1/2 of the penne-potatoes.
Pour the seasoned milk/cream evenly over the top.
Spread the browned onions on top.
Bake covered for 10-15 minutes until steaming hot and cheese is melted.
Warm up a large frying pan (10 - 12 inches in diameter) and melt 1 to 2 tablespoons of butter in it.
Stir the batter again, gently, and pour into hot pan. Sprinkle the raisins evenly over the top. Flip over (you may have to cut it into several portions to flip).
Cut or pull the pancake apart into bite size pieces while it continues to cook. When it is browned a bit, it is ready to serve.
In a 12-inch skillet over medium heat, heat oil and add the chopped vegetables.
Cook 8 minutes or until tender. Add the 1lb of sausage and cook about 4 minutes until sausages are heated through and vegetables are tender.
Stir in 1 tbsp of mustard, 1 tbsp of vinegar, some salt and pepper. Cook 1 minute longer.
Add cutlets to the oil,fry until golden on each side(about 1-2 minutes).
Place 300g of all-purpose flour in a bowl with 1.4 tsp salt and add the 200ml of lukewarm water, then add 30ml oil. Stir with a spoon until it comes together and you can work it with your hands.
Knead the dough until it is smooth, but not sticky, about 5 minutes. If you need to add more flour, only add it 1 teaspoon at a time.
Form the dough into a smooth ball, brush it with a little oil and place it back in the bowl for 1 hour, room temperature. Covering the dough with plastic wrap is fine, too.
Heat the 100g of butter in a pan until foaming and add the breadcrumbs. Toast them, stirring constantly, until they are medium brown. Let cool.
Soak the 1.5 cups of raisins in the 4 tsp orange juice. You can heat them for 30 seconds in the microwave and then soak them until you are ready for them.
Peel, core and chop the 7 cups of apples into small pieces. Add the 150g sugar, 4 tbsp lemon juice, 2tsp lemon zest, 1.5 cups raisins and 1.4 tsp ground cinnamon and mix well.

Preheat oven to 400° F. Roll out the dough on a lightly floured board to about 9 inches by 13 inches. Using your hands, gently stretch the dough thinner on all sides, working your way around the sheet of dough.
Take apple mixture and spread it over the center of the dough.
Brush exposed dough with melted butter. Fold in one side of the dough over the filling.
Spread the breadcrumbs over 2/3 of the dough and pat down evenly.
Fold other side of dough up and over filling to form a roll. Brush with butter. Bake at 400°F for 20 minutes and then at 350°F for 40-60 minutes longer. Remove from oven.
Transfer to a serving platter with a large spatula (or two). Cut into 1½-inch wide slices.
Cut the potatoes in half and place them in a large pot and cover with cold water. Add some salt, and cook until a easily pierced with a fork.
Once the potatoes are finished boiling, place them in a bowl full of ice.
Grate onion into a large bowl and finely chop the parsley.
Peel the potatoes and mash them.
Add the meat, 1/2 bread crumbs, 2 eggs, 3 tbsp parsley and spices, salt, pepper to the bowl.
Mix with hands. (You might want to wear gloves, this gets messy!)

Scoop individually with your hands and roll each into a ball, then flatten. (Iranians usually make oval shapes, but you can have fun with various geometric shapes. Experiment with making squares, triangles, pentagons, etc.) Give to Big Chef to cook.

After the Little Chef has performed their duties, heat olive oil in a pan on low heat. Place the patties in the pan with some distance between each. (Tip: Take a very small piece of the one of the patties and place in the pan, fry it a bit, then taste it to assess whether you need any more spices.)
Once all the kotlets are placed in the pan, fry on low heat. Stay near! Flip them when the kotlets seem crispy and have darkened a bit.
Cut the leeks for the confit. In a large saute pan, cook the leaks down with a few tablespoons of butter, 2 tbsp of water, and a pinch of salt. Let this cook down while you prepare the dough.
In a stand mixer, mix flour and salt and add butter in small pieces. Add all ice water and cider vinegar into the bowl.
Chop the 1lb pork shoulder into small squares
In a skillet, brown pork, then add 1 tsp salt, pepper(to your liking), onions, and garlic. Cook until pork is done.
Add 8 oz. tomato sauce, 1 tsp vinegar, 1 tsp soy sauce, 1 bay leaf, and water. If gravy is too thick, add more water.
Add 10 oz. peas and cook until done. Top with the 1 can of pimentos.
Grind walnuts (1/2 cup) and almonds (if bought whole).
Add 1 cup fresh dates and some water to processor.
Mix/blend dates and water in processor till paste like.
Mix in 1 tsp. cinnamon and 1/2 tsp. cardamom.
Spread honey and cover in almonds.
Chop green chilies, grate carrots, and finely chop the coriander
In a pan (tawa) dry roast oats until slightly brown
In a pan, add oil, mustard seeds, urad dal, and channa dal.
Allow mustard to splutter and dals to turn golden.
Add seasoning to powdered oats mixture. Add the curd to make a batter (you can add as much curd to the mixture to achieve consistency, but don\'t add water).
Grease the idli steamer plates with oil.
Pour batter into each area of the steamer.
Dice 2 large onions. Mince 4 garlic cloves. Chop tomatoes (if bought whole)
Cook 1 cup lentil in about 4 cups of salted water.
Bring to boil. Reduce heat and cover. Simmer for 15-30 minutes. Until lentils are quite tender.
Add 1 cup of basmati rice to lentils.
Continue simmering until rice is cooked. Add water if necessary.
Add tomatoes, chili flakes, salt and pepper to taste.
Cook 1 cup macaroni in separate pot.
Fry onions and garlic in oil till golden.
Let bubble for 10-20 minutes or until thickened sauce like.
(Optional) Blitz sauce in food processor until smooth.
Mix lentils, rice and macaroni in one pot.
Soak the basmati rice in water for 10 minutes. Turn the stove on for the Little Chef.
