Heat 1 tbsp of ghee in a pan and put the rice into the pan. Let the Big Chef mix on the stove, and cook it until a nice aroma is produced.
Add bay leaf, cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, and 1/4 tsp cumin seeds to the pan, and let the Big Chef turn on the stove for you.
Add the green chilies, onions, and 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste and fry everything for 5 minutes until everything becomes tender.
Help the Big Chef with adding the ingredients into the rice cooker.
Put this mixture in a rice cooker along with salt, green peas, fried rice, 1 1/2 tsp coconut milk, and 2 cups water. Cook the rice according to the manufacturer’s directions.
Place some of the lentil mixture on each plate.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Oil a baking sheet with cooking spray and set aside.
Melt 3 tbsp butter over stove or in the microwave.
In a large bowl stir together 2/3 cups of milk, 3/4 cup cheese, 1 egg, and melted butter.
Sprinkle in 1 3/4 cup tapioca flour and 1 cup flour and stir until it forms into dough.
Peel the potatoes (zemiaky) and shred them using a fine food grater. Fill a large pot with salted water and bring to a boil.
Drain as much water as you can from the potatoes. Add salt (soľ) and two cups of flour (múka). Mix well.
Place the dough on a wooden cutting board. Then using a knife, cut off small pieces of the dough and “toss” the dumplings (halušky) into boiling salted water. The smaller, the better.
Boil for few more minutes and scoop out with a large slotted spoon.
Knead dough for two minutes on a lightly floured surface.
Top with sheep cheese (bryndza) and bacon.
Roll the dough into golf ball-sized pieces, and place onto the prepared baking sheet.
Bake in preheated oven until golden brown for about 10 to 15 minutes.
Cut 1 cup potatoes, 1/2 cup carrots, and 1/2 cup french beans into small pieces.
Heat 2 tbsp oil in a deep non-stick pan, add 1/2 cup onions and sauté on a medium flame for 1 minute.
Add all the potatoes, french beans, carrots and mix well.
Cover and cook on a slow flame for 10 to 12 minutes or till the vegetables are cooked, while stirring occasionally. Sprinkle a little water (approx. 2 tbsp) to avoid the vegetables from burning.
Add  salt, 1/2 tsp chili powder, turmeric powder and 1/2 cup plain flour, mix well and sauté on a medium flame for 1 to 2 minutes. take off heat and let cool.
Mash the mixture using a potato masher.
Divide the mixture and shape them into flat ovals.
Dip each cutlet in the prepared plain flour mixture and roll in the bread crumbs till they are evenly coated from all the sides.
Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan and fry each cutlet till it turns golden brown in color from both the sides. Drain on absorbent paper.
Cut lamb into 1” pieces. Finely chop onions. Mince garlic. Chop green chili pepper. Dice tomato, and chop cilantro leaves.
Heat 1/4 cup oil in an large pan.
Add 2 bay leaves, 1 cardamom, 1 cinnamon stick, 10 peppercorns, and 4 cloves.
When leaves begin to sizzle and fragrance starts to release. After onions added, sauté until light golden, about 12-15 minutes. Stir frequently.
Green bean soup with sour cream
Dice the potatoes and cut the green beans to 1⁄2 inch length.
Green bean soup with sour cream
After potatoes have been diced cook in salted water.
Continue cooking, stirring mix for about 20 more minutes. Add little water if necessary to keep food from sticking.
Green bean soup with sour cream
When potatoes are half done, add beans, vinegar, pepper, and garlic. (Can spear the garlic with a toothpick to find easier)
Add 1/2 tsp turmeric, 2 tsp coriander powder, 1 tsp cayenne, and 1 1/2 tsp garam masala. Stir for 5 minutes. Add 2 Tbsp. water.
Green bean soup with sour cream
Simmer until the potatoes are done.
Green bean soup with sour cream
Thicken with paste of flour and water.
Green bean soup with sour cream
Simmer for 15 minutes or until meat is getting tender.
Green bean soup with sour cream
Slowly stir in the sour cream (Do not cook just stir it in).
Wash 3 tomatoes and 1 stalk of green onion. Measure out salt, sugar and sauce. (personal preference)
Cut chicken into thin strips, mince the 3 garlic cloves and chop the 1 cup parsley

Add 1.5lb of chicken breast, 1 cup parsley, the minced garlic, 1/3 cup olive oil, 1/4 cup red wine vinegar, 2 tbsp lemon juice, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp pepper, 1/2 tsp oregano, and 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper in the ziplock bag.
Mix everything together in the bag.
Melt 3 Tbsp. butter. Finely grind almonds and pistachio nuts (if bought whole)
Bring 2 cups fruit juice and 2 Tbsp. rose water to a boil.
Place the bag into the fridge and let sit for at least four hours.
Add 1 cup couscous. Stir well. Cover.
Remove from heat. Let stand for 15 minutes.
Remove the chicken from the marinade.
Rub melted butter into grains well.
Combine couscous with almonds and pistachio nuts.
Cut the stems off of the tomatoes. Peel skin off (optional). Cut tomatoes into wedges no thicker than 2.5 cm.

Crack 3 eggs in a mixing bowl.
Add salt.
Beat till frothy with a pair of chopsticks or a fork.
Help the little chef cut the 3 tomatoes, 1 onion, and 1 carrot.
Pour water in a kettle to boil (depending on little chef).
Peel and dice tomatoes, dice onion, and slice the carrot.
Pour water and lentils in the large pot, and mix in the vegetable bouillon.
Help grind the spices in a mortar and pestle.
Bring the large pot to a boil, reduce heat to low, and simmer 20 minutes.
Place all of the dry ingredients into your favorite mug.
Stir the tomatoes, onion, carrot, apple, and peas into the large pot.
Once the water has come to a boil, pour a small amount (approximately 3-4 TBSP) into the mug and stir the dry mixture with the water until a thick paste is formed.
Add the rest of the water while stirring constantly, to ensure a lump-free consistency.
Stir in 1 garlic, 1 tbsp olive oil, 1/4 cups barbecue sauce, and 1/4 tsp paprika into the pot.
Continue to let simmer for 20 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper to serve.
Fry some of the green onions with oil, till you can smell the fragrance.
Dissolve yeast in a warm milk mixture; allow rising until it is double its size.
Combine the dry ingredients with butter until it is like a pie crust.
Add eggs, sour cream, and yeast mixture to the dry mixture and knead until smooth. Will take about 10 minutes and add flour if it gets sticky.
Once the dough has been divided, brush them with melted butter and spread a walnut mixture to cover.
Roll the dough up, pinch the ends and place in a greased 9 x 13 inch cake pan, put aside so it can double in size.
Bake at 325 degrees F for 35 to 40 minutes.
In a large skillet, heat 3 tablespoons of olive oil over medium-high heat.
Add onions and sauté until translucent. Add the garlic, sauté for another 2-3 minutes. Add 1/2 tsp turmeric powder, stir well.
Add the meat to the skillet, break into very small pieces and brown.
Then add 14 oz tomato sauce, 6 oz tomato paste, a cup of water, salt and pepper to taste.
Cover and simmer over low heat for about 45 minutes. Add chopped parsley near the end of cooking time.
Bring water to a boil and cook macaroni according to package directions.

Fry for a minute or two, or until tomatoes start to soften.
Add in a splash of water.
Cook tomatoes till you can see the juice running out.
Add sugar if the taste is too sharp.
Add a little more water if it is running out of sauce.
Add salt, A1, or fish sauce for taste (optional).
Remove  tomatoes. Do not clean pan or wok.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a heavy bottom nonstick pot
Add some of the pasta, add a large scoop of the sauce, and add another layer of pasta
Help the little chef build the pasta and sauce into the shape of a pyramid. Cover and cook for about 40 minutes over low heat.

Heat the wok/pan till it is very hot.
Add more cooking oil if needed.
Swirl the oil all around the wok/pan and heat till smoking hot.
Pour in the egg, and stir with a pair of chopsticks or a fork, until eggs are scrambled.
Add in cooked tomatoes, rest of the chopped green onions and mix everything together.
Assist in putting eggs and tomatoes together.
Pour 3 cups milk into the pot and bring to a boil.
Add 1 cup rice and 1 tsp butter to the pot.
Continuously stir the mixture to prevent the rice from sticking to the bottom of the pot.
Lower the heat to low and let simmer for 20 minutes or so, until the rice has absorbed almost all of the liquid and is cooked through.
Stir in the egg yolk, sugar, 1/2 tsp vanilla, and 1/2 tsp heavy cream and stir well to combine.
Season chicken legs with salt and pepper.
Stir in the 1/2 cup raisins and 1/2 tsp cinnamon.
Sauté onions and garlic in some oil until just golden.
Remove from heat and serve warm.
Wait for chef koochooloo to season chicken, and add to the pot and sauté for a few minutes on each side.
Add 1/2 cup split peas along with 1 1/2 cups of water.
Add a bit of salt and pepper, cover and cook for 20 minutes.
Add 1 cup prunes and continue to cook covered for another 40 minutes.
Check for seasoning and add more salt if needed. Add 2 tbsp of brewed saffron and mix well. Cook for 5 minutes longer.
Wash, peel, and grate the cucumber.
Take 2 tbsp mint leaves off the stem.

Stir together all the ingredients to marinate the beef: white vinegar, vegetable oil, sweet onion, cilantro, fresh garlic,thyme, oregano, ground cumin, 1 1/2 teaspoons of salt, and 1 1/2 teaspoons of pepper.
Rinse the mint and pat dry.
Marinate the beef with the marinade the little chef just created, cover and chill for 4 hours.
Finely chop up the mint leaves after they are washed.
Combine 3 cups yogurt, grated cucumber, chopped walnuts, 1/2 cup raisins, chopped mint, 1 tsp salt and 1/4 tsp pepper and mix thoroughly with a big spoon.

Meanwhile, stir together all chimichurri ingredients: olive oil, red-wine vinegar, chopped onion, red bell pepper, garlic, chopped flat-leaf parsley, oregano leaves, hot red-pepper flakes, 3/4 teaspoon salt and 1/2 teaspoon pepper and let stand at least 2 hours.
Prepare a grill for direct-heat cooking over medium-hot charcoal (medium-high heat for gas).
Remove beef from marinade and rub off excess (discard marinade).
Oil grill rack, then grill (covered if using a gas grill), turning occasionally, 4 to 5 minutes for medium-rare.

Place the salted eggplants in a large container filled with water; put a heavy bowl or a heavy lid on top of the eggplants to hold them down for ten minutes, this will get rid of the bitterness. Remove eggplants from container and pat dry completely before frying.
Clean the yellow split peas thoroughly, 3 or 4 washes.
Dice the onion and mince the garlic.
Fry the eggplants in 1/2 cup of hot oil until brown on both sides. Remove from oil and place on a thick paper towel to take out the excess oil.

In a large saucepan, heat the oil, add chopped onions, saute until translucent then add the garlic, stir well. Put in turmeric, meat, salt and pepper and cinnamon. Mix thoroughly. Cook until meat is brown on all sides.
Add dry split peas, chopped tomatoes, tomato sauce and three cups of water to cover all the ingredients. Bring to a boil, lower the heat, cover and cook for an hour on medium heat.
Add the fried eggplant to the mixture, adjust the seasoning and add more water if needed.
Add the lime juice or two tablespoons of sour grapes (ghooreh).
Cook for another 30 minutes or until meat is tender.
Score the 2 cucumbers lengthwise on all sides with a fork. Cut the cucumber into thin slices.
In a large bowl toss cucumbers with 1 tbsp salt and let stand 1 hour.
In a small saucepan add 1/3 cups vinegar, 1/4 cups water, 2 tsp sugar, 1 garlic, and 1 tsp dill seed.
Bring these ingredients to a boil.
Add sugar and stir until sugar is dissolved, then let dressing cool.
In a colander drain cucumbers and rinse under cold water. Drain cucumbers well, squeezing out excess liquid.
In a bowl combine cucumbers with dressing.
Cover the bowl and chill for at least 1 hour or up to 6 hours.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil over high heat. Add the potatoes, then reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer until tender, about 20 minutes.
Drain and allow to steam dry for a minute or two.
Peel and slice the cooked potatoes.
Chop the bacon and onion into small pieces.
Preheat an oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
Stir-fry bacon in a skillet over medium high heat for about 5 minutes. Remove bacon; pour off bacon fat.
In the same skillet, melt the butter, add onions, and cook and stir until the onions are translucent, about 5 minutes.
Return the bacon to the pan, add the wine, and simmer until most of the wine has evaporated. Remove from heat.

After big chef has completed step 6, place 1/2 of the potatoes into the prepared dish; then spread 1/2 of the bacon mixture over the potatoes. Layer in the remaining potatoes, then spread the creme fraiche over them.
Add the remaining half of the bacon mixture. Cut the rind from the Reblochon, cut it into thin slices, and layer the slices evenly over the top of the casserole.
Bake in the preheated oven until cheese is melted and a bit brown, about 15 minutes.
Over stove or in the microwave melt the 5 tbsp. of butter.
In a large bowl, combine 5 tbsp of melted butter, 1 cup of cottage cheese, a pinch of salt, 2 beaten eggs and enough flour (2 cups should suffice) to make a soft dough.
Shape dough into a roll; cover and let stand 30 minutes.
Wash and dry the 1.5lb of apricots. Cut in halves; remove and discard pit.
Place 1 sugar cube between each pair of apricot halves; set aside.
Bring water to a gentle boil; add 1 teaspoon salt.

On a lightly floured board, press or roll out dough to a
1/2-inch thickness.
Cut dough into 2-inch squares. Place a stuffed apricot (2 halves with a sugar cube in the middle) in the center of each square of dough. Press dough around fruit, covering completely.

Add to gently boiling water; cook 8 to 10 minutes. Drain
on paper towels; arrange on a platter.
Melt 1/3 cup butter or margarine in a medium skillet.
Add breadcrumbs and 3 Tablespoons granulated sugar; sauté until golden brown.
Austrian Pasta with Cheese and Caramelized Onion
Austrian Pasta with Cheese and Caramelized Onion

In a large bowl, combine the 2 eggs, 1/2 cups milk, 1/2 tsp salt, and 1/2 tsp pepper. Add flour 1/2 cup at a time( 3 times total). Stir with a wooden spoon until smooth. Let rest 10-20 minutes. The dough should be like pancake batter. Thin with more milk if necessary.
Austrian Pasta with Cheese and Caramelized Onion
Meanwhile, sauté onions in butter until golden brown. Set aside.
Austrian Pasta with Cheese and Caramelized Onion
Bring a pot of water to a boil.
Austrian Pasta with Cheese and Caramelized Onion
Drop dough through the holes in a sieve into simmering water. Cook until the dough pieces begin to float.
Austrian Pasta with Cheese and Caramelized Onion
Remove the nocken (dough) from the water with a strainer. Place in a buttered casserole or oven-safe pan.
Austrian Pasta with Cheese and Caramelized Onion
Sprinkle with 1 cup of grated cheese and caramelized onion.
Austrian Pasta with Cheese and Caramelized Onion
Place dish in oven and bake for 15-20 minutes.

In a small bowl, combine the yeast, sugar and water and stir gently to dissolve. Let the mixture stand until the yeast comes 
alive and starts to foam, 5 to 10 minutes.

Combine the salt and flour to the bowl and pulse a few
times to mix. Add the yeast mixture, at the lowest speed, until the flour 
incorporates. When the dough starts to come together, increase the speed 
to medium and mix until the dough gathers into a ball. This should take 
about 2 minutes. Add the olive oil and pulse a few more times. Stop the 
machine periodically to scrape the dough off the hook. Get a feel for the 
dough as you're making it by squeezing a small amount together between 
your thumb and fingers. If it's crumbly, add more water, if it's sticky, add 
more flour, 1 tablespoon at a time. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured 
surface and fold it over itself a few times, kneading until it's smooth and 
elastic.

Add the yeast mixture to a large bowl and stir in
the salt and the 2 tablespoons of olive oil. Then begin stirring in the flour. 
When the mixture becomes too stiff to stir with a spoon, knead in the rest 
of the flour by hand, adding just enough so that the dough is soft but not 
too sticky. As you work, squeeze a small amount of dough together 
between your thumb and fingers. If it's crumbly, add more water; if it's 
sticky, add more flour, 1 tablespoon at a time. Knead until smooth and 
elastic, about 10 minutes.

Form the dough into a round and put it into a lightly
oiled bowl, turning it over to coat the dough entirely with the oil. Cover with 
plastic wrap or a damp towel and let it rise in a warm spot (i.e., over a gas 
pilot light) until it doubles in size, about 1 hour.
Preheat the oven to 450 degrees F. and then put a jelly roll pan or a half sheet pan in the oven.

Begin by making the tomato sauce. In a large saute pan
over medium heat, add 2 tablespoons olive oil, the minced garlic, thyme 
and oregano. Cook until just fragrant then add the crushed tomatoes and 
season with salt and pepper, to taste. Lower the heat and simmer for 7 to 
8 minutes to reduce and concentrate the flavor. Shut off the heat and set 
aside.

Take the preheated jelly roll pan out of the oven and

drizzle some olive oil over the entire surface. Cut the dough into 2 pieces 
and reserve 1 piece for another use. Stretch the pizza dough out so it is 
just bigger than the pan, then lay it inside the pan, so the dough comes up 
the sides to form a crust on the rim. Smear with tomato sauce then tear up 
the mozzarella and scatter it evenly over the top of the pie. Tear the basil 
leaves, spread them over the top and drizzle with a little more olive oil. 
Give it a final season with salt and pepper, to taste, then bake in the hot 
oven until golden and bubbly, about 15 to 18 minutes
In a small bowl combine 1 cup of flour, 1 tbsp salt and 1 tbsp pepper.
Place the content of 2 cans of Nestle Table Cream in a jar and mix it well with sugar until well blended.
Add just enough olive oil to coat a large cooking pan and turn the heat high enough to make the oil simmer, but not smoke.
Pat the meat dry and coat it in the flour mixture.
Add one piece of meat to the hot oil to make sure that it sizzles.
Add the remaining meat, without crowding the pan and sear for about 3-4 minutes per side. You want a golden crust that will give the gravy great flavor.

In a bowl beat the egg whites with a fork carefully not create foam or bubbles or Panna Cotta will come out with holes. The whites should become liquid quite like water and lose elasticity. (You can find pasteurized egg whites in any grocery store. They usually are perfectly liquid.)
Use the colander to separate egg whites from the foam
Cook the meat in batches, if necessary and set aside in a bowl to collect the juice. Then, thinly slice the onions and the garlic.
Pour egg whites into the cream mixture and mix well until homogeneous.
Divide the mixture among buttered non-stick moulds.
Pour boiling water into a baking pan until the water level reach 3/4 of the moulds.

Add a little more olive oil to the pan after all the meat has been taken out and turn the heat to medium. Add in onions and cook the 2 onions until tender, 3-4 minutes. Add the 2 sliced 
garlic and cook till fragrant,30 seconds or so.
Place the moulds in the pan (bain-marie method).
Add the 2 tbsp tomato paste and both paprika, and cook for 1-2 minutes.
Bake at 300°F  for 90 minutes or until the surface is golden brown.
Turn off the oven and let Panna Cotta cool completely inside it before covering the moulds with plastic wrap.
Add 1 tbsp caraway seeds, lemon zest and chicken/beef stock and stir well.

Bring to a simmer for about 15 minutes and taste for seasoning. Adjust as necessary. If the sauce is too thick, thin with a little more chicken/beef stock or water until it is the consistency of gravy.
Place spinach and water in a large frying pan over medium heat.
Cook until all of the moisture is removed.
Mix all other ingredients and add the spinach.
Blend quickly and thoroughly incorporate the egg mixture.
Reduce the heat and let it simmer about 10 minutes.
Peel apples and cut them in cubes and slices. Put them in the lemon juice.
Empty the yogurt in a bowl.
Rinse and dry the yogurt cup. Measure 2 yogurt cups of sugar, put them in the bowl and mix
Add 2 eggs in the bowl and mix
Add 1⁄2 yogurt cup of oil in the bowl and mix
Rinse and dry the yogurt cup, add 3 yogurt cups of floor, the east and the pinch of salt and mix them together.
Proof the yeast (Let it sit for 10 minutes) in warmed milk and a 1/4 tsp sugar.
Help little chef dice beef, onion, chop garlic, and beat egg.
Mix into the yeast the flour, sugar, eggs, salt and other spices.
Add the cube of apples in the dough (without the lemon juice!!)
Brush with beaten egg white and then roll in the nuts.

Allow to cool a bit, then sprinkle on the vanilla sugar, castor sugar and dust with
powdered sugar.
Let sit at  room temperature for 30 minutes  with a cloth over it.

Roll out each piece into a long log about 1 inch round, and then wind the dough
around a 2 inch diameter wooden bob.
Put the dough in the baking pan (or cupcake pan)
Roast over an open fire, continuously rotating the bob until toasted golden brown.
Dice beef chucks into 1” cubes, chop garlic, dice onion, and beat egg.
Decorate with the apple slices on the top and add small peaces of butter on them.
Once the cake is done, put it in the oven for 30-35 minutes. If you choose to do cupcake, bake them for 10-15 minutes

In a medium saucepan, whisk together egg yolks and
sugar until well blended. Whisk in milk and cook over medium heat, stirring 
constantly, until mixture boils. Boil gently for 1 minute, remove from heat 
and allow to cool slightly. Cover tightly and chill in refrigerator 1 hour.

In a medium bowl, beat cream with vanilla until stiff
peaks form. Whisk mascarpone into yolk mixture until smooth.
Take it out, cut and server.
Split ladyfingers in half lengthwise and drizzle with coffee.
Sear beef in oil in a hot pan and sauté for 4 minutes.

Arrange half of soaked ladyfingers in bottom of a dish. Spread half of mascarpone mixture over ladyfingers, then half of whipped
cream over that. Repeat layers and sprinkle with cocoa. Cover and refrigerate 4 to 6 hours, until set.
Add garlic, onion, and egg to the meat and continue to cook.

Mince 2 garlic cloves, ginger, and 4 green onions (set aside green part of green onion for garnish). Remove black seeds and grind husks of peppercorn. Grind 6 ounces pork. Drain and cu 14 ouncest tofu into ¾” cubes.
Add spices, Worcestershire, and soy sauce.
Cook until the liquid is almost dissolved.
Add the beef stock and cook until meat is coated in a thick gravy.
Transfer into a container and let cool.
Add 1/2 cup of chicken stock, 2 tsp soy sauce and 1 tsp sugar to a bowl. Mix together.
Roll 2 sheets of pastry to ½” thickness.Then,  Line 8” tart molds with rolled pastry. Lastly, line the pastry with tin foil.
Roll out remaining pasty sheets and cut lids for the pies. Fill the baked sheets with the meat mixture and cover with the pastry lids.
Attach lids with egg wash and brush the tops with remaining egg wash and sprinkle with black pepper.
Bake for 8 minutes or until golden brown.
Heat wok or large frying pan until hot.
Add  1 tbsp sesame oil, garlic, 2 tsp ginger and white parts green onions.

Stir-fry with a spatula until fragrant.
Add 1 tbsp black beans and 1/2 tsp Sichuan pepper.
Continue to stir-fry.

Add the ground pork and use a spatula to break it up into small grains (you do not want clumps of meat).
When pork is cooked, add 2 tsp chili bean paste and stir to distribute.
Add tofu.
Toss the mix (if you stir, the tofu will lose its shape).
Chop the 5 cloves of garlic and dash of ginger.
Give the stock mixture a good stir to incorporate anything that may have settled.
In a marinating dish, add 3 tbsp. of olive oil, chopped garlic and ginger, and handful of thyme or rosemary.

Pour over pork and tofu.
Toss to coat.
Boil until sauce thickens.
After the Big Chef added the ingredients, mix lamb racks with the marinade with your hands.
Garnish with green part of green onions.
After the Chef Koochooloo mixes the marinade and lamb racks together, set it aside for at least 2 hours at a room temperature.
After 2 hours, heat 2 tablespoon of olive oil on a cast iron skillet at high heat.
Cut and core the 1 apple (leave the skin on).
Sear lamb for about 2-4 minutes on each side, until browned all over.
Preheat the oven to 220 degrees Celsius.
Transfer the lamb to a roasting pan. Roast for about 8-10 minutes for medium and 10-12 minutes for well done.
Dissolve yeast in 1 tablespoon sugar and 1/2 cup warm water.
Let the lamb rest for 5 minutes before serving.
In a medium saucepan, bring to boil 2 cups water, 3 tablespoons sugar, salt and oil. Cool to lukewarm.
Place flour in large bowl. Add lukewarm water-sugar mixture and yeast mixture. Combine thoroughly and knead until smooth at least 10 minutes by hand.
Cover and let rise until doubled.
Punch down dough and turn out onto a lightly floured surface.
Roll dough to 1/2- to 1-inch thick and cut into pieces that will result in 1-inch balls when rolled between the palms of the hand.
Place on a parchment-lined or well-floured cookie sheet with dough ball sides touching.
Let rise again, covered with plastic wrap until nearly doubled.
Help the little chef grate the apples.
Grate apples and lightly beat the 2 eggs.
Mix the 2 cups of flour, ,cut apple, 2 tbsp sugar, 2 eggs, and 1 1/3 cup milk into a bowl.
Heat a frying pan or griddle and spray with oil. Then, help little chef pour batter in pan.
Pour small amounts of batter into little circles on the pan.
Flip when bubbles appear on top. Flip again until both sides are golden.
Bake 15-20 minutes or until lightly browned. Cool completely.
Grind poppy seeds in a mortar and pestle with a little water or milk and toss with cooled bobalki.
Drain the can of apricot halves.
Steam carrots which you sliced, and meanwhile help the little chef cut the 4 boneless skinless chicken breasts.
Cut chicken into large chunks and then roll it in flour.
Heat oil in a large fry pan and lightly brown chicken pieces.
Add the 1 packet of soup mix, 1 can of apricot nectar and 1/2 cup of chicken stock. Stir well.
Cover and simmer gently for 10 minutes or until chicken has cooked through.
Stir in apricot halves and carrots.
Toss the fruit with a spoonful of flour and set aside.

In a small bowl, whisk together the dry ingredients: flour, powdered sugar,
baking powder, lemon zest, and salt.

Next, in a large bowl, whisk together wet ingredients (milk, egg yolks, and
vegetable oil) until a smooth batter forms.
Whip the egg whites in a clean, dry bowl until glossy, stiff peaks form.
Add the dry ingredients to the wet and stir until a smooth batter forms.
Using a spatula, fold the egg whites into the batter. Do it in thirds, until the mixture is airy and light.
Pour the batter into your baking dish.

Cover batter with blueberries. Be gentle, so as to not overly deflate the
cake. Some fruit will sink immediately and that’s okay.
Bake for about 30 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted comes out cleanly.
Cut the bananas into thick slices.
Place the slices of bananas at the bottom of the souffle dish for the base.
Spread the buttered bread with apricot jam and set the bread, buttered side down, on top of the bananas.
Add another layer of bananas after Big Chef added the buttered bread.

Add another layer of bread after the little chef added another layer of bananas. (Repeat this process alternately with the little chef until the souffle dish is ¾ full with the last layer being the bread).
Whisk together the egg, milk, and vanilla sugar until the sugar is dissolved.
Slowly pour the milk mixture on top of the contents of your soufflé dish, ensuring that all the bread is covered. Set aside to soak for 25 minutes.
Toast 1 1/2 tbsp sesame seeds and 1 1/2 tbsp coconut on medium heat in a frying pan, stirring continuously until they are a golden brown.
Set the dish in a deep baking tray and pour in boiling water so that it comes 3/4 of the way up the sides of the soufflé dish.
Transfer to an oven pre-heated to 180°C and bake for 30 minutes, or until the custard is set and the top of the dish is golden brown in colour.

Mix together 3 tbsp peanut butter, 3 tbsp sugar, the sesame seeds and coconut to make the filling.
Store in the fridge until needed.

Crack an egg into a small bowl, then gently slip the egg into the tomato sauce. Repeat with the remaining eggs. 
Cook the eggs until the whites are firm and the yolks have thickened but are not hard, 2 1/2 to 3 minutes.

Heat the vegetable oil in a deep skillet over medium heat. Stir in the garlic, onion, and bell pepper; cook and
stir until the onion has softened and turned translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add the canned tomatoes, paprika and jalapeños; stir, using the back of a spoon to break up the tomatoes. Simmer for about 25 minutes.

If the tomato sauce gets dry, add a few tablespoons of water. Remove the eggs with a slotted spoon, place onto a 
warm plate, and serve with the tomato sauce and pita bread.
Cook bucatini in salted water according to package instructions, drain, keep in a bowl.

Add onion to pot and sauté for about 6 minutes, scraping the bottom of pot to release all
the good flavor. Add tomato paste and spices to onion, stir and cook for another minute. 
Remove pot from heat, pour onion and fat on cooked bucatini, add 1 teaspoon kosher salt 
and mix well.

Generously salt and pepper chicken. Put oil in a large pot over medium-high heat and
brown chicken on both sides to a nice golden-brown color. You may need to do it in two 
batches. Transfer chicken to a bowl.

Line bottom of pot with potato slices, sprinkle with salt. Top with about ¾ of the
bucatini, pressing them down. Arrange chicken on the noodles, arranging eggs between 
them, and top with the rest of the bucatini. Add ½ cup boiling water.

Cover tightly with aluminum foil (make sure the aluminum foil does not touch the
noodles. If it does, first line the noodles with parchment paper and only then with the 
foil). Then cover with lid. Bake overnight or for 6-8 hours. Let rest for 10 minutes before 
serving.
Take a chicken and cut off/pull off all the skin and fat. Don’t throw it out, you will need it!
Cut the skin and fat into inch-by-inch (or smaller) pieces.
Fry them for about 10 minutes until the skin starts to get crispy.
Separate egg whites from egg yolks
Rub the chicken pieces with salt and pepper.
Melt butter in a heavy skillet or stew pot, and add the chicken and onions. Cover and simmer over lowest heat.
Assist little chef with grating the 2 apples.
Once it is cooked a little. Add stock periodically until you have used it all. (If you do not have stock, use plain water or bouillon)
Grate apples and beat 1 egg white.
Grease baking tray and line it with parchment paper.
After 15 minutes, remove half a cup of cooking liquid from the stew pot and thin the peanut butter or paste.
Add this thin paste to the pot and bring to a boil.
Mix 3 cups flour, 1/2 tsp salt, 1 tsp sugar, 1/4 cups brown sugar, and 1 1/5 tsp cinnamon together in a bowl.
Reduce heat and then whisk some of the hot stew liquid into the egg yolks.
Add this egg yolk mixture to the pot and stir to incorporate the egg mixture into the stew.
Rub in 5 tbsp butter into the ingredients until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs.
Cook gently until the chicken is done
Add grated apple and mix well with a wooden spoon.
Be Careful not to heat the stew above a simmer from this point.
Garnish with parsley leaves and serve with rice or a corn porridge.
Add 1/2 cup milk and 1/2 cup water. Stir until you have a sticky dough.
Bring dough onto a lightly floured surface.
Gently knead the dough until smooth.
Dice half a small onion and add.
Shape dough into 6-8 inch rounds and place on a baking tray.
Add one tablespoon of paprika and enough hot water to cover.
Let simmer for about an hour, adding more water as needed.
Chop up two small roma tomatoes and 1/4 pepper and add to the pot.
Let simmer for another 20 minutes or so until everything is nice and tender.
Rub flour on a sharp knife and score damper into 8 wedges.
Combine 2 cups of flour and 1 cup of until you get a mixture resembling yogurt.

Add the cream to the pot, one wooden spoon at a time. Cook
until everything dissolves. The resulting mixture should not be too watery. 
Just like any other sauce.
Tap bread and if it sounds hollow its ready. Let stand for 5 minutes. Transfer to a wire rack to cool the rest of the way.
Rinse eggplant under cold water and blot dry with paper towels.
In several large colanders set over bowls, toss eggplant cubes with salt. Let stand 1 hour to drain.

In large heavy skillet over moderately high heat, heat 3 tablespoons olive oil until hot but
not smoking. Working in 3 batches and using 3 tablespoons oil for each batch, sauté 
eggplant and garlic until tender, about 5 minutes. Drain on paper towels.

Meanwhile, using tongs or long-handled fork, hold peppers over open flame, turning until
blackened on all sides, 2 to 3 minutes.  (Alternatively, on rack of broiler pan under preheated 
broiler about 2 inches from heat, broil peppers, turning every 5 minutes, until skins are 
blistered and charred, 15 to 25 minutes.)
Transfer to large bowl, cover tightly with plastic wrap, and let stand 15 minutes. Peel, seed, and dice.

Transfer eggplant and garlic to large bowl. Add peppers, dill, vinegar, and sugar and toss to
combine. Chill overnight. Serve cold or at room temperature, accompanied by matzoh.
Dice onion, mince garlic, and dice tomatoes
Sauté onions in vegetable oil until they are transparent. Add in minced garlic and sauté.
Add in curry powder and ground ginger, stirring for just a moment before adding in diced tomatoes. Continue to cook until tomatoes become mushy.
Add in peanut butter and sesame seed paste
Stir frequently as you continue to cook over medium heat and bring the mixture to a thick, bubbly boil.
Add additional hot water to make the sauce your desired consistency and salt to taste
Garnish with chopped fresh cilantro, is desired.
Serve over one of the following starchy foods: rice, potatoes (peeled and boiled); sweet potatoes (peeled and boiled)
Start by boiling unpeeled potatoes in salted water. Additionally, hard-boil the 2 eggs.
Chop up about 1/2 of an onion.
Slice the carrots into thin quarter circle wedges and also chop up the pickles.
Combine vegetables in a pot on the stove.

Take out the potatoes when they are almost cooked through
(soft outside with a slightly hard core in the middle). Peel them, dice them, 
and add to the pot.

Now stir in mayo. Start off with 3 spoonfuls, and add more
your desired taste.
Finally, cut up the eggs and mix into

Add salt, black pepper, and paprika to taste. Let sit in
for few hours before serving.

Wash the chicken with water and place in pot. Cover with water and bring to a boil over high heat,
skimming off bubbling foam as it forms.

Add celery, carrots, onion, herbs, salt and pepper and simmer, half-covered at lower heat, for at least 
45 minutes, until the chicken seems done.

The chicken will come away easily from the bone. Pour soup through strainer to get a clear broth. Let
cool. When broth has completely cooled, skim off the fat and save for the matzoh balls.

In a mixing bowl, mix together 4 eggs and 4 tablespoons chicken fat. Stir in the matzoh meal and salt.
Add 1/4 hot water. Cover and refrigerate for at least 1 hour.

Form the matzoh dough into balls the size of walnuts. Bring the salted water to a boil. Add the matzoh balls, cover, and cook for 20 minutes (do not even peek!). Bring the chicken broth to a simmer. Remove matzoh balls from hot water with a slotted spoon and add to the simmering chicken broth just a few minutes before serving.
Cut the cabbages into 1 inch wedges
Cut up a half cup of red onion.
In a wok or a pan, add oil and seasonings
Sauté onions and cabbage until it loses its crispness
Add the beef stock in and simmer for 5 min

Peel the cloves of garlic and crush them, or slice them
with a knife.

In a pot on the stove melt two tablespoons of butter, and
the garlic. Fry for few seconds.

Next add eight cups of water, 2 teaspoons of
teaspoon of caraway, and salt to taste.
Peel the potatoes, cut them into small cubes, and add to the pot.
Boil for about 15 minutes until the potatoes get soft.

In the meantime, toast a slice of bread. Cut the toast
squares and put them in a bowl. Then scoop the finished soup over the bread.

Finally, grate some cheese into the soup (Swiss is
recommended) and also decorate with some garnish, such as parsley. 
Enjoy!

Cube the chicken half an inch cubes.
Mince 3 cloves garlic and the ginger.
Slice 3 green onions (use the white parts fro cooking and save the green parts for garnish).

Cook bacon in a large skillet over medium-high heat, turning

occasionally, until evenly browned, about 10 minutes.

Drain the bacon slices on paper towels. When bacon is cool, crumble

and set aside.

Place potatoes into a food processor and process until pureed, 2 to 3

minutes.

Transfer to a bowl and stir in flour, eggs, baking powder, and salt to

make a sticky dough. Set dough aside.
Fill a large pot about half full of lightly salted water and bring to a boil.

Ladle large spoonfuls of the sticky dough to a small cutting board and

use a knife to chop the dough into tablespoon-size pieces; as you cut off a piece, 

drop it into the boiling water.

Let the dumplings boil over medium heat until they float, 2 to 3 minutes.

Remove dumplings with a slotted spoon to a large serving bowl.

Sprinkle bacon crumbles and a handful of cheese over each batch of

dumplings.

Continue to make and boil dumplings, and transfer dumplings to the

bowl.
Continue sprinkling each batch of dumplings with bacon and cheese.
When all dumplings are made, gently stir the haluski.

Wash 2 potatoes.
Cut into shreds with the help of the big chef.

Prepare a bowl with clean water.
Soak the shredded potatoes in water for several minutes.
Drain shredded potatoes and set aside.
Add olive oil to a saucepan
Then add turmeric, ginger, sugar and raisins.
Put on a low heat to dissolve the sugar and infuse the spices.

Heat up oil in a pan. 
Add 4 dried red chili pepper,1 tsp of Sichuan pepper (optional) and the minced garlic. 
Stir fry for the aroma.
Stir fry until the potatoes become soft.

Add 1 tsp salt, 1/2 tbsp of light soy sauce and 2 tsp black vinegar.
Mix evenly.
Transfer out with the help of the big chef.
Soak the bread pieces with the coconut milk for 10 minutes. Place them in the blender (with the coconut milk) and blend until smooth. Set aside.
Grind the peanuts and the cashews in a food processor until finely ground. Set aside.
Wash the miki noodles in running water. Drain and set aside.
In a wok, heat oil then saute the 6 garlic cloves and onion.
Add 3 tbsp oyster sauce and broth then stir and bring to boil.

Bring 2 cups of fish stock or water to a boil in a saucepan. Season with salt and pepper, and add the chopped garlic and juice of one lime. Add the shrimp and boil until pink, about 5 minutes. Remove the shrimp and set aside. Reserve cooking liquid.
Add shrimp and vegetables ( 1 celery, 1 cabbage, 1 carrot,  snow peas ) then stir fry until the vegetables are half-cooked.
Add pork and squid balls then cooked until color turns to brown.
Add miki noodles then stir and cook for 3 minutes or until soft and tender.
In the same food processor, add the onion, chile pepper, and garlic, and process until finely chopped.
Adjust seasoning with salt and pepper according to taste.
Transfer to a serving plate then garnish with spring onion. Serve and enjoy.
Heat the palm oil (or vegetable oil) in a skillet, and sauté onion mixture until soft and golden. (This takes about 5 minutes)
Add some ground nuts to the skillet, and sauté until it turns golden.

Add the bread crumb and coconut 1/2 cups of the shrimp cooking liquid to the skillet. Cook, stirring, until sauce has thickens, this process takes about 5 minutes. At the end, depends on personal preference, you could choose to add more liquids.
Melt butter in small saucepan over medium-high heat.
Add cilantro and garlic; cook until garlic begins to brown, about 2 minutes.
Add piri-piri sauce and lemon juice. Reduce heat to medium-low; simmer 2 minutes. DO AHEAD: Glaze can be made up to 1 day ahead. Cover and chill. Rewarm before using.
Finely chop cilantro, ginger, shallot, and garlic in processor. Add piri-piri sauce, 1/4 cup oil, lemon juice, coarse salt, and pepper; process marinade to blend.
Place chicken, skin side up, on work surface. Using palm of hand, press on breastbone to flatten chicken. Tuck wing tips under.
Pour half of marinade into 11x7x2-inch glass baking dish. Open chicken like book; place skin side down in single layer in dish.
Pour remaining marinade over. Cover; chill at least 4 hours or overnight, turning chicken occasionally.

Remove top rack from barbecue. Prepare barbecue (medium heat). If using 2-burner gas grill, light 1 burner. If using 3-burner gas grill, do not light center burner. If using charcoal grill, light briquettes in chimney and pour onto 1 side of lower grill rack.
Place disposable aluminum pan on unlit part of grill. Place upper grill rack on barbecue; brush with oil.
Remove chicken from marinade. Arrange skin side up on grill rack above drip pan. Cover barbecue
Grill until skin is browned and instant-read thermometer inserted into thickest part of thigh registers 165°F, turning often, about 40 minutes.
Transfer to platter. Pour warm glaze over.

Gut and slice the bell pepper.
Thinly slice avocado.
Slice Cucumber and granny smith apple.
Peel and dice lemon and lime.
Finely chop lettuce.
Mix everything together.

Add 150 g snap peas and pine nuts.
Mix everything again.
Wash the fonio with cold running water and drain well.
Place the fonio in the top of a steamer lined with cheesecloth.
Set over simmering water, cover, and steam the fonio, about 15 minutes.
Remove from heat, and fluff with a fork.

Drizzle with salted water and steam again until the grains are tender. (Alternately, fonio can be prepared in a microwave by adding enough water to cover in a bowl and cooking until tender, 6-8 minutes.)
In a small mixing bowl, combine the lemon juice with the salt and pepper and whisk to dissolve. Slowly pour in the olive oil while whisking to emulsify.
Place the cooked fonio in a large bowl and add parsley, mint, cucumber and tomatoes.
Pour enough dressing over the fonio mixture to coat the grains well. Toss and serve.
Mix 2 tbsp Dijon mustard and 40 ml vinegar well to make the dressing.
Drizzle the dressing and crumble the blue cheese into very small pieces over the salad. Mix well for a final time.
Cut the fish into 2-inches pieces, and place them in the mixing bowl.
In a large bowl, combine 2 lb pork with soy sauce and lemon juice (or calamansi juice). Marinate for an hour in the refrigerator. Remove pork from marinade, reserving the liquid.
Heat oil in a large pot (or casserole) over medium heat. Fry 1 cup potatoes and 1 cup carrots until lightly brown. Remove and set aside.
In the same pot, stir-fry the marinated pork; cook until lightly brown. Remove and set aside.
Use a vegetable peeler to peel off the tomatoes’ skin and onions’ skin.
Sauté the 3 garlic cloves and onion until fragrant and translucent. Return pork and accumulated juices to pot; stir to combine.
Chop the onion and 2 tomatoes. Cut the rest of the tomatoes into slices.
Add 2 cups tomato sauce, 1 cup water, 1 tbsp brown sugar and bay leaf; stir. Bring to boil then allow to simmer for about 20 to 25 minutes or until pork is tender.
Add 1 cup potatoes and 1 cup carrots; stir and cook until tender. Season with salt and pepper. Add 1 cup diced red peppers then simmer for another 2 minutes. Transfer to a platter and serve hot.
Put the chopped onion, the chopped tomatoes, 2 cloves of garlic, 1 tablespoon of cilantro, 1 teaspoon of salt, and the lime juice in the blender, and blend until smooth in the blender.
Pour mixture directly over the fish. Cover the fish with plastic wrap and put it in the refrigerator for 1 hour.
Heat a large sauté pan over medium-high heat. Add the olive oil to the pan, and once hot, add the julienned onions to the pan and sauté, stirring often until translucent, about 3 to 4 minutes.

Add the minced garlic to the pan and sauté for an additional 30 seconds. Pour the fish and the marinade into the sauté pan and add a teaspoon of salt, and the coconut milk and stir to combine. Once the liquid comes to a boil, add the sliced tomatoes and cover the lid.
Reduce the heat to medium-low and continue to cook until the flesh starts to flake, about 10 minutes. Remove the cover from the pan and sprinkle the remaining 4 tablespoons of cilantro over the fish.
Peel the plantains, cut into cubes, sprinkle with lemon juice, and set aside.
Heat oil in a large pan. Fry the Onion, tomatoes, green pepper, hot pepper, and garlic together.
Add spices to taste. Add meat or broth.
Continue frying and stirring until the meat is nearly done or until the broth is starting to boil.
Reduce heat. Add plantains. Cover and simmer over low heat until plantains are tender and meat is done. Serve matoke (matooke, if you prefer) hot.
In a pot over medium-low heat, stir the condensed milk, butter, and cocoa vigorously.

In a skillet, heat 2 tbsp oil and 2 tbsp butter on med-low temp.
Add the vegetables.

Cook the mixture until it thickens enough to show the pan bottom during stirring (it will be firm enough to stay together and not spread). Pour into a greased dish and let cool to room temperature (or chill a few minutes in the fridge) Grease your hands with butter and take small amounts of the candy and form into 1 1/2 inch balls.
Beef with mushroom and cauliflower stir fry
Trim fat from beef.  Slice meat with grain into 2 inch strips.  Cut strips across grain into 1/8 inch slices.
Assist the big Chef make the balls.
Beef with mushroom and cauliflower stir fry
In a bowl, combine sliced beef with vegetable oil, cornstarch, salt, sugar, soy sauce and pepper.
Beef with mushroom and cauliflower stir fry
Stir to blend.  Cover and refrigerate 30 minutes.  (You may also wish to adjust the seasoning to your liking.  By smelling the aroma of the marinated meat you’ll know if it is well seasoned or not).
Combine 1/2 cup of white flour and 1/2 cup of wheat flour with 4 tbsp. of butter.
Beef with mushroom and cauliflower stir fry
Cook an additional 5 minutes if the balls don\'t hold their shape.
Add 1/4 cup of water for a rollable dough.
Let the dough sit for 30 minutes
Heat 3 tbsp. of oil in a pan.
Put chocolate sprinkles over the balls to decorate.
Add 1 tsp. of cumin seeds and 1/2 tsp. of turmeric powder.
When the seeds begin to pop add 1 chopped onion, 2 chopped garlic cloves, and 1 piece of ginger.

Allow to cook for a few minutes.
Add the remainder of the ingredients.
Sprinkle .25 tsp. of salt and .25 tsp. of cayenne on the potatoes.
Add the 2 boiled potatoes, cut into pieces and 1/2 cup of cooked peas to the pan.
Stir until the potatoes are coated with oil and are yellow
Divide into 6 balls, roll each ball into a 5 inch diameter circle, cut into semi­circles.
Form a cone, fill with filling, pinch closed, and press the edges closed with a fork.
Cook until browned. Squash will be brown and slightly soft and the Brussels sprouts will be bright green, browned and al dente.
Fry samosa in oil until golden brown
Mix the milk, oil, and salt in the saucepan. Boil the whole mixture with medium heat. Remove the pan from the heat when bubbles start to form.
Add the tapioca flour to the saucepan and mix it until no more dry tapioca flour.

Move the dough to the bowl of a standing mixer fitted with a paddle attachment. Beat the dough for a few minutes at medium speed until it smooths out and has cooled enough that you can hold your finger on it for a few seconds.

Whisk the eggs together in a small bowl. With the mixer on medium, beat the eggs into the dough in two additions. Wait until the first addition has been fully incorporated into the dough before adding the second. Scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed.
With the mixer on medium, beat in the cheese until fully incorporated. The resulting dough will be very sticky, stretchy, and soft with a consistency between cake batter and cookie dough.
Using a large spoon scoop rounded portions of the dough into mounds on the parchment-lined baking sheet. Space the mounds an inch or two apart. Dip your scoop in water to prevent sticking.
Peel and cut the cooled potato in small pieces
Peel and cut the cooled 1 1/2 beet in small pieces
Transfer the sheet with the puffs to the oven and bake at 350°F for 25-30 minutes, until the puffs begin to have puffed, the outsides become dry, and they should start to be colored
Add the 2 cups broth, potato,1/2 tbsp salt and 1/4 tsp pepper and onion in a bowl and give to Big Chef
Add the potato after 30 minutes & cook until tender
Fry onion and stir until it begins to brown
Return the broth to the stove and continue to boil until the broth is deep red
Place the mushrooms and shallots in a skillet; add the port; bring to a boil; reduced the heat to low and simmer for 20 minutes.
Remove from the heat and put through a strainer or puree in a blender.
Add the cream. Return to the heat; bring just to the boiling point, reduce the heat and simmer 15 minutes longer.
Ladle into bowls; sprinkle with chopped chives.
Serve with the whipped cream and caviar.
The night before, place pinto beans in a large pot, cover with water and let them soak overnight.
The next day, drain the beans and place them back into the pot, pouring in enough fresh water to cover them a couple of inches.
Bring the beans to a boil, and then turn down the heat to medium and let softly boil for about 45 minutes, until they are nice and soft.
Meanwhile, place rice into a large pan with 4 cups of water and bring to a boil.
The rice will be done when there is no longer standing water in the pot, and the rice is light and fluffy.
Peel and chop eggplant. Chop onion, garlic, carrots and tomatoes
In a large skillet, heat a few tablespoons of olive oil and sauté onions and garlic until slightly browned.
Add the rest of the vegetables and spices, and cook until vegetables are soft.

Once beans have cooked down, mix the vegetables together with the beans. Do not drain the soupy liquid that has been cooked down with the beans and water. There should be a good amount of sauce to pour over the rice, so you can add more water to reach the right consistency.
Scoop rice onto a place and pour a heaping spoonful of beans and vegetable mixture over the top. Best when served very warm. Enjoy.
Trim crusts off 2 slices bread and save them for another use.
Peel the 3 potatoes and 3 carrots. In a large pot of boiling salted water, cook potatoes and carrots until fork tender. Set aside to cool.
In a medium sauce pan of boiling water, cook the 3 beets until tender. Set aside to cool and then peel beets by rubbing with a paper towel.
Once the cooked vegetables have cooled, give to Little Chef to cut.
Once potatoes, carrots and beets have cooled, cut them into small cubes.
In a large bowl, mix all ingredients together and stir to combine. Add olive oil and salt to taste and stir again.
Hard boil the 2 eggs, place in ice cold water to cool, refrigerate until ready to serve.
Crush the different types of fruit individually, to be sure all the skins are broken and the fruit is pulpy.
Put all the fruit in a large bowl with the sugar and cranberry juice and stir to mix.
Peel the tomatoes, remove the green stalk and seeds.
Cut off hard crust from the bread.
Cut the crusts from the bread and cut the slices into strips or triangles.
Place bread into water, and squeeze out excess liquid
Fit the bread into a 1 litre (2 pint) pudding basin to line the bottom and sides, reserving enough bread to cover the top. Fill in any gaps with small bits of bread.
Peel and mince garlic (take out the interior of the garlic).
Reserve 3–4 tbsp of juice from the mixed fruit, then gently pour the fruit mixture into the bread-lined pudding basin.

Cover with a plate that just fits inside the rim of the basin, setting it directly on top of the bread, and then place a heavy weight such as a can of food on top. Place the basin in the fridge to chill for 8 hours or overnight.
Place tomatoes in a blender or food processor, add squeezed bread, garlic, vinegar, salt and olive oil.

Cut bread into half inch cubes and fry in 1 tbsp butter and 1 tbsp oil mixture until golden brown.
Transfer to paper towel to dry.
To serve, turn the pudding out onto a serving dish.
Turn on the blender or food processor and process until smooth and creamy. If mixture is too thick, add tomato and olive oil.
Use the reserved fruit juice to brush or pour over any parts of the bread that have not been coloured.
Put in the fridge for 1-2 hours.
When ready to serve the soup peel and quarter hard boiled eggs, and pour soup into bowls.
Cook scrubbed, unpeeled potatoes in a large pot of boiling salted water until tender.
Sprinkle ham and hard boiled egg into each bowl.
Mash potatoes with a fork in a large bowl.
Mix in 1 1/2 tsp salt and 1/8 tsp nutmeg.
Add 1/2 cup flour and 1/8 cup cornstarch.
In a large soup pot over high heat, add 10 cups of water.
Using hands, knead mixture in bowl until smooth dough forms, adding tablespoonfuls of flour if dough is sticky.
Dice the potatoes and add them to the pot.
Finely dice onions and thinly slice celery and add them to the large skillet.
Once the little chef has put the ingredients in the pot, bring to a boil.
Continue to cook the potatoes 10 minutes after boiling.
Form dough into balls using one fourth cupful for each.
Add sliced carrots into the pot and cook for another 10 minutes.
In a large skillet, add 3 Tbsp of olive oil over med/high heat.
Sauté the diced onions and the celery until soft and golden brown, will take about 7 minutes.
Toss this mixture into the big pot.
Add the shelled shrimp and the chopped fish into the pot.
Add the two bay leaves, 1 Tbsp of Mrs. Dash, 1/8 tsp of pepper, 2 Tbsp of fresh parsley.
Return the pot to a boil and cook another 5 minutes or until shrimp and the fish are fully cooked.
Add salt to taste and remove from heat.

Insert bread cube into center of each dumpling.
Roll dumpling between palms for enclose bread completely and form smooth balls.
Working in batches, cook dumplings in a large pot of nearly boiling salted water, ten to fifteen minutes or until dumplings rise to top.
Using slotted spoon, transfer dumplings to a large bowl.
Keep covered with a damp kitchen towel as remaining dumplings are cooked.
You should place no more than four to five dumplings in your pot at any one time in order to prevent them from sticking together or touching during cooking, which will cause them to fall apart.
Lightly beat egg. Cut fish in half on an angle.
Chop capers. Chop cornichons. Finely chop parsley leaves. Juice lemon.
Heat 3” of oil in a deep fryer to 325°F. Alternately, heat 3” of oil in a deep pot.
Peel potatoes. Cut into chips (about the size of your index finger).
Put the potatoes in the oil. Fry chips for 2-3 minutes (should not be crispy or fully cooked). Remove chips with strainer, to a paper towel-lined platter to drain.
Combine flour, baking powder, salt, pepper, and egg in a large mixing bowl.
Pour in soda water. Whisk to a smooth batter.
Spread the rice flour on a plate.
Dredge the fish pieces in the rice flour. Dip them into the batter, letting excess drip off.
Put the chips in the bottom of the fryer basket. Carefully submerge in hot oil.
Carefully wave the battered fish into the bubbling oil before dropping them in on top of the chips.
Fry fish and chips for 4-5 minutes until crispy and brown.
Remove the basket and drain the fish and chips on paper towels.
Dice the 3 tomatoes and 1 cup cucumber.
Peel and cut the 3 avocado into bite-sized pieces.
Chop the 1/2 cup green and 1/2 cup red bell peppers.

Mix tomato-vegetable juice, 2 1/2 cups vegetable broth, tomatoes, avocados, cucumber, canned tomatoes with juice, green bell pepper, red bell pepper, olive oil, green onions, lemon juice, cilantro, vinegar, hot pepper sauce, salt, and black pepper together in a large bowl.
Cover and chill for at least 3 hours before serving to allow flavors to blend.
Chop 1 lb. of  kale into one inch pieces including ribs
Combine flour, salt and sugar in large bowl. Lightly grease and flour baking sheet.
Add butter. Rub into flour with fingers until mixture resembles sand.
Heat 1 tbsp. of peanut oil in a large, deep pot/wok
Using a flat palette knife, stir buttermilk into flour mix until just combined.
Add chopped onions when oil gets hot
Turn mixed dough onto a flat surface and very gently knead mixture until it just forms a cohesive mass.
Pat dough out until it is about 2 cm high. Use small scone cutter dipped in extra flour, cut out the scones. Put leftover dough back into dough mass.
Cook on medium-high heat for 8 minutes. Stir frequently.
Bake for 20-25 minutes or until brown or hollow sounding when tapped on base.
When the onion gets soft, stir in 1 tsp. of cumin, 1/2 tsp. of coriander, and 1/2 tsp. of turmeric.
Stir together the 1 cup of kasha and the egg (beaten) until coated well.
Prepare all ingredients that need to be chopped, and measure out everything.
Cook the kasha and the egg in a 3 1/2-to-4-quart heavy saucepan over moderate heat, stirring constantly, until grains smell toasty and begin to separate. Takes about 2 minutes.
Add chopped kale, one handful at a time. Stir constantly to coat them with onions, oil and spices.

Add boiling-hot water, ½ teaspoon of salt, and ¼ teaspoons of black pepper, and simmer, covered, over low heat until the kasha is barely tender and most of the water has been absorbed. Takes about 12 minutes.
Remove from heat and let it stand, covered, for about 10 minutes.
Add 1.5 tsp of salt and fresh pepper to taste.
While the kasha cooks, toast the walnuts in 1 tablespoon of butter in a 12-inch heavy skillet over moderate heat. Stir frequently for 5 minutes
Transfer the nuts to a plate, and then add oil and remaining ½ tablespoon of butter to the skillet over moderate heat until the foam subsides.
Cover pot. Turn heat down to medium. Cook for 10-20 minutes or until greens are tender to your taste.
Add the onion and thyme and cook, stirring occasionally until softened and brown, about 15 minutes.
Remove lid and turn off heat
Cut green and 4 red bell peppers in half as well as cut 2 large onions into eighths
Puncture the 2 eggplants in a few spots with a toothpick.
Rub the eggplants with a bit of olive oil and place on a sheet pan.
Place the onions and peppers cut side down onto another sheet pan.
Place both sheet pans in the oven and roast for 10 minutes.Turn the vegetables over and roast another 10 minutes until the eggplants are tender, but not completely collapsed.
Remove the vegetables from the oven, cover the pans with foil, and allow the vegetables to steam until cool enough to handle.
Lower the oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit.
Using a paring knife and your fingers, peel and seed the peppers, but do not rinse them.
Cut 6 of the red pepper halves lengthwise in half again (giving you 12 large quarters) and place in a mixing bowl.
Remove 24 of the largest leaves of the onion, discarding the dry, outermost onion leaves, and add to the bowl of large red pepper pieces.

Coarsely chop the remaining onion and place in an ovenproof baking dish. Cut the 2 remaining red pepper halves and the green pepper halves into ¼×½-inch pieces and place them in the baking dish with the onions.
Slit the eggplants lengthwise and, using the side of a knife, scrape the flesh free from the skins. Discard the skins. Coarsely chop the flesh and add it to the baking dish.
Dice bacon. Finely chop onions. Grate Gruyere cheese.

Whisk the salt, black pepper, lemon juice, and garlic in a small bowl. Slowly whisk in the 7 tablespoons olive oil to make a dressing. Add all but 2 tablespoons of the dressing plus 1 tablespoon of the parsley to the baking dish, tossing well to combine with the chopped vegetables.
In a bowl combine 1 cup of water and .25 cups of millet flour and .75 cups of corn flour.
Place the baking dish in the oven for 15 minutes. Remove, and let the vegetable mixture come to room temperature.
When ready to serve, mound the vegetable mixture at the center of a serving plate.

Toss the large red pepper and onion pieces in the mixing bowl with the remaining 2 tablespoons of dressing, and alternately arrange them in a spiked pattern around the mound. Scatter the remaining 2 tablespoons of chopped parsley over all.
Add wet flour to boiling water while stirring

Wipe mushrooms clean and cut off the stalks if they are dirty.
Pull the stalks apart from the caps and chop the stalks finely.

Clean the spinach and blanch it in boiling salt water for 2 minutes.
Remove, squeeze dry and chop.

Fry the bacon in a pan until well done but not crisp.
Add the onion and fry until almost golden, stirring occasionally.
Add chopped mushroom stalks and fry for a few more minutes.
Take pot off the stove.

Mix in the spinach and 1/2 tsp marjoram.
Mix in 2 egg yolks.
Add some breadcrumbs if the mixture needs thickening.
Season with salt and pepper.

Fill the mushrooms with the stuffing and cover with 1/2 cup grated cheese.
Broil for ten minutes or until the cheese bubbly and golden.
Cook 2 cups of beans (if not already cooked)
Add 2 cups of corn and and cooked beans into a large pot with enough water just to cover
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Bring to a boil over medium heat
Chop 4tbsp parsley, and mince 5 garlic cloves.
Chop Onion. Chop carrots. Puree tomato. Cut potatoes into chunks.
Heat oil in a medium saucepan.
Soften onion and carrots for a few minutes. When soft, turn up heat. Crumble in lamb and brown, tipping off any excess fat.
In a wide, shallow sauté pan over high heat, warm the 1/2 cup olive oil and the 1/2 cup butter.
Reduce heat to low and simmer until cooked through
Add tomato puree and Worcestershire sauce.
Add the 1 1/2 lb shrimp and minced garlic and sauté quickly for about 2-3 minutes.
Bring to a simmer. Cover. Cook for 40 minutes, uncovering halfway.
Add the 1/4 cup lemon juice, 1 tsp paprika, 1/2 tsp pepper flakes, and salt and pepper to taste. Adjust seasonings to your liking.
Boil potatoes in salted water for 10-15 minutes, until tender.
Transfer to a warmed serving dish, sprinkle with the parsley and serve at once.
Mash potatoes with butter and milk.
Put mince into an ovenproof dish. Top with mash. Ruffle with a fork.
Bake for 20-25 minutes until top is starting to color and mince is bubbling though at the edges.
Leave to stand for 5 minutes before serving.
Wash the 3 potatoes and 1/2 cabbage in warm water
Boil 8 cups of water in a pot.
Peel and cut potatoes in small pieces
Little chef is responsible for salting and seasoning the soup
Pour corn flour into boiling water, avoid forming of lumps
Pour the 10 cups water into a large pot and bring it to a boil, put a piece of beef in it and boil till the meat is tender.
Add the potatoes and cabbage to the boiling water. Season with salt and pepper.
Stir continuously and mash any lumps that form

Meanwhile, in a skillet, melt the 1/2 tbsp butter and add the 1 chopped onion, 2 carrots, 2 celery and 2 garlic. Season with salt and pepper, and cook on medium heat for about 5 minutes, until vegetables are tender.
Add the tomatoes and pepper. Season with salt and pepper again and cook for another 3 minutes. Add the vegetables to the soup.
Cook the soup at a simmer for about 20 minutes total, until the potatoes are tender.
Add more corn flour till it is thicker than mashed potatoes
Take the soup off the heat and garnish with fresh herbs, such as dill, parsley and green onions. Serve with sour cream and dill.
Chop the 4 tomatoes 1 cup of fresh cilantro, grate the 3 carrots, and dice the 2 onions.
Place onions on top of the tomato
Splash .5 cups of lemon juice over and toss
Cut bacon into large pieces. Halve and slice onion. Beat egg.
Heat oil in a large, non-stick frying pan.
Fry for 5-8 minutes, until golden brown, turn occasionally.
Lift chicken onto a plate and tip bacon into pan.
Beat 3 eggs thoroughly. Add 1 tsp salt, 2 tbsp water and 2 cups flour to make a soft dough.
Divide dough into 3 parts for easier handling.
Cut into rounds and fill with meat mixture. Use a wine glass or a round cookie cutter to make the rounds of a proper size.

Sprinkle board with flour and roll dough to 1/8 inch thickness. Fold the circles in half and seal the edges together to get a half circle with a meat inside. Then take two corners of the half-circle and put them together, pressing to make them stick. Drop dumplings into large pot containing 3 quarts boiling salted water and three bay leaves. Boil for 25 minutes. Serve with sour cream or butter.
Fry on high heat for another 3 minutes until the onions start to color.
With the pan off the heat, gradually stir or whisk in the stock. Follow with milk.
Add chicken back to the pan.
Combine 1 tsp. of cardamom and 3/4 cup of warm milk.
Bring to a boil. Simmer for 30 minutes.
Boil 1/4 cup of warm water in a saucepan.
Spoon the filling into a large pie or baking dish, with lip. Leave to cool.
In a bowl mix 1 tbsp. of yeast, 1/2 cup of sugar, 3 cups of flour with the warm water. Leave yeast to rise.
Roll pastry on a floured surface to the thickness of 1/4 inch.
Cut long strip as wide as the rim of the pie dish. Use a little bit of egg to fix to the edge of the pie dish.
After yeast has risen add cardamom and milk mixture, and 1 cup of coconut milk powder. Knead into a dough.
Brush with egg. Lift the rest of the pastry over the pie, use rolling pin to help.
Let dough rest in warm place (preferably overnight or until double in size).
Brush lightly with egg to glaze.
Roll each ball into 6” circles. Cut into quarters.
Bake for 30 minutes or until pastry is risen and dark golden brown.
Pour oil in a deep frying pan on medium heat (you want the oil to be hot enough when you start frying).
Drop 3-4 triangles into hot oil (if oil is hot enough, dough will quickly float to top and puff up).
Cook on other side for about 1 minute. Remove from fryer with slated spoon. Should be a light golden brown.
Turn mahamri as soon as it turns light brown.
Pour 4 cup milk, 1 cup sugar, and 1 tsp cardamom seeds in a pot over the stove.
Cut the bread loaf in thick slices.

When the milk mixture has been cooking for about 15 minutes, turn off the heat and soak the slices of bread in this mixture. Be careful not to completely wet them to the point that they will break apart, but try to get them to absorb as much milk as possible.
Let the slices of wet bread rest and cool (some liquid may be lost).
Beat the 4 eggs in a shallow bowl and dip the slices in the egg mixture.
In the meantime, heat up about half an inch of vegetable oil in a deep, heavy pan on a medium high heat.
Cook the slices two by two, flipping half way so that both sides are nice and crisp.
Remove the French toast and let it rest on paper towels to absorb excess oil.
In another bowl mix the remaining sugar (1/2 cup) with the 2 tsp of cinnamon.
Cover the slices in the cinnamon sugar mixture and reserve.
Wash 1 lb berries and fruit in warm water
Peel and cut fruit in small pieces
Fill a medium pot with 8 cups of water. Add 1 pound berries and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and simmer for 12 minutes, partially covered. Add ¾ cup of sugar and 1 Tbsp lemon juice and continue simmering another 3 minutes.

Finally dissolve 4 Tbsp of potato starch in ¼ cup of water and slowly add it to the pot while stirring the soup. Remove from heat and let kissel cool slightly. To serve, ladle the very warm soup into bowls or mugs.

Spread caramelized nuts on a sheet of foil to cool and set aside.

Toss the butternut squash in 2 tbsp olive oil.  Spread on baking sheets.  Season with salt, pepper and 1 tsp sumac.  Roast for 15 minutes, remove from the oven and flip.  Return to oven for another 10 to 15 minutes.
Kale with Butternut Squash and Apples
Fry 4 pieces of bacon strips until crispy.  Remove and put on a sheet of paper towel to drain.
Kale with Butternut Squash and Apples
Cut the spines from the kale using kitchen sheers or a knife.  Cut kale into 2-3” bite size pieces.  Put the kale in a large bowl and sprinkle with 2 pinches of salt and 2 tbsp olive oil.
Kale with Butternut Squash and Apples
Using your hands massage the kale until it changes in texture and color to a supple dark green.  This will take 2-5 minutes depending on kale type and maturity.
Kale with Butternut Squash and Apples
Add juice from ½ lemon and massage for another minute.
Kale with Butternut Squash and Apples
Add butternut squash, 1 apple cut into chunks, red onion, crumbled bacon, cheese and caramelized cashews.
Kale with Butternut Squash and Apples
Toss with a splash of vinegar.  Add additional lemon juice to taste.
Mince 2 garlic cloves and juice the 2 lemons.
Combine lemon juice, garlic, curry powder, coriander, and paprika to taste, as well as salt and pepper to taste in large glass dish, mix well.
Add 3 lbs. of beef short ribs. Stir to coat meat with marinade. Let marinate for 1 hr.
Grill meat over charcoal, or broil in a hot oven
Heat the butter and the olive oil in a frying pan.

In a large mixing bowl, mix together all the ingredients of a room temperature. It is important that all the ingredients are of a room temperature, and not fresh from the fridge. In that case you will have your syrniki especially delicious.
The dough will be sticky and slightly lumpy. Transfer the dough onto a well floured surface.
Stir in the bell pepper and cook for a couple of minutes, at low to medium heat.
Shape the dough into a log with your hands, about 2 inches wide (not length).
Add the spring onions, tomatoes and red pepper flakes, mix well. Crack the eggs in a bowl and mix. Add the feta cheese, combine well.
Cut the log about 3/4 inch sections vertically with a knife.
For each cut out dough, dip sides in flour.
Stir in the egg mixture to the frying pan and give it a good stir. Scramble the eggs until they are done.

Heat a nonstick skillet or griddle on medium high heat. Add a few tablespoons of oil in a skillet, or generously grease a griddle. Shake off excess flour and fry the syrniki about 3-5 minutes on both sides.
Place fried syrniki on paper towel to soak up that oil. Can be served with kissel or sour cream.
Season with salt and ground black pepper to taste.
Mash cheese w/a fork in a bowl.
Mix in the celery and black pepper.
Gradually beat in the cream cheese & fold in the chives.
Chill in the fridge till required.
Peel, quarter & core pears 20-30 min b4 serving. Cut crossways into slices Mix w/the lemon juice to stop them turning brown (I usually use my pastry brush for this)
Fill 18 pre-baked mini-tartlet shells w/the cheese mixture, stand a pear piece on top.

Remove outer leaves, core and shred 3 lbs cabbage.
Chop 1 onion and 6 cloves garlic.
Wash, remove outer leaves and chop 2 leeks.

Heat 2 tbsp oil in a large non-stick pan.
Add 1 tbsp sugar and heat gently until the sugar browns.

Add the chopped onions, garlic and leeks.
Cook until they start to wilt.
Cook kielbasa covered over a low heat, stirring occasionally until cooked through.
Pour the ½ cup of water into the pan, cover and cook for another 10mins before serving.
Sauté 1/2 cup margarine and onions in a large skillet until the onions are sufficiently soft.
Stir cabbage and potatoes into the skillet and sauté until the cabbage becomes wilted.
Place the kielbasa, wine vinegar, salt and pepper into the skillet.
Stir in cabbage, saute, stirring frequently, until the cabbage has softened, about twenty minutes.

Season to taste with pepper.
Transfer the cabbage mixture and pan juices to a large bowl and keep warm.
Cook the 12 oz package of noodles according to the packet instructions, then drain.

Quickly toss the noodles with cabbage mixture and 1 tbsp poppy seeds.
Serve immediately.
Clean off as much excess fat as possible. Then, have the leg separated into three pieces at the joints.
In a bowl, whisk together the olive oil, lemon juice and spices.
Preheat your oven to 285° F /140° C. Place the lamb in a shallow metal oven roasting tray. Pour the mixture over the lamb.
Rub the mixture all over the lamb, massaging it into the meat for several minutes. Add the bay leaves and rosemary sprigs. Place the tray in the oven uncovered.

Let the lamb cook slowly at this low temperate for about 1 ½ hours. You'll see that the meat will release its fat and juices, then reabsorb them as it cooks. After the first 30 minutes, turn the pieces of lamb over. Repeat this two more times during the cooking process.

When 1 ½ hours have passed and you have turned the meat three times, pour the ½ cup of hot water over the meat, then close the roasting pan completely with aluminum foil. Turn up the oven temperature to 365° F /185° C and leave the meat to roast for a least one hour more.

After about one hour, remove the pan from the oven and let it rest for five minutes. Remove the foil. The meat should be very tender and falling cleanly off the bones. Using two forks, remove all the meat from the bones and discard them. Also remove the bay leaves and rosemary.
Dice meat and slighty fry it in a cast-iron pot or skillet
Thoroughly clean and trim the leeks, halve them lengthwise and slice them very thinly. Chop the onions finely. Add the leeks and onions, sauté until they turn translucent and let cool.
Bring 6 cups of water to a boil in a large cooking pot.
When the water has reached a boil add .5 lbs of edamame and 2 tsp. of salt. Then, lower the flame and simmer for 4-6 minutes.
After simmering, drain the cooked edamame in a colander.
In a mixing bowl combine, 2 tablespoons soy sauce, 2 tablespoons water,1 tablespoon rice vinegar,1 tablespoon sesame oil, .25 teaspoon red chili flakes, 1 tsp. chopped garlic, and .5 teaspoon sugar
Mix in the cooked edamame to the sauce created in the mixing bowl so that they are coated with the sauce.
Serve immediately, or store in the fridge for 1-2 days.
Peel potatoes, grate them and, using a cheesecloth, squeeze out the liquid. Beat the eggs and combine them with the ingredients in the skillet.
Season to taste with salt, pepper, marjoram, nutmeg and parsley.

Cover the pot and place into the oven for 1 – 1-1/2 hours. (If you do not own a large enough skillet or Dutch oven, you may also use a large baking dish. In order to achieve a crunchy top layer, remove lid 15 min taking the dish out.

Core 1 cabbage head.
Cut 8 oz steak into 1/4 inch pieces.
Mince 6 garlic cloves and 1 large onion.
Roughly chop 1 tsp parsley.
Seed and thinly slice 1 Italian frying pepper into rings.
Combine the sugar and 1 cup lukewarm water in a small bowl, then sprinkle over the yeast. Set aside for about 8 minutes, or until foamy, then add another 1 1/4 cups lukewarm water.

Combine the flour and salt in a bowl, then add the yeast mixture and stir to form a coarse dough. Turn out onto a lightly floured surface and knead for 6-7 minutes, or until the dough is smooth and elastic.
Bring large pot of salted water to a boil.
Add head of cabbage and cook, pulling off each outer leaf with tongs as it becomes tender, 2-4 minutes per leaf.

Transfer cabbage leaves to a baking sheet.
Set aside and continue boiling cabbage until you have 12-15 leaves.
In a medium pot over medium-high heat combine 2 tsp. dashi granules and 2 cups of water; bring to a boil.
Reduce heat to medium, and whisk in 3 tbsp. miso paste.
Then, dice the 8 oz of tofu and stir it into the pot.
Diagonally slice the 2 green onions into .5 inch pieces, and add them to the soup.
Simmer gently for 2 to 3 minutes before serving.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
In a bowl whisk together 1 cup of rice flour, 2 1/2 cups of white sugar and 1 tsp. of baking powder; set aside.
In a medium bowl, mix together the 2 cups of water,1 tsp. of vanilla, 14 oz. of coconut milk and 1/4 tsp. red food coloring.
Blend in the rice flour mixture into the medium bowl. Pour into the prepared pan.
Cover the pan with foil and bake for 1 hour. Allow to cool completely.
Turn the pan of mochi out onto a clean surface that has been dusted with 1.5 cups of potato starch.
Cut into bite size pieces using a plastic knife. The mochi does not stick as much to plastic knives.

Make the dumpling dough: In a bowl, stir together both flours; add oil and eggs, and stir until dough forms. Transfer to a lightly floured work surface, and knead until smooth, about 6 minutes. Wrap in plastic and refrigerate for 1 hour

Remove the stalks of the spinach, wash and chop roughly. Mix together in a bowl with the feta cheese, shredded mozzarella and two of the beaten eggs. In a separate bowl, mix the water, 1 tablespoon olive oil and milk.

Grease a rectangular baking dish with the remaining olive oil. Lay the pastry sheets along its long side and cut in half vertically. Open the sheets only when you are ready to use them and cover the rest with a damp towel so that they don’t dry out.

Lay three sheets in the greased baking dish. Pour a little of the milk-olive oil-water mixture (about 3 tablespoons) all over the sheet. Repeat this layering two more times, using three fillo sheets each time.

Lay three more sheets over and spread the spinach filling evenly. Continue laying three sheets of fillo, pouring over each the milk mixture, three more times. Lay the remaining sheets on the top of the pie, sprinkling the milk mixture. Whisk together the remaining beaten egg with a little olive oil and brush over the pastry. Sprinkle with sesame or nigella seeds.
Bake the pie in the oven for about 40 minutes, until the top is golden brown. Serve hot, cut into pieces. This dish can be  successfully reheated.

Make the dumpling filling: In a large bowl, mix beef, veal, pork, bacon, parsley, cream, spinach, 1 egg, remaining onion, nutmeg, and salt and pepper. Transfer to a piping bag fitted with a 1⁄2″ round tip, and set aside.
Make the dumpling garnish: Heat oil in a 8″ skillet over medium heat; add minced onion, and cook, stirring often, until caramelized, about 25 minutes. Set onions aside.

Unwrap dumpling dough, and divide into 4 equal pieces; working with one piece at a time, pass dough through a pasta roller until 1⁄16″ thick. Lay sheet of pasta on a work surface, and pipe filling in a straight line down lower 1⁄3 of pasta sheet. (For step-by-step photo instructions, see gallery above) Continue with remaining pasta and filling to make about 25 dumplings. Bring a 6-qt. pot of water to a boil, add dumplings, cooking until they float, about 20 minutes.

Bring chicken stock, carrot, celery, and salt and pepper to a simmer in a 6-qt. saucepan over medium-high heat, until vegetables are soft, about 3 minutes. To serve, divide dumplings into 8 bowls, ladle soup over dumplings, and top each dumpling with some of the caramelized onions; garnish with parsley.
Put 12 ounces sugar in a frying-pan, fry slowly until the sugar starts to foam. Do not stir, because the sugar will get lumpy.
Add the walnuts, mix well and remove from the heat before the sugar gets too brown.
Add the cream immediately and let it boil down.
Mix flour, margarine, the rest of the sugar (150 g equals to 5 ounces), the egg and the salt and make a dough.
Cut the dough into three pieces, two of the same size and one slightly smaller.
