Roll the two pieces of the same size to make up a bottom and a top of the cake in a form with 28-30 cm (11-12 inches) diameter.
Form a roll with the third piece and place it on the bottom along the form.
Pour the filling evenly on the bottom.
Cover the cake with the top.
Bake in the oven at a lower level at about 200°C (400°F) for 40-45 minutes.
Open the form immediately after removing from the oven to prevent the cake from sticking to the form.

Cut 24 oz salmon fillets into six serving pieces.
Chop 2 tsp fresh thyme.
Chop 2 tbsp parsley.
Wet hands with cold water and sprinkle them with salt.
Cook the 4 cups of rice in your rice cooker.

Set the salmon on a foil-lined baking sheet, skin side down.
Sprinkle with salt and pepper.
In a small bowl, combine the 2 tbsp honey mustard and 1 tsp of chopped thyme.

In another bowl, mix 2/3 cup panko breadcrumbs with 1 tsp of thyme, 4 tsp olive oil, 2 tbsp parsley and 1/2 tsp sweet Hungarian paprika.
Add salt and pepper.

Using a small spoon, spread the mustard mixture on the salmon.
Top with the breadcrumb mixture.
Roast the salmon for 12-14 minutes or until it is almost completely firm to the touch and flakes when poked with a fork.
Start by removing and discarding the hard crusts. Cut the bread into 2cm squares.

Melt half the butter in a frying pan, add the bread and cook over a low heat for a few minutes until the bread absorbs the butter and turns a toasted golden brown.  Remove from the pan and set aside, reserving the pan.
Peel and core the apples, and cut into small chunks.

Add the remaining butter and sugar to the bread pan, and cook over a low heat until they melt together. Continue to heat, stirring continuously, until the mixture caramelizes and turns golden. Quickly add the apple pieces and cook for a few minutes until softened. Don’t have the heat too high at this stage, as the caramel will catch and burn easily, ruining the dish.
Sprinkle with a little cinnamon to taste.
Add in the bread, and cook for a few seconds until heated through.
Serve hot with cream or créme fraiche.
Cook the onion with butter in a large skillet under medium-high heat until soft, not brown
Add the leeks and potatoes. Season with salt, pepper and nutmeg.
Add the wine and beef stock, cover and simmer for 25 minutes until the potatoes are lightly cooked.

Meanwhile, pre-boil the sausages in a pot containing just enough water to cover the sausages. Cook until the sausages are two-thirds done, between 15 and 30 minutes depending on the size of the sausages.
Drain the leek/potato mixture and simmer for 5 more minutes. Don\'t drain completely if you want to keep some of the wine taste.
Add the cream to the drained potatoes and leeks and stir.
Lay the pre-boiled sausages on top. Cover and simmer for a another 3-4 minutes.
Sprinkle with chopped parsley and serve.
In a bowl, mix 1 cup of plain flour, 1 tsp. of baking soda and 2 tbsp. of potato starch together.
In a separate bowl, crack one egg and beat it roughly. Then add 1 cup of cold water and mix them together.
Put 1/3 mixed flour in to egg mixture and gently mix. Long cooking chop sticks are the best utensil for mixing tempura batter. If you do not have them, use a fork instead.
Then add an additional 1/3 cup of flour and mix.
Finally add the last 1/3 flour and mix. Lumps in the mix are completely fine. Do not mix it too much because you will get an un-crispy tempura batter.
Put 2 inches of sunflower oil in a frying pan.

Heat up the frying oil to 170 degrees. You can check the oil temperature without a thermometer. Put one drop of tempura batter into the oil. If the tempura batter sinks the bottom of flying pan, the temperature is too low.
If the tempura batter did not sink at all and the batter spread quickly with a crackling sound then it is too high of a temperature.
The best temperature condition is when the drop of tempura batter will sink half way in frying pan, then float.
Put vegetables of your choice into the tempura batter bowl to coat them with tempura batter.

Slice 2 Csabai sausages and 8 hard boiled eggs.
Melt 60 g butter.
Bring 35.3 oz. potatoes to a boil in a saucepan of salted water.
Reduce heat to low and cook for 40 minutes or until just tender.
Drain, cool, peel and thickly slice.
In a bowl, combine the two flours, salt and nutmeg. Make a well in the center, add the eggs and start mixing the batter while adding the milk little by little.
Heat oil in a frying pan over high heat.
The batter should be semi-liquid and should be sticky; to do this, add the water until it has reached such a consistency. Let the batter rest for at least an hour in the fridge.

Add sausages and cook for 2 minutes or until light golden.
Drain on a paper towel.
Meanwhile, cut the cheese in small pieces, pass the garlic clove through a garlic crusher (and set them aside).

Dice the potatoes and cut the savoy cabbage leaves into pieces. Bring salted water to a boil and add the potatoes, when they are almost cooked add the savoy cabbage for 2-3 minutes, remove from fire and strain. Set aside.
Remove the batter from the fridge. Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Take a wooden board and make sure it’s damp with water.
Grease a deep forty cm round baking dish with butter.

Layer one third of the potatoes in the dish.
Top with half the eggs and half the sausages.
Top with 1/2 of the remaining potatoes.
Top with remaining eggs, sausages and potatoes.
Season and spread over remaining sour cream.
Scatter with 1/2 cup stale breadcrumbs and drizzle with 2.12 oz. melted butter.
Cut rolls in two halves and coat each half with a bit of remoulade
Drain pickles well and pat dry with kitchen paper
Cut pickles into thin slices and cover the bottom half of each roll with it
Pat dry on kitchen paper Bismarck herring, so the rolls do not soak through so quickly
Peel and halve the onion and cut it into slices
Cover the Bismarck herring with onions
Place the top half of the roll on the Bismarck herring and press lightly
Wash your fruit well, remove any stickers, remove any stems and cut into fourths. Do no peel or remove seeds. Do, however, remove pits if any.
In a large pot cook the fruit over Medium-Low heat, moving the fruit around occasionally. Be sure that once the juice starts to expel, that it does not come to a boil; do bring it to a simmer.
Continue cooking the fruit for 4 hours.

Slice the 14 oz. package of tofu into 1⁄4” thick squares. Place them in a gallon­sized freezerbag and cover with 1⁄4 cup soy sauce and 1 tablespoon sugar. Squeeze as much air out as possible and seal the bag. Marinate the tofu for 30 minutes.
In a small bowl, whisk together 1/4 cups of tahini, 2 tbsp. of water, 1 tablespoon soy sauce, 1 tbsp. rice vinegar, 1 tsp. sesame oil, 1/2 tsp. salt and .125 tsp. white pepper.

Heat a frying pan until hot. Add 2 tablespoons of toasted sesame oil, and then fry the tofu until browned on one side. Flip the tofu and brown the 

second side.
Press the fruit through a fine sieve or cheesecloths to remove the maximum amount of juice and pulp. Discard what is left over.
Transfer the browned tofu to a cutting board and cut into bite­sized pieces
Over medium-low heat, continue to cook the juice and pulp for 4 hours; stirring every 15 minutes.

Boil 10.5 oz of soba noodles according to the package directions. If the directions give a range of times, use the low end of the range, if there’s only one number, boil the noodles for 1 minute less than what the directions say.
Drain the noodles and plunge them into a bowl of ice water to chill.
Prepare 1 cup of  cherry tomatoes by washing and cutting them in half. Halve, pit, peel, then cube the avocado and squeeze the juice of half of a lemon over it.
Once the fruit starts to caramelize, keep close watch.
Pluck the cilantro leaves to from the stems to make 1/4 cups, and discard the stems.
Add the noodles, tofu, cherry tomatoes, avocado, cilantro, and 2 tbsp. of black sesame seeds to a bowl and drizzle the dressing on top.

The salad will keep for up to one day in the fridge, but it is best eaten
immediately as the noodles will absorb the dressing and get soft.
Open can of tuna with a can opener.
Slice 2 cucumbers, 1 daikon, and 1 carrot very thin diagonally.
In a separate bowl cover the vegetables with 2 tbsp. of salt and let sit for 30 minutes.
Combine vegetables with 1/2 cups of rice vinegar, 2/3 cups of sugar, and the 1/2 teaspoon salt.
You may add kamaboko, imitation crab meat, or seasoned clams.
Let it sit in the fridge for an hour
Mix tuna with mayonnaise and parsley in a mixing bowl.

In a medium saucepan, stir together the 1/2 cup honey and molasses. Bring the mixture to a boil, remove from heat and stir in the 3/4 cup brown sugar, 1 egg, 1 Tbsp. lemon juice and lemon zest. In a large bowl, stir together the flour (2.75 cup), 1/2 tsp. baking soda, 1 tsp. cinnamon, cloves, allspice and nutmeg. Add the 1/2 cup molasses mixture to the dry ingredients and mix well. Stir in the citron and hazelnuts. Cover dough and chill overnight.

Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets. Using a small amount of dough at a time, roll out on a lightly floured surface to 1/4 inch thickness. Cut into small rectangles and place them 1 inch apart onto the prepared cookie sheet.

Bake for 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, until no imprint remains when touched lightly. Brush the icing over the cookies while they are still hot and quickly remove them to wire cooling racks. Store in airtight container with a cup of orange or apple for a few days to mellow.

To make the icing: Combine the sugar and water in a small saucepan. Heat to between 234 and 240 degrees F (112 to 116 degrees C), or until a small amount of syrup dropped into cold water forms a soft ball that flattens when removed from the water and placed on a flat surface. Remove from heat and stir in the confectioners\' sugar. If icing becomes sugary while brushing cookies, re-heat slightly- adding a little water until crystals dissolve.
Fill the middle of each of the peach half with the tuna mixture.
Serve tuna on a platter on a bed of salad leaves.

Cook 2 whole crabs in salt water, drain and cut in half. Cut the 2 lbs. lamb or beef into chunks. Joint and clean pig's foot (optional). Mince 2 onions. Blanch peel and puree 3 tomatoes. Grind 3 chili peppers. Clean 4 mushrooms. Smoke, grill, deep-fry or sundry 2 lbs. of fish.
In a pan toast 2 tbsp. of sesame seeds, and be careful not to burn them.
Add in 1 tbsp. of miso, 2 tbsp. of rice vinegar, and 1.5 tsp of honey.
Add 4 tbsp. of oil in a slow, steady stream while whisking to emulsify.
Remove stomach flaps on the underside of the crabs. Cut them in half, from top to bottom.
Add 1 tsp. of water to thin.
Place 1/2 cup of water, meat and pig\'s foot in a very large, heavy-based pan (not crock-pot because the initial cooking process requires fairly high heat, which a crock-pot does not provide).
Drizzle over your choice of salad
Whisk together the dry ingredients, 3 cups flour, 1 Tbsp. yeast, 1 Tbsp. sugar, and 1 tsp. salt-in a large bowl.
Heat the 1 cup rice milk to a very warm temperature and add the margarine.
Mix this with the dry ingredients until it forms dough.
Remove the finished dough onto a flat surface and knead it for about 5 minutes.
Let the dough rise and double in size. Cover with a dish towel or a plastic wrap. Leave for about 30 minutes.
After 30 minutes of the dough rising, divide the dough into 6 pieces. Use a rolling pin to form oval shapes about 15 cm/6 inches long.
Use a sharp knife to cut four slits into each piece.
Carefully stretch and place the rolls on a baking sheet. Let them rest for around 30 minutes.
Brush the melted margarine over the rolls with a pastry brush, or the back of a spoon.
Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until golden brown.
Stir in the onions and cook dry on high heat, stirring continuously, until the outside of the meat is sealed and browned on all sides.
Slice the fillings of your choice into long sticks.
Reduce heat and continue to simmer for ten to fifteen minutes.
Cut 1 sheet of nori in half or into 5x5 squares
In a large bowl, combine 1.5 lbs of palm nut pulp with 1 cup of  boiling water. Beat with a wooden spoon to form a creamy, smooth consistency.
Add to the meat mixture, as well as the ground chilies, mushrooms and crabs.
Simmer on medium heat for forty minutes to an hour, stirring occasionally to keep food from sticking to the bottom of the pan.
Prepare your choice of fish by removing any residual bones.
Add fish to the soup, either whole or in chunks, during the last twenty minutes of cooking to prevent fist from breaking up too much and becoming mushy.
Once all ingredients are added, continue to simmer slowly until the meat is tender.

Smoke 1 lb. of fish. Peel and finely grate 3 tbsp. of ginger. Mince 2 onions and 2 red chilies. Blanch, peel and puree 4 tomatoes. Blend tomato paste with 1/4 cup of water. Chop 1/2 lb. of green beans.
Season fish with salt to taste and grated ginger.
Heat the 1/2 cup of oil in a heavy-based pan. Saute the fish until crisp and brown.

Remove oil.
Drain.
Set aside and keep hot.
In the remaining hot oil, add the onions and saute until they are almost brown.
Add the tomatoes, 1 tbsp. of tomato paste blended with 1/4 cup of water, chilies, green beans, and garlic salt.
Return the fish to the pan, cover, simmer for ten to fifteen minutes or until the sauce thickens.
Put the 2 cups of gari in a bowl and add enough lightly salted cold water just to cover it completely.
Let stand for ten minutes or until the gari absorbs the liquid and swells.

Fluff gari with a fork.
Accompany each serving of fried fish with some vegetables and gari.

Cook 3 cups of black beans and 3 cups of black-eyed peas according to package directions. Once cooked, add to
bowl with bell pepper mixture.
Assist Little Chef with cutting, measuring and mixing, as needed.
Dice yellow bell peppers and 1 red onion.
Chop 1/4 cup of olives & 2 cups of celery.
Add peppers, onion and olives to a large bowl.
Measure 1/2 cup of sunflower seeds, 3 tbsp. of vinegar, 1.5 tbsp. of olive oil, and 1/2 tsp. of fennel seeds and add to bowl. Stir until well mixed.
Add salt and pepper to taste and stir again.
Chop the onion and green bell pepper.

Place 2 lbs. of ground beef, 1/2 chopped bell pepper, 1/2 chopped onion, 2 teaspoons salt, 2 tsp. of black peppercorns, and 4 smashed garlic cloves in large pot. Add enough cold water to cover ingredients by 2 inches.
Bring mixture to boil over medium ­high heat, then, immediately reduce heat to medium ­low and simmer until beef is cooked through, about 15 minutes.

Strain beef in sink, and remove and discard bell pepper pieces, onion
pieces, peppercorns, and garlic. Cool 10 minutes.

Place all the beef, bell peppers, and onion in food processor and pulse
until mixture is finely chopped. Transfer to large mixing bowl
Melt 4 tbsp. of butter in large skillet over medium ­high heat. Add beef and cook,stirring, until beginning to crisp and dry out, about 15 minutes.
Squeeze 1 lime over beef and toss to combine. Season to taste with salt.
Place 1 cup of sugar and  1/4 cup of water in a heavy­bottomed saucepan and stir to dissolve the sugar.
In a large bowl beat together the 4 eggs, can of condensed milk, 2 cups of whole milk, 1/2 tsp. of vanilla and 1⁄2 cup of sugar until smooth. Pour into the cake pan.

Place over medium heat and boil the sugar, without stirring, until it starts to turn
honey brown. It will take around 10 to 15 minutes
Remove the caramelized sugar from the heat and pour it onto a 9­inch cake pan.
Fill the baking pan with enough warm water to come about 2/3 of the way up sides of the containers.

Place in the oven and cook until a knife inserted into the center of the custard
comes out clean. May take 45 minutes to an hour.
Remove the custard(s) from the water bath and chill well.

Run a knife around the edges of the custard, invert over a serving dish and
serve.
Cook 1 1/2 cup of rice. (it should be prepared 1 day in advance).
For the Beans: Spread the 16 oz. bag of beans out in a rimmed baking sheet. Pick out any debris and broken beans.
Transfer the beans to a colander and rinse under cold running water

Place rinsed beans in a large pot and cover with cold water; water should be
covering the beans about 3 inches.
Let the beans soak for about 30 minutes.
After the beans have soaked, bring them to a boil over high heat.
Reduce heat to medium and summer beans for 30 minutes.
Turn off heat, and cover the beans, and let them rest for 1 hour.
Bring beans back up to boil over high heat.
Add two teaspoons of salt and 7 cloves of garlic, peeled
Reduce heat to a medium and let it simmer until beans are tender. It will take about 30 to 60 minutes.

For the Rice: Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large heavy­bottomed saucepan
over medium heat until its shimmering.
Add 2/3 of a finely chopped onion and cook, stirring, until softened and translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add the Rice and cook, stirring, until grains are shiny and evenly coated with oil, this will take 2­3 minutes.
Add 3 cups of water or broth and 1 1⁄2 teaspoons of salt, increase heat to high, and bring to a boil.
Place a 1/2 green bell pepper on top of the rice.
Boil the rice without stirring until most of the liquid has evaporated and you can see small bubbles bursting on the surface of the rice.
Immediately reduce the heat to the lowest setting, cover, and cook for 15 minutes.
Remove and discard the bell pepper.
Once the rice is done, fluff the rice with chopsticks or a fork, the let cool and refrigerate for 1 day.
For the Gallopinto: Heat remaining 2 tablespoons of oil in a large saucepan over medium­high heat until its shimmering.
Add the remaining onion and cook, stirring, until softened and translucent, takes about 5 minutes.
Add rice and 2 cups of beans to the skillet and cook, stirring until rice is evenly coated.
Continue to cook, stirring, to allow flavors to meld and the mixture to become slightly crisp, takes about 10 minutes.
Cover and cook over low heat for an additional 10 minutes.
Cut ends from 3 plantains and peel them.
Diagonally cut plantains into 1/2­ inch­ thick slices.

In a large nonstick skillet heat 1/3 cup oil over moderately high heat until hot but
not smoking and sauté plantains in batches, without crowding, until golden 
brown, 1 to 2 minutes on each side, adding more oil to skillet as necessary.
With a spatula transfer plantains as sautéed to paper towels to drain.

Wash the 2-4 pounds of yam or cocoyam or plantain.
Peel off the covering before or after boiling.
Place inside a large pot and add 4 cups of water.
Bring to a boil for about 20-30 minutes or until soft and tender.

Put the boiled yams or plantain or cocoyam into a food processor.
Add 2 tbsp. of margarine/butter, and salt and pepper to taste.
Allow this to blend into a smooth thick dough.
Roll the dough into balls and serve with your favorite soup.
Heat 8 cups (1/2 gallon) of milk in a large pot on the stove until it reaches 180 degrees, stirring constantly. Milk will burn fast, so stir regularly and keep a watchful eye on the thermometer.
Chop 1/2 head of  lettuce, 2 medium tomatoes, and 2 avocados, then put in their own separate bowls.
Grate 8 oz. of cheese and put it in a bowl. It can be of of your choice: cheddar, cotija, queso fresco, or monterey jack.
Heat 2 15 oz. cans of refried beans by draining the water from the can, then add them to the pan with a little water, mash them as you heat them. Keep the beans on warm.
Pour enough canola oil into a frying pan so that you have a quarter inch layer of oil. Heat the oil on medium high heat until sizzling hot, but not smoking.
Fry the tortillas one at a time in the oil until each side is golden brown, around 30 seconds to one minute. Bubbles should form in the tortilla, otherwise the oil is not hot enough.
Place the tortilla on a paper towel-lined plate, to absorb the excess oil. Sprinkle with a little salt to taste.
Once it reaches 180 degrees, transfer the milk to an oven-safe dish and allow it to cool to between 105-110-degrees. Turn on the oven light to allow the bulb to start heating the oven.

In a side dish, combine 2.5 tablespoons of yogurt with 2 tablespoons of milk, and mix it together. Once the milk you heated has cooled to between 105-110 degrees, add the milk-yogurt mixture to the heated milk. The cultures in the existing yogurt will begin to convert the whole 8 cups of milk into yogurt!

Cover the oven-safe dish filled with all ingredients, and wrap the entire container in dish towels. Place this in the oven with the oven light on for 7-9 hours. The heat from the bulb is enough to help the cultures convert the plain milk into yogurt.

You’ll rely on cheesecloth to help separate and thicken the yogurt further. My method has been to line a fine strainer with four damp layers of cheesecloth and allow the remaining moisture in the yogurt to separate itself, with the help of gravity, into a separate bowl. Food-sterile cheesecloth is available at most grocery stores, and you can also find it in the food section of many craft stores (use those coupons for added savings). This step can take upwards of an hour, so exercise patience. Help speed up the process by mixing the yogurt and pressing it against the cheesecloth with a spatula. The liquid is inclined to rise to the surface.
Drain and rinse the can of black beans
Help or aid the little chef cut up the vegetables
Extract all the mango flesh, including that from the skins and the central seed.

With the help of the Big Chef chop the red bell pepper, red onion,
zucchini, 2 avocados, and small handful of cilantro leaves.
Transfer all of the chopped vegetables into a large serving bowl and lightly toss them
Squeeze the juice out of the two limes into the small mixing bowl
Add 2 tbsp. of olive oil, 1/4 tsp. of garlic powder, 1/2 tsp. of salt, and 1/4 tsp. of black pepper to the mixing bowl and whisk together to create the dressing
Pour the dressing on top of the veggies in the large mixing bowl and lightly toss all together
Put the flesh in a blender with the 1/4 cup of Cointreau/orange liqueur and 2 cups of heavy cream and blend for 30-45 seconds.
Pour into either a large serving bowl or individual dessert glasses.
Before serving, decorate as desired with sprigs of fresh mint and fresh fruit.
Soaking the bread (crust removed) in water and squeeze well to remove the excess water.
In a food processor add the bread, grated onion and the tarama. Blend until the ingredients are mashed (like a pulp).
Add half lemon juice and blend a little more. Pour in the olive oil slowly while blending.
Blend until the oil is incorporated and the mixture is smooth and creamy. Add some more lemon juice if you prefer, and blend again.
In a food processor, combine the 15 oz. can of tomatoes (with juices), 1/4 cup of cilantro, 1/4 cup of diced onions, 1 garlic mashed garlic clove, and 1/2 tsp. of salt; puree until smooth.
Transfer the sauce to a small skillet and simmer over medium heat until slightly thickened, about 10 minutes. Cover and keep warm over low heat.
In a large skillet over medium-high heat, cook the 5 oz. of chorizo until browned, about 5 minutes. Add to the sauce and cover again.

Add 1 tablespoon vegetable oil to the fat in the skillet. Place a tortilla in the skillet and cook until light golden but not crisp, about 30 seconds. Flip and cook for 30 seconds more. Transfer to an individual plate. Cook the remaining tortillas, adding a bit more oil to the pan if necessary.
Heat the 16 oz. can of refried beans, if using, in a small saucepan. Spread the beans on the tortillas.

Add another tablespoon of oil to the skillet. Working in batches, crack the eggs into the skillet. Cook until the bottoms are set and the edges golden, 1 to 2 minutes. Turn the heat to medium-low, cover and cook until set, about 1 minute more.
Place 1 egg on each tortilla and spoon the warm sauce over the eggs. Sprinkle with the avocado, cheese and additional cilantro. Top with a dollop of sour cream.
Prepare the 6 prawns, by removing shells, heads and tails and picking out the spinal cord (dark thread running along top of back) with the tip of a knife.
Grease and flour one 9x13 inch baking pan.

Boil for 5 minutes in salt water.
Leave to cool thoroughly in water, then remove.
Sift 2 cups of flour and 1 tsp. of baking powder together and set aside in a mixing bowl.
Cream 1/2 cup of butter or margarine and 1 cup sugar together until fluffy. Add 5 eggs and the 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract; beat well.
Add the flour mixture to the butter mixture 2 tablespoons at a time; mix until well blended.
Dice the onion. Slice the bell pepper into rings.
Put the 3 fish fillets in the same water, as soon as the water starts to boil, turn down heat.
Help to add ingredients to the pot and stir as needed.
Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 30 minutes. Pierce cake several times with a fork and then let cool.
Blend the 4 garlic cloves with 2 tbsps olive oil in blender. Set garlic and olive oil mixture aside. (Don’t wash the blender.)
Combine the 2 cups of  whole milk, 14 oz. can of condensed milk, and can of evaporated milk together in a bowl.
Blend 2 1/2 cups of cilantro and 1 cup of broth (or water) in blender.
Put remaining 2 tbsps olive oil in pot and then add diced onion, peppers, black pepper, cumin and salt. Sauté until onions are translucent.
Pour over the top of the cooled cake
Add rice to pot and sauté for 2­3 more minutes.
Add garlic and oil mixture and stir to combine.
Quickly add remaining 3 cups broth, cider vinegar and peas. Stir again, lower the temperature and simmer for 12­20 mins.
Whip 1.5 cups of whipping cream, the remaining 1 cup of the sugar, and the remaining 1 teaspoon vanilla together until thick.
Spread over the top of cake. Be sure to keep the cake refrigerated, and enjoy!
Drain, rinse and dry grape leaves. Place off to the side.

In a large bowl mix ground round, Lamb, salt, pepper, minced parsley, onion chopped, crushed or pressed garlic and Tabuli (or rice); mix well. Lay out one grape leaf stem up, place about 1 rounded tablespoon meat mixture near stem. Fold stem up over meat mixture fold one side leaf over mixture, fold top over then roll the rest but not tight. Place in at least 1 gal pot, and continue until all leaves are filled and snug in pot.
Cover all stuffed leaves with chicken broth adding water if you don’t have enough broth, more broth if you have it on hand (you can use just water if you want).
Bring the broth to a boil then turn heat to low, simmer and cook covered until tender (pierced with a fork) about 30 minutes. Then remove about 1 quart of broth from pot and let cool down a little.
In another bowl beat 4 eggs until frothy adding slowly juice from lemon. Take the warmed broth and add to the egg mixture slowly a 1/2 ladle at a time still beating the egg mixture.
After all broth is mixed with egg & lemon slowly add to pot on stove. Cover the pot and turn flame off. Let sit for about 10 minutes then serve.
Peel the 2 avocados. Cut flesh into cubes. Sprinkle with the juice of 1 lemon to prevent them from turning brown. Put aside.
Peel 2 grapefruits with a knife. Separate segments.
Squeeze or juice one half of the grapefruit and any flesh or pith left over.
Cut pineapple into small pieces to make 1/4 cup
Cut the 3 papayas in half lengthwise and remove seeds.
Prepare a 9 inch by 4 inch loaf pan by lightly greasing the sides. Cut a piece of wax paper or parchment to fit the bottom for quick removal.
Wash 3 tomatoes and 1/4 cup of cilantro.
Mix together dry ingredients (flour, sugar, baking soda, cinnamon & cloves) in a bowl.
In a separate bowl, quickly mix 1 egg. Spoon in and mix the honey, coffee, and oil.
Heat up the frying pan on medium high heat
Quickly fold in the dry ingredients - mixing just enough to combine without toughening the batter.
Place the three whole tomatoes in the pan and cook until the skin begins to break and split apart.
Fold into pan and bake for 30 minutes. Use a toothpick to see if center is done.
Remove tomatoes from heat and dice the tomatoes.
Dice the onion, and chop cilantro. Cut two slices of the pickled jalapeño pepper and finely chop the slices.
Put tomatoes, onions, cilantro, and jalapeños in a bowl.
Add 1 tsp. of salt, 1/2 tsp. of minced garlic, and juice half a lemon into the bowl.
Remove flesh with a teaspoon, leaving about 1 cm on skin.

Over high heat, bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add the 4 potatoes; cook
until tender when poked with the tines of a fork, about 10 minutes. Remove the 
potatoes from the water and transfer to a cutting board to cool. When the 
potatoes are room temperature, give to Little Chef to peel and cut.

After potatoes have been cooked and cooled, peel the potatoes and cut into 1⁄4”
slices. Set aside.
Peel hard­boiled egg and cut into 4 sections.

In a blender, add the cubed queso blanco, evaporated milk, aji amarillo paste,
ground turmeric and saltine crackers. Turn the blender on medium, and slowly 
drizzle in the oil until it reaches the desired consistency. Salt to taste ­some 
brands of cheese have more salt than others and no salt may be needed.

Take the 5 lettuce leaves and arrange them on a large plate or platter. Fan the
sliced potatoes on top of the lettuce. Pour sauce over potatoes. Garnish with 
eggs and olives.

Arrange all ingredients in papaya halves.
Top with a prawns tail to decorate.
Help Little Chef to pour the sauce, if necessary.

Mix mayonnaise, Tabasco and grapefruit juice to taste.
Drizzle over papaya halves.
Chill for 15 minutes before serving, with rest of sauce in a small jug.
Heat the grill to high. Brown the beef in a deep ovenproof frying pan over a high heat for 5 minutes.
Prick the eggplant with a fork, then microwave on High for 3-5 minutes until soft. Mix the yogurt, egg and parmesan together, then add a little seasoning.
Stir the tomatoes, purée and potatoes in with the beef with some seasoning and heat through. Smooth the surface of the beef mixture with the back of a spoon.
Slice the cooked eggplant and arrange on top. Pour the yogurt mixture over the eggplant smooth out evenly, then grill until the topping has set and turned golden.
Peel the 3 plantains. Cut them into small chunks. Put into a large, deep mixing bowl.

In a medium bowl, combine the ground lamb, salt, pepper and oregano leaves with your hands, mixing until all of the seasonings have been evenly distributed. Cover and refrigerate for at least 1 hour, or overnight.

Preheat oven to 300 degrees F. Place the lamb mixture in the bowl of a food processor and add the onion, garlic and bacon. Process until a smooth puree is formed, 30 seconds to 1 minute, scraping down the sides of the bowl as necessary.

Line a rimmed baking sheet with aluminum foil. With moistened hands, shape the lamb mixture into a rectangle about 8 inches long and 5 inches wide. Use an instant-read thermometer check the center of the loaf, stop baking once it reaches to 155 degrees F. it is about. 30 to 35 minutes. Remove from the oven and allow to rest for 15 minutes.

Put the oven rack to the highest position and preheat broiler. Cut the loaf of lamb meat crosswise into very thin pieces. Lay the strips on a rimmed baking sheet lined with aluminum foil and broil until edges are browned and crispy, 2 to 4 minutes. Be sure to keep an eye on it, as the broiler works quickly!
Mash into a thick paste with your fingers or an electric blender (add 2-4 tablespoons water for smoother blending).
Measure ingredients and give to Big Chef.
Gently heat 1/4 cup of corn oil in a small skillet and add 2 tsp. of turmeric.
Gently heat the corn oil in a small skillet and add the turmeric.

Put the 6 cups of milk in a medium sized pot with the 2 orange peel strips, cinnamon stick, and a pinch of salt. Bring to boil and add the rinsed rice. Cook on low heat for about 1 hour  and  15  minutes,  or  until  the  rice  is  tender.  Stir  occasionally,  increase frequency of stirring as the cooking time increases.
Remove the cinnamon sticks and orange peel from the rice.
Add the 1/2 cup of sugar or panela and 1/2 cup raisins, cook for 15­-20 minutes, or until it is tender and creamy. Stir frequently.
Add  the  0.5 cups condensed  milk  and  vanilla  to  the  arroz  con  leche  and  stir  well. Remove from heat.
Scoop into small cups or bowls for serving.
Sprinkle with cinnamon or chocolate and serve.

Stir well.
Remove from heat and blend into plantain mixture (which should be thick yet soft enough to pour).
Warm up the bread either in the microwave (30 seconds), on the stovetop or in the oven.
If it is too soft, add amounts of rice flour (a tablespoon at a time); if too stiff, add small amounts of water.

Grease a standard loaf pan.
Pour the plantain mixture into the pan.
Bake for 1 hour or until cooked and firm.
Remove from the oven and let stand for 15-20 minutes before turning it on a wire rack.
Remove the spinach stems and basil stems from the leaves and discard.
Steam the spinach and basil in 3 tablespoons of water, until wilted.
Cook pasta in boiling water until al dente (do not add salt as queso fresco is already salted.
Place cooled spinach and basil mixture, cheese and milk in a food processor and process to a thick purée.
Once Big Chef has finished blending items in food processor, pour them over top of pasta and stir until well combined.
Halve vanilla pod lengthwise and scrape seeds out.
Toast almonds in a dry pan on medium heat for a few minutes, tossing occasionally.
Remove from heat and let cool.
Add 4 tablespoons of water to a small pan on high heat.
Add 1 tsp. of sugar, vanilla pod seeds and empty pod seeds and squeeze juice from 4 tangerines.
Leave ticking away from 5-8 minutes or until thickened and reduced to a soup.
Meanwhile peel and finely slice the remaining 4 tangerines and arrange them nicely on a platter.
Roughly chop and scatter over the almonds and mint leaves.
Use a sharp knife to scrape over a few shavings of chocolate and serve.
Boil the potatoes with some salt until they are tender when punctured with a fork.
Slice the 2 tomatoes in small sizes
Combine with salt, white ground pepper, key lime juice, aji or chili and oil, quantity to your liking
Mix tuna fish with 2 cups of mayonnaise, and the diced onions.
Spread potato mixture on a thin rectangular sheet of plastic. Spread the filling
Top with tomatoes, sliced avocado and roll using the plastic to help form a round loaf.

Place the pieces of fish with 1/2 diced onion, 1 cup diced tomatoes, chili,
salt, Tabasco, and oregano in a non-reactive dish.
Cover with lime and lemon juice.

Let sit covered in the refrigerator for an hour, then stir,
making sure more of the fish gets exposed to the acidic lime and lemon 
juices. Let sit for several hours, giving time for the flavors to blend.

Make a paste by combining the 1 1/2 tbsp of crushed garlic and 1/2 tsp of salt.
Whisk together the garlic paste, 2 tsp of rice vinegar, 2 tbsp soy sauce, 2 tbsp canola oil, 
2 tsp cumin, and 1.5 tsp ground black pepper.

Place the 1 1/2 lb steak in one bowl & the onions in another.
Divide the marinade between the 2 bowls & let set in the refrigerator for at least an hour.

Pour a small amount of oil in a wok, and turn on
medium heat. Once the oil is hot add the steak with marinade and cook 
until brown. Add the 15oz. of tomato and simmer for a few minutes.

Add the 2 jalapeño, cilantro, and onions with marinade
to the wok, slowly stirring until well blended. Simmer for 5 more 
minutes.

As the ingredients are cooking in the wok, sprinkle
the potatoes with paprika, and fry in a separate pan. Once done add to 
the other ingredients.
Cut the 2 chickens into small pieces.
Place the chicken, onion, tomatoes, ginger, garlic and bay leaf in a heavy casserole dish.
Cover with a thick, tight-fitting lid that will not let any steam escape.
Put the casserole on medium to high heat.
Turn heat down to low when ingredients start to simmer.
Remove casserole from heat and without removing lid, shake casserole well to stir up contents so that it cooks evenly.
This salad can be layered in a clear glass bowl or in a 9x13 pan.
Chop the onions, celery, green pepper, and lettuce.

Cook the 4 yellow potatoes in salted water until tender
when pierced with a fork. Let cool, peel, cut into quarters, and set aside.

Place the 4 slices of bread in a small bowl and pour the
3/4 cups of evaporated milk over it to soak. Set aside.

Place the 1 1/2 lbs of chicken breasts in a pot with the chicken
stock (4 cups) , and bring to a simmer. Cook for 10-15 minutes, until chicken is 
just barely cooked through.
Set chicken aside to cool. Strain broth and reserve 2 cups.

Remove stems and seeds from the 3 Aji peppers. In a
blender, process peppers with the vegetable oil until smooth.

Sauté the garlic and onions with the puréed peppers
and oil, until the onions are soft and golden. Remove from heat and let cool.
Shred the cooled chicken into bite-size pieces.

In a blender or food processor, process
evaporated milk and bread mixture with the nuts (3 tbsp) and parmesan cheese (3 tbsp, grated)
until smooth. Add the cooked onion mixture and process briefly.

Return onion mixture to pan, and add 1 1/2 cups of
the reserved chicken stock. Bring to a low simmer, and stir in the 
chicken. Heat until warmed through, adding more chicken stock if 
sauce is too thick.

To prepare beef, combine first 7 ingredients
in a large bowl; toss well. Cover and chill 3 hours.

To prepare fiery rub, combine parsley, 1 teaspoon
salt, 1 teaspoon paprika, 1/2 teaspoon pepper, and 1/4 teaspoon turmeric.

Remove beef from bowl; thread beef onto each of
skewers. Press fiery rub onto beef. Place kebabs on grill rack coated 
with cooking spray; grill 6 minutes or until desired degree of doneness, 
turning once. Serve with Roasted Yellow Pepper Sauce.
Arrange the cucumber, zucchini, and onion in alternating layers.
Mix 1/3 cup of vinegar and 1/4 cup of sugar dissolved in 1/2 cup of hot water. Add 1/2 tbsp. of salt, 1 tsp. of pepper, and a pinch crushed red pepper. Add a couple ice cubes to chill.
Drain any water formed from cucumbers before adding the dressing.
Allow vegetables to marinate in the dressing for at least 1 hour before serving.

Place the 1/2 cup of raisins in a small bowl and cover
boiling water. Let them plump in the water for 10 minutes.
Sauté the chopped onions, garlic, and 2 peppers in the 3tbsp olive oil until soft and fragrant.

Add the 1 tsp cumin and 1 tbsp paprika and cook 2 minutes more,
stirring. Add the ground beef and cook until browned.

Drain the raisins and add them to the ground beef.
Add the beef broth and simmer for 10 to 15 minutes more, or until most 
of the liquid is gone.

Stir in the hard-boiled egg and the black olives with
fork. Season mixture with salt and pepper to taste.

Remove beef mixture from heat and let cool for 5
minutes. Stir in 1/2 cup crumbled queso fresco.

While the beef is cooking, bring a large pot of salted
water to a rolling boil. Slice the tops off of the peppers and reserve. 
Clean the inside of the peppers, removing the seeds.

Cook the peppers in the boiling water until bright red
and just tender, about 8 - 10 minutes. Drain peppers and blot dry with 
paper towels.

Fill each bell pepper with some of seasoned ground
beef mixture. Top with remaining queso fresco.

Place the peppers on a baking sheet, with the tops
alongside them (but not covering the filling). Bake the peppers for 10 to 
15 minutes, or until the cheese is melted and the filling is heated through.
After the dressing and before the bacon make sure to refrigerate for 30 minutes.
Cook the bacon & set aside to cool & chop before using.

Layer your salad as followed:
lettuce
green peppers
onions 
celery 
peas
dressing
bacon
cheese

Mix together 1 1/2 tbsp Shaoxing wine, 1 tbsp light soy sauce, salt and 1 tsp cornstarch, to make marinade.
Marinade the chicken.
Set aside.

Heat about 1 tbsp of cooking oil in a wok. Once hot, turn the heat to low.
Gently place the cashew nuts into the wok, stir-frying briskly.
Once you see the cashew nuts begin to brown, remove them form the oil and drain (another method: roast the cashews in an oven or buy roasted cashews).

Mix 1 tsp light soy sauce, 1 tsp dark soy sauce, 1.5 tbsp sugar, 1 tsp corn starch, 2 tsp black vinegar, 1.5 tbsp water and tiny dash of sesame oil, to make the sauce.
Taste sauce, add more sugar, soy sauce or sesame oil depending on your preference.
In a bowl, combine the 1 1/4 cups of flour, 3/4 cups of sugar, 1/2 cup of cornmeal, 1/4 tsp. of salt, and 1 tsp. of  baking powder.
Combine 1 egg, 1 tsp. vanilla, and 3/4 cup of sugar in another bowl.
Slowly add the dry ingredients into the other bowl and mix well.
Drop dough in spoonfuls onto a greased cookie sheet.
Help little chef drop dough into spoonfuls onto a greased cookie sheet.
Soak the 0.5 cups tapioca in the 1 cup (250 ml) of water in a small bowl for 30 minutes.

While the tapioca is soaking, make the rice balls. Combine the rice flour  with  the  1/2  cup (125  ml)  of  water  in  a  large  bowl  and  mix  until  a  dough  comes together. The dough should be slightly tacky and you should be able to form the dough into a large sphere. If the dough is too dry and crumbly, slowly add more water, one tablespoon at a time, until the dough can hold its shape.

Form  the  rice  flour  balls  by  pinching  off  about  a  teaspoon  of  the dough and rolling it between your palms to form a small sphere about 1/2 in (1.25 cm) in diameter. You should be able to make about 20 small rice balls from the dough. Cover the rice balls with a damp paper towel and set aside.
Drain the tapioca in a fine ­mesh sieve set over the sink and rinse with cold running water. Allow the tapioca to continue draining over the sink.

To make the porridge, combine the coconut milk with the remaining 1/2 cup (125 ml) of water in a large saucepan. Stir in the salt and the sugar and bring  the mixture to a boil over high heat. Reduce the heat to low, and then add the rice  balls  to  the  saucepan  and  gently  simmer,  stirring  to  ensure  the rice balls don’t stick to each other. Continue simmering the rice balls until they are cooked through and become pleasantly  chewy, 3–5 minutes. As the rice balls simmer, they will become firmer and expand slightly.

Increase the heat to high and return the liquid to a boil. As soon as the liquid boils, turn off the heat and stir in the drained tapioca pearls. Continue to stir until the tapioca becomes tender and translucent, 2–3 minutes. If the porridge becomes too thick for your liking, you can thin it out with more water or coconut milk.
Stir in the mangoes and serve the porridge warm.

Heat about 2 tbsp of cooking oil in your wok again.
Once hot, turn heat to medium and add the dried chili peppers and fry till aromatic. You should be able to smell the spiciness in the air.
Add the ginger, garlic and white portions of the green onions.
Turn heat to medium-low and saute until fragrance comes out.
Place strawberries in a blender; top with 2 tablespoons sugar. Pour 1 cup water over sugared strawberries.
Blend until strawberry chunks transform into juice.
Combine strawberry juice, 6 cups water, 1 cup sugar, and lemon juice in a large pitcher; stir until blended. Chill before serving.
Add marinated chicken cubes into the wok and turn heat to medium-high, stir-frying briskly to coat the chicken in the aromatic oil. Do this for 3-5 minutes.
Add in the previously fried cashews.
Turn heat to high and stir to mix well.
Add in the prepared sauce and stir-fry to coat the chicken well in the end.
Saute ground turkey in the pot sprayed with Pam.
Spice turkey with season salt, pepper, cumin, garlic, and a little chili powder. Begin to brown.
Add vegetables and saute for 2 - 3 minutes.
Add can of green chiles and saute another 2 - 3 minutes.
Add 4 cups of chicken stock and 4 cups of water, and bouillon, and bring to a boil.
Add a little more seasonings if desired.
Bring back to a boil, and then simmer for approximately 20 minutes or until the rice is tender.
Rinse the salted salmon so not as salty.
Mince the onions to smaller pieces.
Chop green onions into small pieces.
Mix altogether and add Hawaiian salt to flavor.
Cover in a bowl and let it sit for a couple hours.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Help or aid little chef with measuring.
Sift flour, salt and baking powder together.
Blend oil, whole eggs, guava juice, vanilla, and coloring into a bowl.
Add dry ingredients. Mix at medium speed for 5 minutes.
Whip egg whites until they are triple in volume. Slowly add the sugar and cream of tartar. Whip mixture until soft peaks form.
Fold guava mixture into egg white mixture and mix till smooth.
Pour batter into pans and bake for 30 minutes
Remove from oven and turn cake over onto a rack immediately. Let cool with pan in place.
Chop strawberries. Grind Cinnamon. Grind nutmeg. Mash banana. Zest lemon. Chop walnuts.
Mix strawberries, 2Tbsp. sugar. Let sit for 15 minutes, until strawberries give off juices.
Mix together flour, cinnamon, baking soda, nutmeg and salt.
Whisk banana, eggs, oil, cup sugar, strawberries and lemon zest in large bowl.
Mix dry ingredients into wet ingredients until combined. Do not over mix.
Line muffin pan with muffin liners.
Scoop batter evenly into muffin cups.
Bake for about 20 minutes or until toothpick comes out with a few crumbs but not wet.
Let cool on a rack to room temperature.
Wash and soak 1 cup of brown rice for 1 hour.
Wash, peel and cut the mushrooms.

Place the rice in a rice cooker.
Add 8 cups of soup stock, 2 tbsp of scallions and 1 cup of mushrooms.
Chop the duck into smaller pieces or remove the meat from the bigger bones.
When the porridge is done, add the duck pieces and cook further for 20 minutes.
Sprinkle 1 1/2 tbsp of ginger before serving.
Lay the sheet of nori on the wooden or bamboo mat with the smooth side facing down.
Fill a bowl with water for your hands.
Wet hands and grab some rice to cover the nori with a layer of sushi rice.
Cut long strips of cucumber and place them in the center of the rice.
Roll into long sushi roll using the wooden/bamboo mat to aid (it takes a little getting used to, but it's fairly easy).
Cut into smaller pieces as desired.
Put the lentils, bulgur wheat, onion and the chicken stock or water together in a pan.
Bring to boil and then on a low heat simmer, stirring occasionally for about 30 minutes or until the lentils and bulgur are tender.

Stir in the butter (or olive oil), dried mint, the red pepper flakes, Turkish hot pepper paste (optional) and the tomato paste. Mix well and simmer for another 10-15 minutes, until the soup has a creamy consistency.
Add the lemon juice and more water if necessary, then season with salt and pepper.
Heat 2 Tbsp. olive oil on medium heat in a pot. Add the diced onions and cook slowly for about 10-12 minutes. Add minced garlic and cook one minute more.
Crushing tomatoes by hand. Cut any hard stem ends or stray tomato skins.

Add tomatoes to the pot with the onions, Add chicken

stock, bay leaves, and dried oregano. Heat to a simmer and reduce heat 

to maintain a low simmer. Cook for 20 minutes. As you are cooking the 

tomato soup base, prepare the bread croutons in the next step.

Heat 2 Tbsp. olive oil in a sauté pan on medium heat.

Once the oil is hot, add the cubed bread to the pan. Toss to coat with the 

oil and spread the cubes out in a single layer. Let sit in pan without moving 

until one side is golden browned, then turn over to another side. Once at 

least two sides have browned, remove from heat.

Once the tomatoes have cooked for 20 minutes, add the

lightly browned croutons to the soup. Cook for 5 minutes. Turn off the heat 

and cover the pan. Let sit for 10-15 minutes.
Remove the bay leaves. Use an immersion blender to roughly purée the soup (about half of the soup, leave some chunky bits).
Add 48 oz cherries, with their juice, to a 4-quart saucepan.
Add 1/2 tsp salt, 1 cinnamon stick, and 1/2 inch thick lemon slice.
Bring to a boil, reduce heat to medium-low, and simmer until cherries are soft, about 5 minutes.
In a small bowl, whisk together 8 oz sour cream and 1⁄4 cup of hot cherry liquid from pan.
Remove pan from heat; stir in sour cream mixture. Chill the soup.
Place one cup of rice on one hand, make a dent in the center, and put in the filling of your choice in it: Umeboshi, Shake, Katsuo, or Tuna.

Finely chop 2 garlic cloves.
Peel 1 1/2 lbs russet potatoes.
Beat 1 large egg.

Place 1/2 oz dried porcini mushrooms in a small bowl.
Add 3/4 cup hot water and let stand for 45 minutes. Strain through fine mesh strainer, reserving soaking liquid.
Coarsely chop porcini.
Finely grate 1 1/2 lbs potatoes by hand (or processor with help from Big Chef).

Transfer potatoes to a large bowl. 
Add enough cold water to cover, and let stand for 5 minutes.

Drain potatoes.
Wrap in dry kitchen towel; twist ends to squeeze out as much liquid as possible (Have Big Chef help as needed).
Heat 1 tbsp olive oil in a nonstick skillet over medium-high heat.
Add chopped porcini and 2 garlic cloves, finely chopped. Saute for 2 minutes.

Add reserved porcini soaking liquid and 1 tsp Hungarian hot paprika.
Cook until liquid evaporates, stirring frequently, about 3 minutes.

Season with salt and pepper.
Set aside to cool.
(Note: Mushroom mixture can be made 1 day ahead. Cover and refrigerate until ready to use).

Place potatoes in a large bowl.
Mix in 1 beaten egg, 2 tbsp fresh breadcrumbs, 1 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp black pepper.
Give potato and mushroom mixture to Big Chef to cook.
Heat 6 tbsp olive oil in a cast-iron skillet over medium-high heat until hot, but not smoking.
Working in batches, drop in potato mixture by 1/4 cupfuls into hot oil, spacing apart.
Using spatula, flatten each into 4-inch rounds and cook until crisp and brown. About 4 minutes per side.
Using slotted spatula, transfer latkes to paper towels to drain.

Add more oil to skillet as necessary and allow oil to get hot before adding more potato mixture.
Repeat until all of the potato mixture has been used.
Take pistachios out of the shell, and make sure to grind into powder.
Cut the spinach into small pieces.
Place the couscous in a bowl and add the boiling stock.
Leave for 5 minutes until couscous has softened and liquid is absorbed
Stir in melted butter, raisins, lemon rind and nuts.

Cut 28.2 oz veal into 1 1/2-2 inch cubes.
Cut 4 artichoke hearts in half (400 g can artichoke hearts).

Chop 1 onion, 1.4 oz. butter and parsley to serve.
Slice 1 large carrot.
Crush 2 cloves of garlic.
Pour the dressing in and toss.
Heat 1 tbsp oil in a large frying pan over medium heat.

Cook veal in batches for 3-4 minutes until browned.
Transfer to a plate.
With adult supervision add remaining 1 tbsp oil into the same pan and saute 1 chopped onion, 1 sliced carrot and 2 chopped garlic cloves until soft and lightly golden, about 4-5 minutes.
After all is mixed refrigerate, covered, until ready to serve.
Add 2 tbsp brandy (orange juice) and cook until reduced by half.

Add 1 tbsp paprika.
Cook, stirring for 1 minute.
Return meat to pan with 1 cup beef stock.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to very low and simmer very slowly. Cover for an hour or until meat is very tender (test a piece of meat and see if it will pull apart using two forks).
Remove lid, increase heat slightly and simmer, uncovered for 10-15 minutes to thicken sauce slightly.
Remove fry pan temporarily from heat and reduce stove setting to low.

Place 1/4 cup sour cream into a small bowl. Add a serving spoon of sauce from the fry pan.
Whisk in thoroughly until there is no sign of curdling.

Add another spoonful of sauce.
Whisk again until smooth.
Add sour cream mixture to the fry pan and mix well.
Return pan to heat and reheat gently.

Meanwhile: Cook 13.2 oz. fettuccine in a large pot of salted boiling water.
Drain well.
Place 1.4 oz. chopped butter, salt, pepper and 1 tsp caraway seeds (optional) into a large mixing bowl.
Add hot, drained fettuccine noodles and toss until butter is melted.
The syrup is done when you see the bottom of the pan after passing a spoon through it.
Sprinkle the parsley on the soup for garnish before serving.
Serve after Little Chef has added the parsley gamish
Cover and simmer on low for about two hours.
It is done when the sauce is thickened and the meat is tender and falls apart.
Chop 1 large onion, 3 cloves garlic, dice 14.5 oz tomatoes (if not using a can).
Cut 2-3 lbs whole chicken into pieces.
Heat 2 tbsp bacon grease in a large skillet over medium heat.
Add 1 large chopped onion, 3 chopped cloves garlic, 1 tsp red pepper flakes and 3 tbsp paprika to the skillet.
Stir the ingredients together and saute until the onions are translucent.
Add chicken pieces and pour 1 cup water all over.
Cook over medium heat for 1 hour, adding water if necessary.
Stir in 14.5 oz tomatoes, reserving the liquid.

Stir liquid into a medium bowl with 2 tbsp flour and 8 oz sour cream.
Mix until well blended.
Place the little pinky size smoked sausage link  in the indent and fold the kolaches  over the sausage and seal.
Bake for 10- 12 minutes or until golden brown.
Wrap the rice around the filling and form into triangle or ball shape. Wrap the rice ball with a piece of Nori seaweed.
Cut potatoes in medium wedges and cook in salted water until easily pierced with a knife.
Put cooked potatoes into a bowl, while still hot, squeeze lime over them and stir. Set aside to cool.
Meanwhile chop up celery and green onion.
Once cooled add the mayonnaise, celery, green onions, peas, raisins, and carrots.
Stir until mixed, but do not over stir or potatoes will become mushy.
To make the sauce add a 1/4 cup of mayonnaise in a small bowl and add 2 tbsp. soy sauce. Mix together until slightly brown
Add salt and pepper to taste.
Before you start, make sure your hands are dry in order to keep nori dry and crispy. Place the seaweed on the palm of your hand (shiny side down) and put a thin layer of rice on the nori.
Dab on a little of the mayonnaise mixture on the rice and place fillings on top.
Refrigerate for at least 1 hour to let the flavors meld.
Place fillings (shiso leaf, cucumber, raw fish and daikon radish sprouts) vertically across middle of middle of the rice.
Fold nori over from corner to corner and enjoy.
Boil 1 lb. of udon noodles in water for about 5 minutes until cooked. Drain. Rinse. Set aside. Then boil 6 cups of dashi stock.
Then boil the spinach for 30 seconds. Drain and cut the spinach into 2 inch pieces.
Cut the 2 leeks into 1-inch diagonal slices; and the chicken breast into 4 equal slices.

Divide the udon noodles into four bowls. Arrange the spinach, leeks, chicken, 6 oz. of kamaboko, sliced, and 4 shiitake mushrooms evenly on top of the noodles, and around the sides. Pour the boiling stock equally into the bowls.
Cut and discard thick ribs from leaves of cabbage.
Thinly slice remaining cabbage core; set aside.

Heat oil in a 4-qt saucepan over medium-high heat.
Add 8 oz ham.
Cook until lightly browned, 3-4 minutes.

Add 6 minced garlic cloves and 1 large minced onion.
Cook, stirring occasionally, until golden, 5-7 minutes.
Add 2 1/2 cups stock. Bring to a boil.

Whisk in 1 1/3 cups fine yellow cornmeal, 1/2 tbsp hot paprika, salt and pepper.
Set filling aside.
Working with one cabbage leaf at a time, lay leaf flat on a work surface with what was the stem end facing you.

Place 1/4 cup filling in the center of leaf.
Fold top of leaf over filling.
Fold in half crosswise, completely encasing the filling at the top. Roll cabbage into a tight cone shape.

Place sliced cabbage in the bottom of an 8-qt saucepan.
Arrange stuffed cabbage leaves, overlapping slightly over top.
Sprinkle with 1/2 tbsp sweet paprika, salt and pepper.

Whisk 6 oz tomato paste and 3 cups chicken stock in a bowl.
Pour over cabbage.
Bring to a simmer over medium-high heat.

Reduce heat to medium-low; cook partially covered, until tender, about 45 minutes.
Transfer stuffed cabbage to a serving platter.

Strain sauce, discarding sliced cabbage.
Spoon sauce over the top.
Garnish with parsley, sliced pepper, sour cream and more sweet paprika.
Remove from the heat, add coconut milk and whisk rapidly.
Add a tablespoon of soy sauce and a dash of lemon juice. If the sauce seems a little thin, thicken with a little roux.
Melt a knob of a butter in a pan over medium heat
Add some finely chopped garlic and lay in the fish skin side down.
Add a splash of lemon juice and season.
Grill to just before the fish starts to flake.
If you want a sauce to go with fish, best to have either something a little Asian like a Sweet Coconut or Soy Sauce.
Bake 35 to 40 minutes, or until tops are brown and crispy
Add one mugful of sugar to the pot fir every mugful of the fruit mixture. Mix in the lemon juice, about 4 tablespoons.

Return the fruit to the pan, and bring to the boil once again. Boil, stirring occasionally, until the gel stage is reached (the temperature of the marmalade should be about 10 degree C when checked with a sugar thermometer)
Remove from hear, and skim foam from the surface
Grind 12 oz hazelnuts until very fine.

Add 2 tsp baking powder.
Set aside.
Separate 6 egg yolks from egg whites.
In a large bowl, whip the egg yolks with 5/8 cup sugar until pale yellow in color.
Beat in the ground hazelnut mixture.
In a separate bowl, whisk the 6 egg whites until stiff.

Quickly fold (use the spatula to push down through the yolks and whites, scraping the bottom of the bowl and lift some of the yolk up and over the whites, turning the bowl a quarter turn as you fold) 1/3 of the egg whites into the yolk mixture.

Fold in another 1/3.
Add remaining whites and fold until no streaks remain.
Bake in oven for 60-75 minutes, or until top of cake springs back when lightly tapped.
When the cake is cool, slice horizontally into 3 layers.
Whip the 1 pint of heavy whipping cream until stiff.
Spread generously between layers, on top and on the sides of the cake.
Sprinkle chopped hazelnuts on top as garnish.
Boil the eggs, when done let cool.
Take the eggs out of the shell.
In a large bowl, combine chopped potatoes and eggs. Mix together mayonnaise, chopped onion, green onion, green pepper, and celery. Season with salt and pepper, then mix well.
Cover, and refrigerate for several hours or overnight.
Let butter and cream cheese soften to room temperature.
Mix the butter and cream cheese well.
Add sugar and beat until mixed but not so much that the frosting becomes loose. Add vanilla.
Cook 1.5 lbs. of cubed chicken breast, 2 cubes of chicken buillon, 6 chopped garlic cloves, one chopped onion and one chopped bell pepper.
When the chicken is soft, shred it. Save the water to be mixed with the corn dough.
Cut the 3 tomatoes, remaining onion, roll of spearmint and remaining 1 bell pepper in small pieces and fry them in 4 oz. of butter.
In a large pot add 2 liters of water to the 1 lb. of corn flour and add the fried vegetables. Mix it all together on medium heat. Add achiote or annatto to make the corn dough look slightly red.
Once the corn dough is cooked, add the chicken or beef shreds, as well as bitter orange, and let it cook for another 5 to 10 minutes.
Peel the 6 bananas and insert one skewer in each. Place them on a tray and put it in the freezer.
Once the bananas are frozen start melting the chocolate. In a pot add the 2 cups of chocolate and stir until it’s melted.
Take the bananas one by one from the freezer and dip them into the chocolate, covering the whole banana. Optional cover chocolate with chopped nuts.
Place the chocolate covered bananas back into the freezer for another 10 minutes and then they are ready to eat!
Heat a heavy skillet over medium-flame. Spread the 1/4 cup of  cornmeal evenly over the bottom of the skillet.
Toast the cornmeal, stirring occasionally, until it is lightly browned and releases its aroma.
Remove and pour into a  blender and process until it is ground to a fine powder.
Add all the ingredients: 2 cups of milk, 2 cups of water, 1/4 cup of cocoa powder, 3 tsp. of sugar, and 1/2 tsp. of cinnamon to a blender and process until smooth and frothy.
Adjust sugar to taste and serve cold over ice. Any solids that settle to the bottom are eaten with a spoon.
Cook the 2 lbs. of corvina or tilapia in a saute pan.
Dice the fish in very small cubes and place in a deep dish.
Dice the red onion, large green pepper, and chop the cilantro.
Add the diced onion, diced pepper, chopped cilantro, and 1 cup of lime juice.
Add salt and pepper to taste.
Let the ceviche rest for a couple of hours before serving.
Place 3 cups of water, 1 cup of rice, and 2 cinnamon sticks into a deep sauce pan.
Simmer on medium heat until water boils then lower heat to medium low until rice is almost done, tender inside, stirring every few minutes.
In a smaller sauce pan warm 3 cups of milk on low heat, stirring often, for about 15 minutes.
Add warm milk to the rice mixture and add sugar stirring often until desired consistency, it takes around 30 to 45 to be ready on medium heat.
Remove the cinnamon sticks and serve.
In a large pot, bring 6-8 cups of water to a boil over high heat. Add a tablespoon of salt and gently add the head of cabbage into the boiling water. Cook for 10 minutes.
Toast the walnuts for a few minutes. You will start to smell them get fragrant, but be careful not to burn them!
Place eggs in a bowl. Add baking powder, salt and pepper. Mix well.
Add herbs, walnuts, and zereshk to the eggs. Mix well until all nicely incorporated.
Warm up a non-stick pan with some oil.  Place the egg and herbs mixture in. Cover and cook for about 20 minutes on medium-low.
Cut the kuku into four pieces and carefully flip each piece.  Cover and cook for another 20 minutes or until kuku is cooked through
Wash and separate herbs from stem.
With adult supervision finely chop using a food processor. Mix well and set aside.
Wash rice and soak in 4 cups of salted water for two hours.
In a non-stick heavy pot bring 6 cups of water to a boil.
Drain rice and add to the boiling water, let it boil for ten minutes on medium to high heat for about 10 minutes.Check to see if the rice grain is firm at the center and soft on both ends.
Using a colander drain rice and rinse with cool water.
Wash and dry the pot and put back on the stove.
Cook the rice on medium to high heat.
Add 2-3 tablespoons of oil, add rice and layer with the chopped vegetable and sprinkle the dried herbs over each layer to cover the rice evenly.
Put the cloves in the rice and make a few holes in the rice with the bottom of a spatula.
Sprinkle the liquid saffron over the rice.
When the rice starts steaming, add about 1 cup of water.
Reduce heat to medium-low, cover and cook for about 45 minute.
For a thick bottom crust tah-dig, leave it 15-20 minutes longer.
Rinse the  rice with cool water a few times. Soak the rice in 4 cups of cool water, add 2 tablespoons of salt, set aside for at least a couple of hours.
Pick over dried barberries (zereshk), wash and rinse a few times, soak in cool water for half an hour. Drain.

Place 2 tablespoon of butter in a small saucepan, add zereshk to the pan, heat it up on a medium-low heat for five minutes. Add 2 tablespoons of liquid saffron and 1-2 tablespoons of sugar to balance the sour taste of zereshk (if you prefer a more sweet taste, add more sugar to the mixture). Mix thoroughly.

In a large non-stick pot that has a tight fitting lid, bring 5 cups of water to a rapid boil on medium-high heat. Drain the washed and soaked rice and pour into boiling water. Bring water back to a boil for about 10 minutes. Test to see if the rice is ready. Rice grains should be hard in the center and soft on the outside. Drain the rice in a mesh colander and rinse with cool water a few times.
Wash the pot. Return the pot to heat on medium-low.
Add 2-3 tablespoons vegetable oil or butter and a tablespoon of liquid saffron. With a large spatula place the rice into the non-stick pot, building it into a pyramid shape. Give to big chef to cook.

In order to release the steam make 2-3 holes in the rice with the bottom of the spatula. Cook for 10 minutes on medium-high heat until rice is steaming, when the steam starts to come out, pour a cup of water over the rice, cover, lower heat and steam the rice for another 50 minutes.
With a large scoop take some rice mix in with the remaining saffron and set aside.
Add parsley, 2 tbsp vinegar and sourcream to your liking
Now Add the tempering mix & serve
Whisk the yogurt with a fork. Add to the pot slowly.
Cook till meat is done to your liking and sauce is thickened.
In a dutch oven (or large pot) saute the onion, green onions, and garlic in 4 tablespoons of olive oil until translucent.
Add the lamb and brown a little, then add 1/2 tsp turmeric. Give the ingredients a few stirs so the spices release their flavors. Season with salt and pepper.
Prick the Persian lemons with a fork and add them to the pot.
Add 3 cups water to your pot. Cover and cook over medium heat for one hour.
In a separate pan, add one tablespoon olive oil. Add celery and give it a quick saute.
After the hour of cooking in the dutch oven or pot, add the celery to it.
Add chopped herbs, 2 cups water, and adjust seasonings.
Cover and cook on medium for 1 1/2 hours.
When done, the khoresht should lose its bright green color and your kitchen should be filled with a lovely smell.

Place two Tbsp. of canola oil in the pot, add one tablespoon of saffron and enough water so that the whole bottom of the pot is covered in a thin layer of liquid. With a wooden spoon give it all a nice stir

Since water and oil don’t mix, the key here is to stir the liquid to move around the oil and immediately drop in the lavash in the pot before the little oil circles find each other and make a big circle! You can cut your lavash so that if fits the bottom of the pot perfectly, you can measure out the size just before you put in the liquids. Alternatively, you can also place longer pieces of lavash that come up the sides of the pot. If you do, make sure that the sides are oiled. You can place one or two layers of lavash bread.
Top with rice and proceed to either make chelow or any type of polow that you wish.
Rinse the rice for a minute in the colander with cold water. Pour the rice into a medium mixing bowl and cover it with 2 inches of cold water. Let the rice soak for 90 minutes.
Drain the rice in a colander and rinse again with cold water, shake out the excess water. Rinse and dry the mixing bowl and set aside.
Bring 3 cups of water to a boil in a 5 quart nonstick pot (using a pot with a nonstick surface is important; it will help in the formation of the crispy tahdig).
Pour in 3 cups rice, 12 oz. beans, and 2 tsp salt. Stir. Bring the water back to a boil. Let the mixture boil uncovered on medium high for 8 minutes. Stir the rice periodically during cooking.
While rice is boiling, crush 1/2 tsp saffron threads in a mortar and pestle. Pour 1/2 cup of hot water into the mortar and let the saffron soak.

After 8 minutes of boiling, pour the rice into a colander and rinse with lukewarm water, then drain. Rinse and dry the pot and put it back on the stove. Stir the fresh chopped dill into the rice in the colander, making sure it is well mixed throughout the rice. I use about 1 cup of chopped dill; you can use more if you like a very green rice with a strong dill flavor.
In the medium mixing bowl, stir together 1/2 cup vegetable oil, half of the saffron water, and 1 1/2 cups of the cooked rice.
Spread the oil and rice mixture in an even layer on the bottom of the pot. This will become your tahdig.
Scoop the rest of the rice out of the colander and into the pot, forming a volcano-shaped mound in the middle of the pot.
Make a hole in the center of the volcano with the handle of a wooden spoon, pushing it almost to the bottom of the pot.

Place a thin kitchen towel over the top of the pot, being careful not to let the towel get too close to the heat source. Place the lid tightly over the top of the towel. Turn on the heat to medium and let the rice steam for 10 minutes.
Meanwhile, mix together the remaining saffron water with remaining 1/4 cup of vegetable oil.
After 10 minutes, remove the towel and lid from the pot and pour the saffron oil mixture evenly over the top of the rice.
Replace the towel and lid. Turn heat to low. Let the mixture steam for 45-50 minutes longer.

In a bowl combine 1 cup yogurt,1 grated onion, 3 tbsp olive oil, 3 tbsp lime juice, the liquid saffron, 2 tsp salt and 1 tsp pepper. Blend well into a smooth mixture, adjust the seasoning with lime juice and salt and pepper.
Pour the mixture over the chicken in a large bowl, making sure that all the pieces are fully covered with the sauce. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 6-8 hours.
Thread the chicken pieces onto metal skewers, place the skewers on the hot grill and continue grilling until chicken pieces are well cooked.

Chop 2 onions and fry in oil until slightly golden then add 1/2 tsp turmeric to it. Fry chicken in onions until color changes. Add 1/2 - 1 cup water and bring to boil. Turn heat down and let boil slowly until chicken is cooked.

While chicken is cooking, beat 1 lb. yogurt until it is smooth. Dissolve saffron in half a cup of hot water. Add the liquid saffron, 2 tsp salt, pepper and optional eggs to the yogurt and mix very well.
Wash rice and pour 3 cup water in a large pot and bring to boil. Pour in rice and cook while stirring occasionally until rice is al dente. Drain. (Basmati will cook a lot quicker than regular rice).

Pour several spoons of oil and several spoons of the yogurt mix into a non-stick pot. Add a thin layer of rice and flatten using the back of a spoon. Add a layer of chicken on top followed by another layer of rice. Again flatten the rice. Spread several more spoons of the yogurt mix on the rice. Continue in this fashion until chicken, rice and the yogurt mix have been used up. Add some more oil on top.

Put the lid on and cook for about 1.5 hours on medium low heat. Note that the longer Tah-Chin is cooked, the thicker the TahDig (delicious crispy layer of rice at the bottom) will be. When cooked, remove the lid and let cool for a few minutes. Place an inverted large dish over the pot and turn it over. Tap the pot in order to loosen the contents inside. The contents should fall on the dish in one piece with the Tah-Dig on the outside.
Wash rice and soak in warm water for at least 30 minutes

While the rice is soaking, in a separate pot (or Dutch Oven), heat 2 Tbsp. canola oil over medium heat and fry the onions, stirring occasionally until soft and golden, about 10 minutes. Add 3 tsp turmeric and fry for another minute.
Turn up the heat to medium-high and add another Tbsp. of oil and brown 1 lb. beef for about 5 minutes.
Add 1 lb. green beans, 8 oz. sliced mushrooms and another tbsp. of oil and sauté for about 2 minutes.
Add 1 tbsp tomato paste and fry for one minute. Then add the tomatoes, 1 tbsp. salt, 1/2 tsp. pepper and 1/2 cup of water.
Bring to a boil, then turn down to low heat and simmer covered for about 15 minutes. Set aside when done.
In a small bowl mix together 2 tsp cinnamon, 1 tsp cumin and ground saffron. Set the spice mixture aside.

Fill a large non-stick pot ¾ full with water and 1 tbsp. salt.  Bring to a boil over high heat. Drain the soaked rice and add to the pot of boiling water.  Turn down the heat slightly to medium-high (it should still be boiling) and boil for 6 minutes stirring occasionally.

Drain the rice in a wire sieve.
Using a paper towel, dry your pot. Pour enough canola oil into your pot to just cover the bottom. Add the saffron water to the oil.

Using a spatula, add enough rice to form a layer to cover the bottom of the pot and form the ta-dig (the golden rice crust).
Sprinkle about 1/3 of the beef and green bean mixture on top. Then add 1/3 of the spice mixture.
Repeat the layers (rice, meat mixture, spices) forming a sort of pyramid.
Using the handle of a wooden spoon poke three holes in the rice and pour over 1/4 cup water mixed with 1 tbsp. canola oil. Cover and cook over medium heat for 10 minutes.

Turn down the heat to medium low and take a clean dish towel and cover the lid of the pot. Make sure that the lid is on tightly. Alternatively you can use a double layer of paper towel between the pot and lid. Let the rice steam for 40-50 minutes.
When rice is ready very gently mix the rice. Season with salt and pepper if necessary. Using a spatula transfer the rice to a serving dish.
Make a mound of 12 oz. plain flour on a board.
Make a large well in the centre of the mound, cut 8 oz. butter into small pieces, fill the well with this, then add 3 oz. castor sugar, pinch of salt, and 1 egg.
With your hands quickly work the ingredients into a smooth dough.
Form into a ball, wrap in a damp cloth and chill in the refrigerator for 1 hour.
Wash and peel the 1 lb. of rhubarb.
Pour over the juice of 1 lemon.
Roll out the dough and line a 9-inch buttered pie tin.
Cut an 8 oz. stale brioche (any rich sweetened bread may be used if brioche is not available) into thin slices.
Cut slices in half and line the pastry shell with them.
Melt 3 oz. butter, pour over the bread, sprinkle with 4 oz. castor sugar, cover with rhubarb, sprinkle with remaining 4 oz. sugar.
Bake in a pre-heated oven at 450°F, Reg 8 for 10 minutes.
Reduce heat to 350°F, Reg 4 for about 30 minutes or longer.
Make dressing by mixing in a bowl and refrigerate overnight.
Chop up vegetables and place into a mixing bowl.
Combine tomatoes, peppers, onions and cucumber with dressing (discard garlic).
Top with feta cheese, green onion.
Make the marinate: mix olive, lemon juice, garlic (or other favourite spices), coat the chicken with the marinate, leave in a bowl in a fridge (for a night).
Preheat the oven to 360 F/ 180 C
Rinsed rice put inside the baking dish, add chopped pepper and tomato, mix all ingredients.
Season with chilli, oregano leaves and small pinch of salt.
Put the chicken on top of the rice mixture, cover them with thyme.
Pour the bullion over the meat (it should cover the rice with vegetables, not meat). Decorate with olives.
Bake about 1 hour (the time depends on the chicken size) until golden brown.
During baking time add some bullion, if the rice seems to be dry add more fluid.
Pour the bullion over the meat (it should cover the rice with vegetables, not meat). Decorate with olives.
Beef with mushroom and cauliflower stir fry

Place flowerets in boiling water.  Cook for a minute or two.  Using a strainer, remove cauliflower and immediately rinse under running cold water to stop cooking.  Set aside. In another bowl, mix broth or water with cornstarch and oyster sauce.  Stir to blend.  Set aside.
Beef with mushroom and cauliflower stir fry
Heat oil in a skillet (or a wok) over medium-high heat.  Stir-fry the beef for about 3 to 5 minutes or until meat is brown.  Add garlic and onion, sauté until it softens.
Beef with mushroom and cauliflower stir fry
Stir in mushrooms and cauliflower.  Cook for a few minutes.  Stir in cornstarch mixture.  Continue stirring until sauce thickens for about a few seconds.
Beef with mushroom and cauliflower stir fry
Correct the seasoning, to taste.  Remove from heat.
Beef with mushroom and cauliflower stir fry
Serve hot the beef with mushroom and cauliflower and garnish with fresh coriander.
Tear 1/2 lb. kale leaves from the woody stems and rinse well in a colander under cool, running water. Allow the kale to drain. Cut the kale into thin strips or small pieces.
Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Break 1/2 lb. pasta in half, add it to the boiling water, and cook according to the package directions. Drain the pasta in a colander.

While the pasta is cooking, add 2 tbsp olive oil, 2 tbsp butter, and minced garlic to another large pot or skillet. Cook over medium heat for 2-3 minutes, or until the garlic is soft and fragrant. Add the kale and continue to sauté until the kale has wilted and has turned a deep green color (about 5-7 minutes). Turn the heat off.

Add the drained pasta to the pot with the sautéed kale. Toss the pasta and kale together. Allow them to cool to the point that steam is no longer rising from the pot. You want the pasta warm, but not hot enough to melt the Parmesan.
Season the pasta and kale with salt and freshly cracked pepper to your liking. Add 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese and toss to coat. Add a pinch of red pepper flakes over top if desired.

In a large, enameled cast-iron casserole, heat 2 tablespoons of the oil until shimmering. Add the bacon and cook over moderately high heat until the fat is rendered and the bacon is crisp, about 5 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the bacon to a paper towel–lined plate.

Add the onion to the casserole, cover partially and cook over moderately low heat, stirring occasionally, until very soft, about 20 minutes. Increase the heat to moderately high. Add the wine, apple, juniper berries, bay leaves, sugar, 1 teaspoon of kosher salt and 1/2 teaspoon of pepper and boil for 3 minutes. Add the water and the sauerkraut. Reduce the heat to low, cover and cook until the apple is very tender, about 45 minutes.
In a large skillet, heat the remaining 2 tablespoons of oil until shimmering.
Poke the sausages several times with a fork and cook them over moderate heat, turning several times, until golden and heated through, about 8 minutes.
Spoon the sauerkraut onto a platter and arrange the sausages on top. Sprinkle the reserved bacon over the sausages and serve with mustard.
Steam or boil the veggies (it`s better to cook them before cutting, and to do it separately as different veggies have different cooking times).
Mix all the vegetables, except the carrot, and add salt, pepper, olive oil and lime juice. Mix well.
In a pyrex, put a layer of veggies, then cover with a thin layer of mayonnaise (store-bought or fresh), and then with another layer of veggies.
Finish with mayonnaise, hard boiled eggs, and carrot cubes, to decorate.
Add the avocado flesh to a blender and puree.
Add the stock and continue blending until smooth.
Blend in the lime juice, yogurt, Tabasco sauce, and salt and pepper.
When ready to serve, spoon into bowls and top each with a thin slice of lime.
Mash the soft yam pieces in a mixing bowl.
Gradually add the beaten egg, butter, and salt, mixing well to make sure that all ingredients are blended.
Spoon the mashed yam into an oven-proof casserole dish and spread the top with the beaten egg yolk.
Place it in the oven for 15 minutes, or until golden brown.
Sprinkle the top with nutmeg and cinnamon.
Red Pepper Spaghetti with chicken sausage
Place sausage in a skillet. Add hot water, cover, and cook for 10 minutes.
Red Pepper Spaghetti with chicken sausage
Remove sausages and separate links if necessary. Discard drippings.
Red Pepper Spaghetti with chicken sausage
In a large Dutch Oven, sauté tomato and onion just until al dente.
Red Pepper Spaghetti with chicken sausage
Red Pepper Spaghetti with chicken sausage
Add remaining ingredients. Cover and simmer 1 hour, or until thickened, stirring occasionally.
Red Pepper Spaghetti with chicken sausage
Serve over pasta, or by itself with hot crusty bread.
Chop Bosnian tomatoes and beat the 2 eggs
Stir-fry chopped Bosnian tomato in a wok over high heat until the tomatoes become liquid
Add dried shrimp and simmer for a few minutes
Season with clam base and mix beaten eggs into stir fry until the eggs are all cooked
Preheat an oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
Butter an 8x8-inch baking dish and sprinkle 1 tablespoon cornmeal over the bottom of the dish.
Sift the all-purpose flour, semolina flour, 1/4 cup cornmeal, baking powder, and salt together in a bowl.
