Boil potatoes and carrots in skin (it helps to keep vitamins), then cool them down and peel them.
Boil eggs and set aside to cool.
Chop potatoes, carrots, eggs, and dill pickles into 1/2 inches squares.
Stir in mayonnaise, but only for the part of salad you are going to eat today. If you add all the mayonnaise, the salad does not save well.
Mix the salad and refrigerate for a while.
In a large pot, heat the butter and add the veal and grated onions. Fry for a few minutes until the meat starts to brown.
Add water to the pot until the meat is covered. Season with salt and pepper and 2 to 3 tablespoons of tomatoes. Cover the pot and let the meat boil.
In the meantime, cut the ends off the Lima beans and clean them well (you also cut them in half if you desire). Add the Lima beans to the m eat after it has been boiling for several minutes.
Add more water until everything in the pot is covered.  When the beans are done boiling, add the rest of the tomatoes.
Let the stew boil for a few more minutes so that the liquid can thicken.
In a medium saucepan, mix together the vinegar, sugar, bay leaves, carrot, onion, peppercorns, and mustard seeds.
Bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Reduce heat and simmer until the sugar dissolves, about 5 minutes. Remove from heat and allow the pickling liquid to cool to room temperature.
Place the herring fillets in a bowl. Pour in the cooled liquid and mix so that all the herring is covered in the liquid. Let marinate in the fridge for 2 days.
To serve, remove the fillets from the pickling liquid and pat dry. Cut the fillets into 3-inch pieces and transfer to a platter. Garnish with the red onion and chives and serve.
Using your hands, mix all the ingredients together well. Shape into flattened balls and refrigerate while preparing the rest of the dish.
Drain the tomatoes, saving the juice. If necessary, add water to equal 1/2 cup total juice.
Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a large saute pan on high heat. Add potatoes and saute, turning halfway, until lightly browned. Transfer to a paper towel to drain.
Add remaining oil to skillet and heat. Add ½ lb onions and saute till soft and translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add garlic and saute another 1-2 minutes, being careful not to burn the garlic.
Dissolve the tomato paste in the saved tomato juice and pour it over the cooked onions. Season with salt and pepper and cook for 15 minutes until the onions have melted slightly into the sauce.
Spread the Kafta in a 9×12 inch baking dish. Arrange the potatoes atop, overlapping if necessary.
Layer the tomatoes atop the potatoes, then spread the onion mixture evenly over the tomatoes.
Bake until the tomato sauce is thickened, the meat is deep brown and potatoes are tender, about 1 hour. Let sit 10 minutes before serving.
To serve, cut into squares, spooning some of the sauce directly over each square.
Whip the cream until stiff.  Fold it into the mayonnaise and then set aside.
Drain the fish and pick out all the bones, if necessary.
Take about ⅔ of the cream and mayonnaise mixture and add the fish to it. Then, add the chopped onions and dill, cayenne, lemon juice, salt and pepper. Mix well.
Spread half of the mixture over the bread. Top with another 9 slices of bread. Then cover this next layer with the other half of the mixture. Finally, top with the remaining 9 slices of bread.
Press the “cake” down with your hand to get an even top.
Using the saved 1/3 of the cream mixture, spread over the top and sides of the cake. Put in the fridge while you prepare the garnish.
Slice the eggs and cucumber. Chop the cherry tomatoes.
Now, you are ready to decorate your smorgastorta! There are no rules to how to garnish it- decorate it however you would like with the prawns, eggs, tomatoes and cucumber!
Let the cake cool in the fridge before serving.
Melt the remaining 5 tablespoons of butter, and with a pastry brush, coat the bottom and sides of a 10-inch round baking dish with some of the melted butter.
Unwrap the phyllo on a work surface and keep any unused phyllo covered with a very damp tea towel.

Take two sheets of the phyllo and sprinkle about 1/2 cup of the meat mixture along the bottom edge of the longer side. Roll the meat mixture to form a small log and then place this along the edge of the baking dish.
Continue making the logs and place them in a coiled fashion in the baking dish until the dish is filled.
Generously butter the top of the pie with most of the remaining melted butter and bake for 30 to 40 minutes until the top is golden. Serve warm or at room temperature.
Measure out 2 cups flour. Make a well in the middle and add 1 tbsp oil and 1/2 cup of water. Stir until the dough turns stiff and lumpy.

Add the other 1/2 cup of water a little at a time, stirring it in until everything comes together in a soft dough and it does not stick to the sides of the bowl. Cover the bowl with some plastic wrap while we make the syrup.

Put 1/2 cup packed brown sugar in the pot with the water and sliced ginger (1.5-2 inches, add more if you like things spicier). Add a star anise. Bring the syrup to a simmer and stir until the sugar dissolves.
Cover and keep it on low heat until the dumplings are ready.
Take about a quarter of the dough. Leave the rest covered in the bowl so it does not dry out.

Roll out the dough on a lightly floured board into a rope about an inch thick and pinch it into 1 inch pieces. Dust hands with a little flour. Flatten one of the pieces of dough into an oval, and place a pea sized lump of filling onto it.
Fold the dough in half and roll it between your hands to make a ball. Place the tangyuan (dumplings) onto a floured plate.
Put the plate in the freezer and transfer the tangyuan to a freezer bag once they are frozen.
Bring the simmering syrup back to a boil.

Hold a spoon or a ladle under the surface of the liquid and gently drop the tangyuan onto the spoon, then release it into the syrup (this helps prevent the tangyuan from sticking to the bottom). Do not crowd too many of them in the pot. When the tangyuan float, they are done.
Put in a large bowl and stir in the sugar, vinegar, olive oil and pepper.
Drain the fennel and dry well.
Take the fennel and add salt and pepper, and mix with the citrus ingredients.
Arrange the arugula on a serving platter.
Place the mixed ingredients on the arugula and top with lemon zest, dill, parsley and mint.
Peel, core and thinly slice 10 apples.

Make the filling by mixing 10 sliced apples, 2 cups sugar, 1/2 tsp salt, 2 tbs cinnamon, 1/2 lbs melted butter and a splash of lemon juice (raisins and ground walnuts can be added if desired). Set aside.
In a large bowl, blend 2 cups flour, 1 cup sour cream, 1 tsp vinegar, 1/4 tsp of salt, 2 egg yolks, 1 tsp baking powder, 1 tbs of melted butter and 1/2 cup warm water.
Knead for about three minutes, dough should be light and very smooth. Cover and let rest for an hour.
Cover a large table with cloth and sprinkle it lightly with flour. Place dough in the center and roll it to about one inch thick.

Flour hands lightly. Place hands, palms down, under dough and stretch gently in all directions toward the edge of the table. While stretching, ease dough by lifting gently. Be gentle to prevent tears.
When stretched to the thinness of tissue paper, trim off the thick edges.
Spread dough with melted shortening. Let dough rest for ten minutes.
Sprinkle entire surface of dough with 1/2 cup breadcrumbs. Place apple filling all over entire surface of dough.
Use the cloth to roll the strudel away from you. Tuck in the ends.
Place on a parchment-lined baking sheet and brush entire surface of strudel with melted butter. Bake for thirty minutes or until flakes start to separate and strudel is shiny and golden brown.
Transfer to a wire rack to cool slightly. Cut into slices.
Drain the cabbage. Peel each cabbage leaf and cut out the hard rib in each leaf. Set aside.

In a large skillet, heat a couple of tablespoons of olive oil over medium-high heat and add the chopped onion. Saute until light golden brown, then add the minced garlic and 1/2 tsp turmeric powder. Stir and saute for a few more minutes.
Add the ground beef, salt and pepper to taste and brown until well done. Set aside.
In a medium size pot combine 1/2 cup rice and 1/2 cup yellow split peas. Add enough water to cover the rice by an inch over the rice line.

Add a teaspoon of salt and a tablespoon of oil then bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Reduce the heat, cover with the top, a little ajar, to let the steam out, and cook until the water is fully absorbed. Set aside.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the meat mixture, rice and peas, chopped herbs, cumin and 2 tbsp saffron. Mix well.
In a large pan, sauté the sliced onion in 3 tablespoons of olive oil until translucent.
Add a tablespoon of tomato paste and sauté for a couple of minutes until it is no longer raw. Add salt and pepper to taste. Add three cups of water and bring to a gentle simmer.
In the meantime, place a scoop of the mixture into the center of each cabbage leaf, fold in the bottom, sides and the top of the leaf to complete the wrap.
Arrange the stuffed cabbage with the seam down, next to one another in the pot of tomato sauce.
Cover and cook on medium-low heat for an hour. In the last 10 minutes of cooking sprinkle with 2 tablespoons of lemon juice or vinegar and just a sprinkle of sugar. Taste and adjust the seasoning.
Carefully put them in the oil. Fry one side and then turn over and fry the other side.
Bake, uncovered, for 30 minutes. The turn the chickens and continue baking until tender and golden brown, approx. 25 more minutes.
Place the pan back on stove top and bring the chicken juices to a boil. Add olives and lemon juice.
Pour sauce over chicken and serve.
Stir in garlic/coriander/ginger mixture and 1/4 tsp pepper.
Stir in 2 lbs of the shrimp. Add tomato slices, and cook for 10 minutes over medium heat.
Add water and salt. Increase heat and bring to a boil.
Add rice, stirring to mix evenly. Reduce heat and simmer until all the water is absorbed. Remove from heat.
To prepare the topping, sauté the other 2 chopped onions in the remaining oil until golden.
Add the remaining spices, chopped coriander, grated lime peel, and garlic/coriander/black pepper mixture, stirring to mix well.
Add the remaining 1 lb of shrimp, and sauté until cooked through (about three minutes). Spoon shrimp/rice mixture onto a platter, arrange shrimp topping on top.
After the marinade is complete pour half into one large ziplock bag with the chicken, then pour the other half in another ziplock bag with the flank steak.
Marinate for at least 2 hours or overnight
Grill meat until cooked through, slice  into strips.
Heat the remaining 2 tablespoon of oil in a large nonstick skillet until shimmering and saute the chopped onion over medium heat. Cook until soft.
Add the sliced green and red bell pepper and continue to cook until peppers are soft and onions are beginning to brown and crisp.
Separate the cooked vegetables into two bowls and mix chicken in one and beef in the other.
Set the lobsters or tails aside while you prepare the basting/serving sauce.
Melt the butter in a small, heavy saucepan over medium-low heat.
Add the oil, Worcestershire sauce, lemon juice, wine, garlic, parsley, and cayenne pepper and simmer gently until the garlic is fragrant and has lost its raw edge, 3 to 5 minutes.
Remove from the heat and add salt and cayenne and black pepper. Set half aside for serving.
When ready to cook, place the lobsters or lobster tails in the center of the grate, belly side up, and brush generously with the basting sauce.

Cover the grill and cook until the lobster flesh is firm and white, about 30 to 40 minutes for lobsters and 20 to 30 minutes for tails. Brush the exposed meat once or twice with the basting sauce during cooking.
Transfer the lobsters to serving plates or a platter and serve immediately, accompanied by the reserved sauce in ramekins for dipping.
Add 2 Tbsp water into the pot along with the apple, sugar, pomegranate seeds and cinnamon stick.
Cook for about 10 minutes at medium-low heat. Then turn the heat down to low and cook for 20 minutes at low heat.
Add the lemon juice into the marmalade a few minutes before you turn off the heat and stir.
Wait until it cools down a little bit, then place it into a clean jar and close the lid tightly.
In a large bowl, use your hands to mix together the ground beef, chives, ½ tsp cinnamon, 1 tsp cumin, salt, pepper, egg, parsley, mint, and 1 minced onion.
Wash your hands really well after you’ve mixed everything together!
Wash your hands really well after you’ve mixed everything together!
In a large pot, add the crushed tomatoes, chicken stock, pomegranate molasses, garlic, the other minced onion, lemon juice, ½ tsp cinnamon and ¼ tsp cumin.
Place the pot over medium high heat and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat and simmer for about 30 minutes while you cook the meatballs.
Take the meatball mixture out of the fridge and grab a baking sheet.
Using your hands, scoop out about 1 tbsp of the meat and roll into a ball. Place the meatballs on the baking sheet. Repeat until all of the meatballs are made.
In a large frying pan, heat the olive oil over medium high heat.
When the oil is hot, add about half of the meatballs and brown the sides. You should rotate them about every 3 minutes. You don’t need to cook them all the way through at this point.
Place the browned meatballs onto a plate with paper towels to drain.
Finish browning the rest of the meatballs and drain them as well.
Add the meatballs to the tomato sauce and gently stir.
Simmer the meatballs in the tomato sauce for another 30-40 minutes, until the meatballs are cooked through and the sauce is thick. Serve hot.
Heat up the wok again with 3 cups of oil to 350 degrees F and add the cut up flank steak. Stir for 3 to 4 minutes, and then remove from the heat and drain well.
Heat the wok up again and add 2 teaspoons oil, and help Little Chef add the ground garlic, all the cut up scallions, and the cooked beef. Cook for 2 to 3 minutes.
Help Little Chef add the sugar, black pepper, and soy sauce and cook for another 3 to 4 minutes. Remove from the heat and serve over the rice noodles.

Crumble the sausage (if using) into a skillet over medium-high
heat. Cook and stir until no longer pink. Remove from the heat and set aside.
Rinse 2 cups white rice and cook in 3½ cups water with 2 Tbsp olive oil and 1 tsp salt. Cover and simmer for about 20 minutes, or until all the water is absorbed.
Fill ⅔ of large soup pot with water. Bring to a boil. Add ½ Tbsp salt and 4 Tbsp vinegar.
Peel and discard the top two leaves from each cabbage. Use a knife to cut out the core of each cabbage.
Cook the buckwheat first by adding one cup of buckwheat and two cups of water into a pan and cook it similarly to how you cook your rice.
Mix all of the ingredients in a large bowl.
Form the mixture into little balls and set on a baking sheet.
Heat vegetable oil in a frying pan over medium high heat and fry the fish balls until they are golden brown and cooked through.
Boil the potatoes, carrot, onions, and garlic in a large pot.
Rinse the veal, then add it to the vegetables.
Mince the carrot, onion and veal once fully cooked.
Mash the potatoes once cooked and season with salt. Shape the potatoes into a flat disk and put vegetable and meat stuffing on it.
Close the filling inside the potatoes so the filling won’t fall out. Dip in flour.
Fry them each side with vegetable oil.
Peel potatoes and onion. Grate the potatoes and onion in the large bowl.
Add the flour, egg, sour cream. Mix it well, then add 1 tsp of salt and pepper.
Warm up a skillet with oil over medium heat. Add 2 tablespoons of the mixture and fry each side until golden brown. Repeat for the rest of the mixture.
Fill a large pot halfway with water(about 2 quarts), and bring to a boil.
Add the sausage, and cover the pot. Return to a boil.
Add the beets, and cook until they have lost their color, then add the carrots and potatoes, and cook until tender, about 15 minutes.
Add the cabbage, and the can of diced tomatoes. Stir well.
Heat the oil in a skillet over medium heat. Add the onion, and cook until tender.
Stir in the tomato paste and water until well blended, then transfer to the pot.
Add the raw garlic to the soup, cover and turn off the heat. Let stand for 5 minutes.
Taste, and season with salt, pepper and sugar.
Put first cabbage in water, core down, for about 5 minutes, then rotate and continue cooking another 5-6 min. You will pull off leaves as they begin to soften.
Remove the leaves to a platter to cool when they are done. You know they are done when they are soft and yellowish and larger leaves will turn a dull green.
Repeat with the second cabbage, adding more water if needed. Reserve about 3 cups of water from the pot!
Mix ground meats and rice together in a large bowl.
Grate and fry 4 carrots in approximately 3 Tbsp oil and 1 Tbsp butter. Once they are soft, add 1 cup of mushroom marinara sauce and saute another minute.
Add carrot mixture to rice and meat. Add 2 eggs and 1 Tbsp salt and mix well.

Cut the larger leaves in half down the center removing the tough stem portion- you will end up with 2 leaves. Place 2 Tbsp meat mixture at the top of each leaf and roll the leaf into a cone shape with the thicker part of the leaf at the base and stuff the wide part into the top.
Heat 2 Tbsp of olive oil and saute remaining 2 grated carrots with 1 tsp of Mrs. Dash. Stir until soft.
Add 1 Tbsp sour cream and 1 cup of mushroom marinara sauce. Saute another minute and remove from heat.
Pour the sauce over the Golubtsi and add enough reserved water from boiling the cabbages to almost cover Golubtsi (2½ to 3 cups).
If using a pot, bring to a light boil, then cover and simmer 40 minutes over medium heat.
If using a dutch oven, cover and bake at 450 ° F for 20-25 minutes on the bottom third (one step below the center rack). When it bubbles, reduce heat to 350°F and bake 1 hour.
Crush the crackers and soak them in milk.
Sauté the mushrooms and onions on medium heat to caramelize. Stir frequently so they don't burn.
When your mushrooms and onions are nearly done, add the garlic and cooked for a minute or two before turning off the heat.
Mix together the meat, sauteed mushroom, onion, and garlic mix, and crackers. Form small patties with the meat and lightly coat them in flour.
Fry the patties on medium heat in a little vegetable oil till golden brown.
Finish your grechanyky in the oven. You can add some tomato sauce before putting them in the oven, if you wish.
Cut the butter into cubes and mix with the flour, 2 eggs and salt until the dough forms. Cool for about 2 hours in the refrigerator.
Take the dough out of the fridge and roll it out with a rolling pin. Preheat the oven to 220C/425F degrees.
Grease the cake pan with butter and then line the dish with the rolled out pastry dough.
Prick the dough all over with a fork.
Clean the leek and cut it into thin rings. Chop the spring onions.
Fry the bacon in a pan. Set aside.
In a bowl, beat 4 eggs with the creme fraiche and season with salt, pepper, and nutmeg.
Spread the bacon and leeks over the dough and sprinkle with cheese and scallions. Pour in the egg mixture.
Bake the quiche for about 25 minutes until it is golden brown.
In medium saucepan over high heat, combine barley and 5 cups water.
Cover and bring to boil, then reduce heat to low and simmer until tender, about 30 minutes, adding more water if necessary to keep barley covered.
Bring small saucepan water to boil. Stir in poppy seeds, then remove from heat and let stand, covered, for 30 minutes.
In small, dry skillet over moderate heat, toast almonds, shaking pan constantly, until browned and fragrant, about 4 minutes.
In fine-mesh sieve, drain poppy seeds, then transfer to blender. Process until finely ground. When barley is tender, drain, reserving 1/2 cup of liquid.
Transfer barley to large bowl. Stir in reserved liquid, honey, and salt. Stir in toasted almonds, ground poppy seeds, apricots, and raisins.

Preheat the oven to 325°F. Lightly butter 8-inch square baking dish or 2-quart shallow casserole dish. Press barley mixture evenly into pan. Bake 20 minutes, then cool in pan, cover, and chill overnight.
In small bowl, whisk together sugar and cinnamon. Spoon chilled kutia into small bowls, sprinkle with cinnamon-sugar if desired, and serve.
Shred the cabbage, sprinkle it with salt, and press it a bit.
Discard the core of peeled fresh apples. Slice them and combine in the large bowl.
Dry, peel, and chop the nuts.
Add the mayonnaise, sugar, lemon juice and cinnamon to taste in the mixing bowl. Stir and put it into the salad dish. Sprinkle the salad with nuts, and decorate with carrot figures.
Mix all ingredients thoroughly in large bowl. Make patties accord­ing to desired size.
Drain the feta and place it in a medium bowl.
Grind the spices coarsely, if desired.
Heat a small skillet over high heat.
Add the coriander, cumin, and caraway seeds, and shake the pan continuously until the spices start to release their aroma, about 2 minutes.
Immediately transfer to a bowl and pour in the olive oil.
Add a pinch of coarse salt and swirl the spices in the oil and steep for a few minutes.
Pour the mixture over the feta.
Wash and dry the herbs then trim the stems, but leave them intact.
Place the herbs on a large platter in a few fluffy piles.
Place the walnuts on the platter, along with the radishes and lavash.
Transfer the feta to the platter and garnish it with coarse salt.
Grill, bake or fry according to desire.
Put flour, eggs, milk and salt in a food blender and blend.
Add the spinach bit by bit. The mixture will become Shrek /Hulk (or any other favorite super hero) green.
Put pan on stove and melt some butter or oil.
Once this is hot, put the green mixture on top and cover with some of the cheese.
Turn the pancake once the bottom is golden brown.
Bake for a few more minutes until the cheese has melted and fried a bit.
Roll the dough into a ball and place in a lightly oiled bowl, turning to coat. Cover with plastic wrap and set aside in a warm place for 1 hour, or until doubled in size.
Preheat the oven to 220 C or 425 F and line a large size baking tray with baking paper.
Plac the dough on a lightly floured work surface and divide it into 10 even sized pieces.
Put ⅓ cup water in a large bowl. Place the sesame seeds on a large plate.

Working with one piece of dough at a time, use your hands to roll the dough out to make 55 cm (22″) long ropes. Fold in half so two ends align, then lift off the board and use your hands to twist each rectangle into a two stranded “rope”.
Place back on the work surface and join the ends together to make a circle, pressing the ends firmly together to seal. Repeat with the remaining dough to make 10 rope circles.
Dip each ring, first into the water, immersing completely to coat, then drain well and toss in the sesame seeds, turning gently to coat.
Transfer to the prepared tray and set aside at room temperature for about 20 minutes, to rise slightly.

Bake in the oven for 15-18 minutes, or until deep golden and cooked through. Transfer to a wire rack to cool.They are best eaten on the day of making but will keep, frozen in an airtight container, for up to 1 month.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt
Turn out onto a lightly floured work surface and knead for 8–10 minutes, or until dough is smooth and elastic. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt
To make the sauce, heat the oil in a large saucepan over medium–high heat. Cook the onion for 6–8 minutes, or until golden.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt
Remove onion from pan, leaving as much oil in pan as possible. Add the mince and cook for 15 minutes, or until lightly browned and liquid is evaporated.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt
Return onion to pan and add all remaining ingredients, except the boiling water and chana dal.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt
Mix well and cook for 2 minutes. Add the boiling water.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt
Cover, reduce heat to low and simmer, topping up with extra water if necessary, for 30 minutes. Add the chana dal and stir through. Reheat just before serving.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt
Divide the dough into eight pieces and roll each into a ball on a lightly floured work surface.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt
Working with one ball at a time, and keeping the others covered with a cloth to prevent drying out, roll balls into 20 cm circles, then cut in half.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt

Using a pasta machine on the widest setting, roll out dough, lightly dusting with flour when necessary to prevent sticking. Reduce setting on machine and pass through dough again, repeating until dough is about 2 mm thick. Cut into 3 cm squares.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt

Place 1 tsp of the gandana mixture in center of a square. Moisten edges with a little water and press edges together to seal. Place on a tray lined with a tea towel. Repeat with remaining dough and filling.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt
To make the garlic yogurt, use a mortar and pestle to pound the garlic and salt to form a smooth paste. Whisk together the yogurt, garlic paste and water in a bowl until smooth. Set aside.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt
Bring a large saucepan of water to the boil. Cook the ashak (dumplings), in batches,for 3–4 minutes, or until they float to the surface and start to flip over. Drain well.
Dumplings with Beef Sauce and Yogurt
Spread the garlic yogurt onto a serving platter. Place ashak on top, then spoon over the meat sauce. Scatter generously with dried mint.

Mix first 3 ingredients in processor. Using on/off turns, cut in butter until mixture resembles coarse meal. Mix 3 tablespoons ice water and vinegar in small bowl; add to processor. Blend until moist clumps form, adding more ice water by teaspoonfuls if dough is dry.
Gather dough into ball; flatten into disk. Wrap in plastic; refrigerate at least 1 hour.
Combine first 3 ingredients in heavy 11–inch–diameter ovenproof skillet. Stir over medium heat until sugar dissolves.

Increase heat to medium–high; boil until caramel is deep amber color, occasionally brushing down sides of skillet with wet pastry brush and swirling skillet, about 8 minutes. Remove from heat; stir in butter and cinnamon.

Immediately place skillet with caramel atop ice in large skillet; let stand until caramel is cold and hardened, about 30 minutes. Remove skillet from ice. Position rack in center of oven; preheat to 400°F.

Arrange quince wedges tightly together, rounded side down, in concentric circles atop caramel in skillet. Fill center with any broken quince pieces. Roll out dough on lightly floured surface to 12 1/2–inch round. Place dough atop quinces; tuck edges of dough down around sides of quinces. Make three 2–inch–long cuts in center of dough to allow steam to escape during baking.

Place skillet on rimmed baking sheet. Bake until quinces are tender and crust is deep golden brown, about 1 hour 15 minutes. Remove from oven; let cool 30 minutes. Place large platter atop skillet. Using oven mitts, hold platter and skillet firmly together and invert, allowing tart to slide out onto platter. Rearrange any dislodged quince wedges, if necessary.
Mix the mayonnaise, mustard and vinegar together for the dressing.
Now place the remaining ingredients in a large bowl.
Add the dressing and toss until everything is just covered.
To maintain the quality of the fish, serve it on chilled plates and keep the sashimi in the refrigerator until you are ready to slice it
Remove fish from the refrigerator and, using a sharp knife with a thin blade, slice very thinly. Divide slices of fish evenly among 8 plates.
Drizzle each serving with about 1/4 teaspoon olive oil and 1/2 teaspoon soy sauce, adding more as desired. Sprinkle sesame seeds and chives over fish and serve immediately.
Boil the cauliflower until soft. Divide it into parts when cool enough to handle.
Mix the oil with the vinegar, sugar, chili pepper, and season with salt to taste.
Put the cooked cauliflower in a bowl and pour the oil and vinegar dressing over the cauliflower. Sprinkle with dill on top and serve.
Line a (8in) square baking tin with a cling film. Sift icing sugar and (1oz) of the corn flour into a small bowl. Sprinkle a little over the base and sides of the tin. Set bowl aside.
Put caster sugar, lemon juice and 14 fl oz. water into large pan. Heat gently until dissolved – do not boil.
In a small bowl, mix the remaining corn flour with 100ml (3 1/2 fl oz.) cold water, and then stir into sugar syrup. Sprinkle gelatine over liquid and stir with balloon whisk to break up lumps.
Bring to boil, then simmer over medium heat for 20 minutes, whisking often. The mixture should thicken and turn pale yellow.
Remove from heat and set aside for 5 min. Stir in rose water and pour into tin. Leave to set in a cool place overnight.
Dust a board with some reserved corn flour mixture, and then invert Turkish Delight on to it.
Remove tin; peel off clingfilm. Cut into cubes, and then roll each gently in corn flour mixture to coat.
Sprinkle over a little glitter, if using. Store in an airtight container with remaining corn flour mixture at cool room temperature for up to 1 month.
Turn over baking pan containing Turkish delight onto clean counter or table and cut with oiled knife into one inch pieces. Coat with powdered sugar mixture.
Peel plantains and cut them in medium pieces. Turn stove on from medium to high heat.
Add cooking oil to sauté pan and place on stove.
Wait for oil to be hot and add the plantains to fry. Wait until they are golden and remove from pan.
Use plantain crusher (or the bottom of a soup can!) and crush each piece of plantain.
Place crushed plantains back in the hot oil for the second time and remove when they are completely golden.
Peel plantains and cut them in three pieces. Turn the stove onto medium-high heat.
Add four cups of water to a pan and place on stove. Place the plantain pieces in it and add two teaspoons of salt. Wait for 15 or 20 minutes with the water boiling.
Remove plantains from pan and place them in a bowl.
Start smashing the plantains with a fork or with a plantains smasher. Add of the water from the pan to the mixture in order to make it lighter.
Peel plantains and cut them in four pieces. Turn stove on to high heat.
Add three cups of water to a pan and place on stove, and then place the plantain pieces on it and add one teaspoon of salt. Cook for 15 minutes with the water boiling.
Remove plantains from pan and place them on a plate, remove boiling water from pan and add sugar with a little bit of water to make caramel and place it on stove again.
Place plantains in the caramel, add cinnamon and butter and wait 15 minutes so that the plantains get flavorful. Serve.
Preheat oven to 350°F and open the cans of milk.
Add the 7 eggs and the two kind of milk to the blender.
Turn the blender on and wait for about three minutes, then turn off.
Add sugar to the baking pan.
Turn the stove on to heat the baking pan until it caramelizes around the entire pan.
Add the blended eggs and milk to the baking pan.
Place the baking pan in the oven for 45 minutes. Remove from oven and let it cool a bit.
Peel the potatoes, the beetroot and the carrots. Cut each of them in two pieces.
Turn on the stove to medium-high heat.
Add 7 cups of water to the pan and place on the stove.
Place the potatoes, beetroot and carrot pieces in the pot and add three teaspoons of salt.
Wash the eggs and place them to the pan also. Cook for 15 or 20 minutes with the water boiling.
Remove the water from pan and wait 10 minutes for the ingredients to cool.
While waiting, peel the onion and cut the onion and the pepper in small square pieces.
Place cut vegetables into a bowl and start peeling the eggs.
Cut the potatoes, carrots, beetroot and eggs in small square pieces.  Add them to bowl.
Mix the vegetables and eggs.  Add vinegar and mayonnaise.
Mix all the ingredients and serve.
Cut the chicken breast in slices.
Add the chicken, pineapple juice, nutmeg and a little bit of salt to a bowl.  Let it marinate for two hours.
Fry the meat in a pan with butter.  Place it on a plate lined with paper towels to drain when it is cooked through.
In a small saucepan, add the pineapple juice and nutmeg marinade.  Place it over low heat ( under Big Chef supervision ).
Add the fried slices of chicken breast till the juices run dry.  Serve hot.
In a bowl, beat the egg yolks just to mix well with the egg whites.  Add the salt and the milk.  Mix.
Add the butter to a frying pan over medium heat and when hot , pour in the beaten eggs.
Simmer until eggs begin to set.  Using a spatula and fork , roll up and let it brown.
Cut the tomatoes, the cucumber and the beetroot in slices, and the lettuce in small pieces.
Arrange the vegetables in the bowl.
Mix the salt, vinegar and olive oil.
Add the dressing to the vegetables.
Boil the pasta until soft and add the salt to the water.
Drain the pasta and add to a large bowl.
Put the slices in a bowl.  Season with salt, oregano and lemon juice.
Grease a glass baking dish with butter.
Put the slices in the baking dish and cover it with foil.
Place in the oven at 350 degrees, for 25 minutes
Rub the pork chops with sage, salt and pepper.
Heat the cast-iron skillet over high heat, then add 1 tsp olive oil and sear the chops on both sides until golden brown, about 5 minutes total. Transfer to a plate.
Wipe out the skillet and add the remaining olive oil. Add the onions and the apple to the skillet and brown over medium-high heat.
Add a little more salt and pepper, as well as the apple cider and stir.
Add the chops back to the skillet and cook again for five minutes on each side.
When ready to serve, put the chops, apples and onions on a plate and pour the remaining juices over.
Peel and cut the apples. Place the apples in a lightly greased 9x13-inch baking dish, sprinkled with 1/4 cup brown sugar and the cinnamon.
In a large mixing bowl, cream butter and remaining brown sugar. Add eggs and stir in flour and 1/2 cup walnuts.
Spread the mixture over the apples and sprinkle with the remaining walnuts.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees and bake for 45 to 55 minutes, or until the apples are tender.
When ready to serve, serve it warm with some vanilla ice cream!
Cut frying chicken into pieces. Put the pieces on a breadboard and sprinkle both sides of the pieces with salt and pepper. Melt 1/4 pound butter in a pan.

Spear the chicken pieces, one at a time, with a long-handled fork and put them in the hot butter. Let them sizzle and brown over high flame, first on one side, then on the other, until they are appetizingly brown on both sides.
Put them in a colander and run cold water through them. Let the water drain off.

While they are draining, take your long-handled fork and remove all the pieces of chicken from the frying pan to a soup pot. When the pan is empty, put the sliced leeks into the butter in which the chicken was fried and cook them lightly until they are no longer crisp.
Use a rubber spatula to scrape all the remaining butter and the leeks into the soup pot with the chicken.

Sprinkle with 1/2 teaspoon dried thyme and add 1 cup of parsley tops tied together with a piece of twine. Pour the contents of 14 ounce cans of clear, unconcentrated chicken broth and 2 cups of water into the pot.

Add 1 teaspoon of salt and ½ teaspoon of pepper, turn the heat to high, and bring the soup to a boil, then turn the heat down to a simmer. Continue to simmer for 1 hour. Turn the heat off, and allow the soup to cool to room temperature.
After the soup is cool, remove the bunch of parsley and throw it away. Take a paring knife and pull the skin off the chicken meat.
Take the meat off the bones. Cut the meat into bite-size pieces and put them back in the pot.

Heat 1/4 cup of the oil in a large frying pan over medium-high heat and cook the onion for 6–8 minutes, or until golden. Add the lamb, garlic and 1 tbsp of the salt and cook for 8–10 minutes, or until lamb is well browned on all sides.
Add the water, reduce heat to low and cook, skimming surface occasionally, for 1½ hours, or until lamb is tender. Remove lamb from pan and set aside. Reserve the stock.
Place half of the sugar in a hot, dry saucepan over medium heat. Cook, shaking pan, for 5–6 minutes or until sugar has caramelized.
Carefully add 1 cup of reserved stock, the remaining salt, 1 tsp of garam masala and a pinch of cardamom.
Bring to the boil, then remove from heat and set aside.
Drain the soaked rice. Cook in a large saucepan of boiling water for 5 minutes, or until almost cooked. Drain and return to pan.
Pour over the caramelized sugar mixture, add a pinch of garam masala and cardamom, and stir until rice is evenly coated.

Heat 1 tbsp of the oil in a frying pan over medium-high heat. Add the carrot and remaining sugar and stir for 5 minutes, or until lightly caramelized and glossy. Add the sultanas/ raisins and cook for another 1 minute.
Remove from the heat and stir in another pinch of cardamom. Set aside.

Heat the remaining oil in a frying pan until smoking. Pour oil over the rice. Using the end of a large spoon, make holes all over rice to allow it to steam evenly. Top with spiced carrot and reserved lamb.
Cover and seal pan with a tea towel, then a lid. Place over high heat and cook for 5 minutes, or until you hear a ticking sound.
Reduce the heat to low and cook for another 10 minutes. Remove from the heat and leave, covered, for 10 minutes.
Remove lamb and spiced carrots, and mix rice well. To serve, cover base of a platter with a little rice, spoon over the lamb and then cover with remaining rice.
Top with spiced carrot, then scatter with almonds and pistachios.
Add the tomato and chili and cook for 10 minutes, or until dal is soft, sauce is thickened and oil has risen to the surface.
Add potatoes and brown well on all sides. Remove from skillet. Pour off all but 1 tablespoon oil from skillet. Add ginger and garlic and stir 1 minute.
Stir in pepper flakes and turmeric. Blend in 2 tablespoons water. Mix in onion. Add potatoes, tamarind liquid and remaining 14 tablespoons water.
Stir in cardamom, fennel, cinnamon and pepper.
Cover and simmer until sauce has thickened slightly, about 15 minutes. Season with salt.
Cover the dish and bake at 350 degrees F. for about 1 hour, until the meat is tender and begins to break up.
Remove the dish from the oven.
Add the spinach, stirring until the spinach is wilted and blended in. Allow the stew to cool slightly. Add the yogurt, lemon peel and salt to taste. Sprinkle with roasted pine nuts.
Brush the baking pan with some of the oil, and start laying the pastry leaves inside.

First, lay two leaves, sprinkle or brush with oil, then lay two other leaves, and repeat the procedure until half of the leaves are laid. Make sure that they cover the pan by hanging them about one inch over the edges of the pan.
Sprinkle spinach with salt, then mix well by hand.
Add the feta cheese, oil, onions, eggs and salt, and spread this mixture over the already laid pastry leaves.
Finish by covering the spinach with the rest of the pastry leaves repeating the first-half procedure and then roll the hanging edges of the bottom leaves over the pie (think of a pizza crust)
Sprinkle top with oil and bake moderately at 350F for about 45 minutes, or until golden brown.
Serve hot, accompanied with buttermilk, or beaten yogurt, thinned down in cold water or with chilled stewed prunes.
Place the bulgur in a large bowl and add the chopped onion, cumin and 2-3 tablespoons hot water. If you only have whole bulgur, grind it in a food processor first.
Add the red pepper paste. Mix together. The idea is that the bulgur grains will swell and soften.
Add the chopped tomatoes, pomegranate molasses and lemon juice to the mix.
On top, sprinkle the chopped herbs: parsley, mint, dill if using, spring onions and olive oil. Combine but try to avoid over-mixing. Season with the salt.
Taste and see if you think if any of the herbs or spices should be increased. As with all these salads, nothing dire will happen if they are.
Decorate with black olives if desired, and mint sprigs. Kısır is often served with lettuce or even vine leaves on the side in which it is wrapped.
When cool, add the eggs and knead for approximately 10 minutes, using a pastry bag with a large nozzle, put 7-8 pastries in a pan containing the heated olive oil.
Start frying the pastry over low heat, increase heat when pastry puffs up a bit and fry until golden.
Remove fried pastry with a perforated spoon, draining away the oil, then put into the syrup. Strain off the syrup, place Tulumba on serving plate and serve cool.
Heat the oil in a deep skillet over medium flame. Stir in the paprika and cook slightly to color the oil, about 10 to 15 seconds.
Add the onions and garlic and sauté until the onions are translucent and wilted but not browned, about 5 minutes.
Add the tomatoes and cook for 3 to 4 minutes to reduce down a little bit.
Add the peppers, water and salt and pepper and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low, cover and simmer for about 10 minutes. Add more water as needed to keep it from drying out.
Using a spoon, form four small indentations in the simmering peppers to hold the eggs. One by one, crack the eggs into a small bowl and slip each from the bowl into an indentation.
Cover and simmer for another 10 minutes or so until eggs are cooked through.
Place the ground beef or lamb, onion, herbs, spices, salt and pepper in a large bowl and knead together well.
Wrap in plastic and chill for 1-2 hours to allow the flavors to mingle and make the meat easier to handle.
Form the meat mixture into balls, patties or ovals the size of a small egg.
Heat the oil in a skillet over medium flame and, working in batches.
Sauté the meatballs until browned on all sides and cooked through. Browned meatballs can also be finished in a 350ºF oven.
Preheat oven to 350°F. Place the almonds and sugar in a food processor and process until the almonds are finely pulverized. Remove to a bowl.
Make a well in the center of the almonds and stir in the eggs with a wooden spoon until the dough starts to come together. Then knead the dough with clean hands until smooth.
Cut the dough into 4 equal portions and remove to a floured work surface. Roll one portion out into a rope about 3/4 inch in diameter.
Press down with your palm to flatten the rope to about 1/2-inch thickness.
Cut the rope on a diagonal into 1-inch pieces and remove to an ungreased cookie sheet. Repeat with the remaining dough.
Bake cookies for about 12 to 15 minutes, or until they are lightly browned on top. Remove to racks and cool completely.
While the cookies bake, bring the water and 1/2 cup sugar to a rapid boil in a saucepan over high heat. Stir to dissolve sugar and let boil for 10 to 15 minutes.
Remove and cool to room temperature. Stir in the orange flower water.
Put powdered sugar in a large bowl. To finish, dip each cookie first in the sugar syrup to wet. Then toss each cookie in the confectioner's sugar to coat well.
Place on a rack to dry and repeat with the rest of the cookies.
Saute the onion for around 5 minutes until soft. Add the ground beef and brown.
Add a pinch of cinnamon, salt and pepper, and the chopped parsley and stir well.
On low heat add the beaten egg, but don’t let it scramble. Then let this cool completely so your pastry doesn’t fall apart!
Place 2 or 3 tablespoons of beef mixture about 1.5 inches from the bottom of the phyllo pastry sheets leaving approximately one inch either side.
Pull the phyllo (brik) up from the bottom; fold the sides to the center of section and continue to roll.
Place the Boreks (fold side down) in a frying pan with vegetable oil. Fry on both sides until golden.
Bring to a simmer then cook for about 30 minutes, or until the contents of the pot are tender.
Squeeze the lemon juice over the chicken and allow to marinate for about an hour.
Add the oil to a deep frying pan and heat on high heat.
Place the chicken in the pan and brown on all sides then add the onion, garlic, whole chili and tomato.
Stirring occasionally, cook over medium heat for about half an hour then add the squash and cook for an additional 15 minutes before adding the canned palm soup base and the okra.
Simmer for a few minutes until the okra is tender.
Place the chopped onion and the minced garlic in a skillet with the peanut oil over medium heat. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the onion is transparent.
Add the tomatoes, salt, hot red pepper, and the bay leaf.
Simmer 5 minutes or until the tomatoes are almost pureed.
Stir in the 2 cups water and bring to a boil. Add the rice, stir; cover and cook for 20 minutes or until all the water is absorbed.
Stir and serve as a side dish for meats or poultry.
In a small saucepan, bring the rice, 1 cup water and 1/4 teaspoon salt to a boil.
Lower the heat, cover and simmer until the water is absorbed, about 17 minutes. Fluff with a fork and let cool.
Meanwhile, fill another saucepan with salted water. Add the carrot, bring to a boil and cook for 2 minutes.
Using a slotted spoon, transfer to a bowl; toss with 2 tablespoon olive oil, the vinegar and oregano. Season with salt and pepper.
In the same saucepan, blanch the corn in the boiling water for 3 minutes; transfer to the bowl with the carrot.
Add the peas to the boiling water and cook for 1 minute. Transfer to the bowl.
Add the rice, cubed celery, chopped celery leaves and onion to the bowl.
Season with salt and pepper, drizzle with the remaining 2 tablespoon olive oil and toss.
Prepare a medium-hot fire on a charcoal barbecue. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F.
Prick the eggplant with a fork in several places.
Place the eggplant on the grill about 4-5” from the fire.
Grill, turning frequently until the skin blackens and blisters and the flesh just begins to feel soft, 10 to 15 minutes.
Transfer the eggplant to a baking sheet and bake until very soft, 15 to 20 minutes.
Remove from the oven, let cool slightly, and peel off and discard the skin.
Place the eggplant flesh in a bowl. Using a fork, mash the eggplant to a paste.
Add the 1/4 cup tahini, the garlic, the 1/4 cup lemon juice and the cumin and mix well.
Season with salt, then taste and add more tahini and/or lemon juice, if needed.
Transfer to a serving bowl and drizzle with olive oil and sprinkle parsley on top. Place the olives around the sides and serve.
Add the vermicelli and the butter to a deep pot.
Heat until the vermicelli is golden brown. Then, add the rice and saute for a minute.
Add the chicken broth and mix well.
Bring to a boil and then lower the heat, cover the pot with a lid, and simmer until the rice is cooked, about 25 minutes.
Turn off the heat and let is sit for a few minutes.
Slice onion, cut garlic into slivers or mince, chop parsley, cut eggplant into 1-inch rounds, cut zucchini into ¼-inch rounds, and seed and chop red pepper.
Blanch tomatoes by placing in boiling water for 10 seconds.
Drain, and when cool enough to handle, peel, seed and chop. Reserve juice from tomatoes.
Heat oil in a deep, heavy saucepan. Add onion, garlic and 1 tablespoon parsley. Saute about 3 minutes or until onion is soft.
Add eggplant, zucchini and red bell pepper and mix well.
Cover pan and simmer over low heat until the vegetables are tender; about 30-35 minutes.
Add tomatoes with the juice, stir well, cover again and simmer 10 minutes more.
Remove from heat and let stand, covered, for 10 more minutes. Then add the wine vinegar and black pepper to taste. Stir well. Serve warm.
In a large bowl, with a small amount of the warm water,  dissolve yeast and then add sugar. Then add flour and when moistened, add the butter and salt.
Knead the dough until it is very smooth.  Cover and let stand in a warm place for 4 hours.
Divide the dough into balls the size of two hands cupped together.
Place the dough in the pan and slit the dough in several places.
Sprinkle the tops with sesame seeds and bake on the bottom shelf of a 400°F oven for 5 - 6 minutes.
Move up to the middle shelf of the oven until lightly browned.
Bring potatoes, broth, water, 1 teaspoon salt, sugar, and 1 tablespoon vinegar to boil in 12-inch heavy-bottomed skillet over high heat.
Reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and cook until potatoes offer no resistance when pierced with paring knife, 15-18 minutes.
Remove cover, increase heat to high (so cooking liquid will reduce), and cook 2 minutes.
Drain potatoes in colander set over large bowl, reserving cooking liquid. Set drained potatoes aside.
Pour off and discard all but ½ cup cooking liquid (if ½ cup liquid does not remain, add water to make ½ cup). Whisk remaining tablespoon vinegar, mustard, and oil into cooking liquid.
Add ½ cup cooked potatoes to bowl with cooking liquid mixture and mash with potato masher or fork until thick sauce forms (mixture will be slightly chunky).
Add remaining potatoes, onion, and chives, folding gently to combine.
Season to taste with salt and black pepper.
Serve warm or at room temperature; it tastes best after resting at room temperature for an hour or so to let the flavors mingle and the potatoes soak in more of the dressing.
Chop up the cabbage and onions into small pieces and add salt.
Heat the oil in a skillet and caramelize the sugar a bit (this takes about 2-3 minutes on medium heat). Sugar will melt and turn brownish color. Do not burn.
Add the chopped cabbage, onions and the caraway seeds into the skillet.
Cover, and cook for about 30 minutes on low, stirring regularly, until light brown in color. Season with pepper.
Pan fry the sausage slices for several minutes to brown lightly and remove.
Dice the cooked sausage made by the big chef in step 4 once it is cooled.
Boil some water and cook the noodles until soft, drain. Let stand for a few minutes. Season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Combine the cabbage mixture, cooked sausage, and boiled noodles made in the big chef step 5 to finish the dish.
Combine the ground chuck, pork and veal in a large bowl. Add the breadcrumbs, nutmeg, salt, pepper and 1 beaten egg.
Mix gently by hand until thoroughly combined. Refrigerate until ready to use.
In large mixing bowl, combine warm milk, sugar, oil and yeast. Let stand for 5 minutes or until yeast starts to foam.
Add salt, beaten egg and 3 cups of flour.
Using dough hook, knead dough on medium high speed for 5 minutes or until dough is smooth and elastic, adding additional flour
Turn dough into a greased bowl, cover with a warm damp towel and set in a warm draft free space for 45-60 minutes, or until dough has doubled in size.
Punch down dough and divide into 18 pieces. Keep covered and set aside.
Meanwhile, remove meat from refrigerator and divide into 18 pieces. Roll each piece into a sausage shape, about 4” long. Set aside.
Line three cookie sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mat.
Roll out a piece of dough into a rectangle, and place one sausage in the center. Fold over the ends of the dough and pinch to seal.
Place the sausage rolls on the baking sheets (seam side down) and brush lightly with beaten egg, if you want.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees and let the rolls rise while the oven is preheating. Bake for 30 minutes or until golden brown.
Lightly grease the two 8 inch round pans.
In a large bowl, use an electric mixer to beat butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Add eggs, reserving just enough to brush over the tops, about 1 tablespoon. Stir in the almond extract.
Combine the flour and baking powder; stir into the batter by hand using a sturdy spoon. The dough will be stiff.
Press the dough evenly into the two prepared pans. Press almond halves into the top of the dough. Brush the top with a thin layer of the remaining egg.
Bake in the preheated oven for about 30 minutes, or until the top is golden brown. Cut into wedges to serve.
Lightly grease the baking pan. Line the baking pan with parchment paper and allow some of the paper to stick over the sides, about 2cm.
Sift flour, baking powder, cinnamon, cloves, salt and nutmeg into a large bowl.
Stir in sugar. Make a well in center. Add milk and butter.
Using a wooden spoon, stir until smooth. Spoon into the prepared pan. Smooth the top and sprinkle with walnuts.
Bake for 30 to 35 minutes or until a skewer inserted in center comes out clean. Cool in pan for 5 minutes.
Turn, top side up, onto a wire rack to cool completely.
Rinse the peas and set aside.
In a large pot over medium heat, heat olive oil. Cook onion, carrot, celery and garlic until onion is translucent.
Stir in peas, broth, seasoning and salt.
Cover, bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer 2 1/2 hours.
Puree with a blender or food processor. Return to pot, heat through, and serve.
Sift the flour into the bowl. Add the eggs and a pinch of salt.
Add 1 cup of milk and whisk vigorously until there are no lumps. Add the remaining milk slowly and continue to whisk.
Melt about 1 tablespoon butter on the skillet over high heat. Spread the butter around until it covers the pan.
Then ladle in 6 tbsp of batter into the pan when the butter starts to brown.
Tilt the pan to evenly spread the batter, add cheese and bacon to the batter to be fried along with the pancake.
Flip the pancake when the edges start to brown, and cook on other side.
Stack the pancakes on a plate until ready to serve.
Mix the pasta, pepper, onion, tuna and mayonnaise well. Add the olive oil and vinegar and mix.
Put rice and coconut milk in the rice cooker. Add shrimp (if you would like), salt and pepper. Begin to cook the rice.
While the rice is cooking, prepare the carrots and tomatoes.
When ready to serve, add the carrots and tomatoes.
In the mixing bowl, mix together the dry ingredients.
Slice the chicken into thin pieces.
Sprinkle the seasoning mix onto the chicken and let sit for 5 minutes. When chicken is ready, thread the meat onto the skewers and then brush with oil.
Grill or broil for 3 minutes on each side, or until chicken is cooked through.
Steam or bake the eggplant on a baking dish in the oven at 375 degrees for around 25 minutes, until the eggplant is tender.
Scrape out the soft flesh from the skin. Add the sesame paste, the salt, garlic and lemon juice to the eggplant.
Mound on a small dish and sprinkle with parsley.

In a medium bowl, mix together the coconut, sugar and egg yolks to form a stiff dough. Squeeze into 1 inch balls, and roll each ball in flour to coat. Place on the baking sheet, spacing about 2 inches apart.
Bake for 20 minutes in the preheated oven, or until golden.
Season the meat and boil until cooked. Set aside.
Add peppers, tomatoes, onions and garlic in a blender with water and blend until you get a coarse mix
Heat the palm oil in a pot. When hot, add the blended pepper mix and cover. Let simmer for about 10 minutes on medium heat.
Add the Knorr cubes, basil, chili pepper powder, crayfish powder, and salt to taste to the blended pepper mix. When satisfied with the taste, add the cooked meat.
Let simmer for 5-10 minutes, then add chopped spinach.
Prepare onion by cutting into slices.
Add onion, tomato puree, red pepper and garlic to a blender and blend until smooth. Add bouillon cubes, white pepper and thyme. Add olive oil to the blended paste and set aside.
Begin to wash the rice with hot water until the water runs clear. Drain the rice through a fine sieve. Fill a pot with 4 cups of water.
Pour the rice and blended mixture into the pot of water and stir with wooden spoon.
Place pot on stove and set to medium heat and cook for 45 minutes.
Beat the egg into a bowl and set aside. Peel the overripe plantain and mash with a fork. Add water little by little to the plantain until it is runny.
Pass the plantain mash through a sieve into the egg mixture. Mix it all together.
Sift the flour into the plantain and egg mixture. Mix very well. Add salt, cayenne pepper and evaporated milk and stir very well.
Set frying pan on medium heat and add just enough vegetable oil to fry the pancakes. When hot, add a little batter and cook until the underside is light brown, about 5-7 minutes.
Flip pancake over and lightly brown the other side. It is ready when both sides are lightly browned. Repeat for the rest of the batter.
Stack finished pancakes on a plate and serve.
Heat water to boiling in a pot.
Slowly pour the maize flour into the boiling water and whisk to avoid forming lumps.
Stir continuously with a large wooden spoon and mash so that lumps don’t form.
Keep adding flour until it is thicker than mashed potatoes. Cook for 3 -4 minutes while stirring continuously.
Melt the chocolate in a bowl which sits on a pot on the hob.
Blend the butter until it is airy and soft and then add the praliné. Mix the butter and praline and make sure you have a smooth substance.
When the chocolate is melted, blend it with the butter and praliné mix.
Fill a piping bag with the blend of butter, praliné and chocolate.
Create small round shapes on some baking paper with a nozzle of either 8mm or 10 mm.
When you have formed the round shapes, put them in the freezer or cold fridge.
Spread out some melted chocolate on a marble surface with a metal scraper. Let the chocolate harden
Once hardened, scrape off the chocolate. This will give you the chocolate flakes.
Add tempered chocolate to a bowl.
Dip the truffles into the chocolate. Then let truffle fall into bowl of flakes and roll it until it is fully covered.
Begin by making the cake. Beat 5 eggs and ½ cup of sugar until they triple in volume.
Sift the 1 cup of flour into the egg mixture and fold it in slowly and gently. Then fold in 1 tsp vanilla extract.
Pour the batter into a round baking pan and bake for about 40 minutes.
To make the pastry cream, heat 1 ½ cups of cream over medium heat and allow it to simmer.
In a bowl, mix together the cornstarch, water, ½ cup sugar, and 4 egg yolks.
Slowly add the mixture to the cream, whisking continuously (you don’t want the eggs to scramble!). The mixture will thicken after about a minute.
Remove from heat and stir in 1 tsp vanilla extract. Place the pastry cream in the fridge until you are ready to assemble the cake.
To make the whipped cream, beat 3 cups cream, 3 tbsp sugar, and 1 tsp vanilla extract on high speed until peaks form.
Cut the cake into 3 equal layers. Place the first layer on a plate or serving platter.
Spread raspberry jam over the first layer of cake. Then spread a thin layer of the whipped cream and place the next layer of cake on top.
Spread a thick layer of the pastry cream on top of the second layer of cake and place the third layer of cake on top of that.
Spread raspberry jam the the third layer and then use the rest of the whipped cream to spread on the sides of the cake and then make a dome on top of the cake with the whipped cream.
Roll the marzipan out and carefully place it over the whipped cream layer of the cake and smooth it around the cake. Cut off any excess marzipan.
Decorate the top however you want and then place in the fridge until you are ready to serve.
If using whole fish: Cut two or three slits into each side of the fish; rub salt and pepper into the slits and on the side of the fish.
If using fillets: Rub salt and pepper onto the fillets.
Heat oil in deep frying pan until very hot.
Fry fish in hot oil, one side at a time, until fish is browned and crispy, turning once. Reduce heat and cover.
Allow fish to cook a few more minutes until it is done. Remove fish from pan. Place fish in covered dish in warm oven.
Increase heat under frying pan. Fry the onions in the same pan, until fully cooked.
Remove onions and place them over the fish.
Add Peanut butter and curry powder (or other spices) to frying pan. Mix well with remaining oil.
Reduce heat to very low. Slowly stir in enough water (about a cup) to make a smooth sauce.
Pour sauce over fish and onions. Serve with posho or rice.

Have a peek by lifting up the edge with a fish slice – it should be golden. Then turn the fish over on to the other side and give it another 2 minutes, and drain on crumpled silicone paper (baking parchment) before serving.
Serve sprinkled with crushed salt, the rest of the lime zest and the limes cut into quarters to squeeze over.
Peel your potatoes and cut them lengthwise into discs of about 1/4 inch thick.
Slice the discs lengthwise into fries of the same thickness.
Make sure your sink is clean, and wash your fries in cold water. Drain the water, and wash them again in new clean water.
Repeat this a few times until no starch comes off the potatoes and the water stays clear. Dry your fries well, so there is no more moisture on their sides.
Put the thermostat for your oil to approximately 320°F or 160°C, not higher.
Put a small to medium amount of fries in the cooking basket (you will have to do this multiple times If you put in too many fries at once you will lose your temperature).
Make sure all fries are under by shaking the basket. During cooking you can shake the basket a few times so you know they're not sticking together.
Take out the fries, shake them and put them in a big bowl to cool off, once they are cooled to room temperature they are okay to start the second cooking.
Put the thermostat of your oil at approximately 370°F-374°F or 185°C-190°C, this is usually the highest setting, or just below that.
Put a small amount of the precooked fries in your basket. Fry them while shaking the basket in the oil a few times during cooking.
Trim and wash the vegetables and cut them into julienne matchsticks one and three-quarters inches long and one-eighth inch wide.
Toss them in a large mixing bowl with the tarragon and a sprinkling of salt and pepper.
Wash and dry the chicken pieces and set aside.

Using a casserole large enough to hold the chicken and the vegetables comfortably, layer in the following order: one-third of the vegetables, half of the chicken, half of the remaining vegetables, the rest of the chicken and the remaining vegetables.
Pour in the vermouth and enough chicken broth to barely cover the chicken. Cover and refrigerate.
When ready to cook, bring to the simmer, covered, and cook slowly 25 to 30 minutes or until the chicken pieces are tender and, when pierced, the juices run clear.
Strain out the cooking liquid, degrease it and adjust the seasonings.
Blend the cream and cornstarch in a small mixing bowl. Whisk the egg yolks in a large bowl and stir in the cream mixture.
Slowly whisk in the hot cooking liquid. Pour the sauce over the chicken.
Set over medium-low heat, swirling the casserole gently, until the sauce is warmed and thickens slightly, but do not bring to the simmer or the egg yolks will curdle.
To serve, ladle the chicken, vegetables and sauce into large warm soup bowls and sprinkle each serving with parsley.
Mix all the dry ingredients together in a bowl except the walnuts.
Make a well in the middle of the dry ingredients and add the wet ingredients except the chocolate.
Mix well with a wooden spoon (or maybe an electric mixer).
Bring a small amount of water to the boil in a saucepan and balance a ceramic or metal mixing bowl over the top of the saucepan.
Chop up the chocolate roughly and add it to the bowl. Stir continuously until the chocolate is almost completely melted.
Remove from the heat and continue to stir until the chocolate is completely melted and smooth.
Mix the melted chocolate and the walnuts into the cake batter.
Grease a medium sized cake tin well and line the bottom of the tin with greaseproof paper.
Pour the cake batter into the prepared tin and bake for 40 minutes.
Turn the cake out to cool. When cooled dust with icing sugar and serve.
On a sheet of waxed paper, combine the flour, salt and pepper. Lightly dredge the salmon fillets in the flour and set aside.
In a 12-inch fry pan over medium high heat, stir together the olive oil and one tablespoon of butter.
Add the salmon fillets and sauté, turning once, until they are just cooked, about 3–4 minutes per side. The fillets should be firm to the touch and flake easily with a fork.
Remove the salmon from the pan and place on a warm plate. Tent with foil to keep warm.
Reduce the heat to medium and add the remaining tablespoon of butter, lemon peel, port and rosemary to the pan.
Whisk ingredients together to combine. Bring to a boil and add the balsamic vinegar.
Continue to whisk until all the ingredients are well combined.
Remove the sprig of rosemary and pour the sauce over the fillets. Garnish with additional sprigs of rosemary and serve.
Crush your garlic into a paste if you have a pestle and mortar, then mix that into softened butter.
Slice your bread. The trick is making sure you don’t cut all the way through.
Once sliced, spread a half spoonful or so of butter onto each side of a slice till all the butter mix is used up.
Wrap in foil, or just place on a baking tray then put it in the oven on 180c/350f until the butter is melted and give it a few more minutes uncovered until getting a bit of color.
Preheat oven to 200 ° C (400F) and prepare a large baking tray.
Chicken drumsticks marinate: For the marinade use bowl and put the chopped parsley, or some dried parsley, Vegeta, red pepper, salt, pepper and vegetable oil, enough to make a paste mixture.
Make little cuts on the drumsticks' skin (on the thickest part) and spread this mixture and rub. Leave a little to exist, at least an hour.
Wash potatoes thoroughly and remove only a thin transparent crust or not to peel and cut into halves or quarters, depending on size of potatoes.
In a deep pot heat the water to the boil then salt and put the potatoes and cook for 5 minutes.
In a large baking tray, pour a little oil and heat it in the oven for a few minutes.
Take it out and in the hot oil in tray put immediately filtered potatoes, drumsticks, whole combs garlic, pepper it. Put the rosemary and stir to coat the potatoes with oil.
Sort prepared thighs and bake in preheated oven for 45-60 minutes depending on the size of thighs and pieces of potato. When baked remove the dish from the oven until the potatoes then add salt.
Serve with a green salad or another as desired.
Cook, stirring constantly until the soup is slightly thickened. Serve immediately.
While frying, help keep pieces flat by pressing on them with a metal spatula. Cook for 5-10 minutes depending on fish thickness.
Sprinkle with some sumac or squeeze on fresh lemon juice.
To prepare your tostada, spread a large spoonful of mashed beans over a tostada shell. Sprinkle on cheese and other toppings.

In the same sauce pan, add 2 cups of your reserved poaching broth, add salt and bring to a boil. Immediately turn the heat down to low, cover the pot and cook for 15 minutes. Remove from heat and let sit (with lid still on) for 5-10 minutes more.
While your rice is cooking, remove the chicken from the ice bath and rub the outside of the chicken with the sesame oil.
To make the chili sauce, blend your chili sauce ingredients in a blender until smooth and bright red.
To make the soup: You should have six or seven cups of the reserved poaching broth left over to serve as soup. Just before serving, heat up the soup, taste and season with salt as necessary.
Dice the onions and carrots and boil them in the large pot for 20 minutes.
Drain the onions and the carrots.
Quarter the potatoes and boil for 20-25 minutes or until tender.
Add the onions and carrots to the potatoes and mash well. Add the milk and butter. Mix well!
Add the salt and pepper to taste and mix again. Serve hot.
Peel the apples, remove the cores and cut into pieces.
Place the apples, orange juice, sugar and one lemon wedge into a pan and cook for around 20 minutes.
Remove the lemon wedge and mash the apples into a sauce with a potato masher. Allow the apple sauce to cool before adding cinnamon to taste.
Cut the beef into cubes. Peel the small red onion and slice thinly. Smash the rosemary sprigs to release some of the oils.

Put oil, red wine vinegar, mustard and a pinch of salt and pepper in a bowl and stir well. Put the beef, onions, garlic cloves, rosemary and the marinade into the bag. Squeeze the bag to mix it all up. Let the beef marinade overnight or for 24 hours.
When the beef has marinated, either take out the garlic cloves or chop them up to go into the stew, if you would like.
Dice the large onion. Prepare 1 ½ to 2 cups beef broth.
Combine all-purpose flour, paprika, mustard powder, salt and pepper into a bowl. Sprinkle the mixture over the meat.
Heat 2 tbsp butter in a large pot. Add the meat and onions and cook over medium heat for about 5 minutes.
Pour the beef broth into the pot and add the bay leaves.
Put the lid on the pot and let the meat simmer for 45 minutes.
Add molasses to the pot, and stir well. Put the lid back on and simmer for 45 minutes.
After 90 minutes, the stew should be thickened. Remove the lid and let simmer on low heat for 15 more minutes.
Season the stew with salt and pepper to taste. If it is the consistency you like, it is ready to serve! If it is too thick, add a little more beef broth and let simmer for 5 more minutes.
Put the rice and milk into the pan.
Bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 30 minutes.
Strain through a fine mesh sieve. Stir in the sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg and orange zest.
Put in the refrigerator to chill.
Wash and peel the yams. Cut into cubes.
Add yam cubes to a pot and pour in enough water to cover.
Place a lid on the pot and cook on medium heat for 15-20 minutes.
Uncover the pot and using the wooden spoon, gently mash the yam. Add in the palm oil, bouillon cubes, dried fish, salt and pepper and stir to combine.
Reduce the heat to low, place the lid back on and let simmer for another 10-12 minutes.
Chop the walnuts as finely as possible or pulse them a few times in a food processor.
In a small pan add two tablespoons of oil and saute the finely walnuts lightly over medium heat. Stir frequently.
Add the pomegranate syrup and 2 cups of water, mix well and simmer for 30- 40 minutes on low heat. Set aside.
In a large heavy pot, saute the onions in 2 tablespoons of oil over medium heat until golden brown, add turmeric and stir well.
Place the chicken pieces into the pot and cook until golden brown on all sides, add salt, pepper and a small dash of cinnamon.
Pour the pomegranate walnut mixture into the pot, mix well, additional water if needed, chicken pieces need to be covered in liquid, bring back to a boil.
Then lower the heat, cover and simmer for two hours. The slow cooked chicken, walnuts and pomegranate sauce will be rich and creamy.
Add the sugar at the end. Start by adding 2 tablespoons of sugar, well without shredding the chicken.
Put the Lentils in a small pot, add salt and pour in boiling water until it covers the lentils (Approx. 2 cups of boiling water).
Cover the pot with the lid (leave the lid cracked open so the steam can scape) and simmer for 30 minutes at low heat.
Pour the soaked rice (including the water) into a pot and simmer the rice until it becomes tender.
Drain the rice in a colander.
In a small pot, dip fry the diced onions in vegetable oil until translucent.
Add the ground beef to the pot.
Add salt, black pepper powder and ground cinnamon, stir well and fry along until the beef is evenly brown.
Add the raisins to the pot and continue frying for 5 minutes.
Pour in the lentils in the rice pot and mix well so the lentils and rice are well blended.

In a large pot, pour 2 Tbsp vegetable oil, lay the sliced potatoes across the pot and add the lentils and rice mixture to the pot. Add 2 tbsp oil (Mix 2 Tbsp Oil with 4 Tbsp boiling water) to the pot.
Cover the pot with a large napkin and put the lid on top.
Add 5 to 6 tbsp of the lentils rice to the beef/raisins mixture, then pour in the soaked saffron
Mix thoroughly, cover the pot with the lid and cook for 15 minutes.
Fry the dried barberries in 1 tbsp vegetable oil.
Add the beef/raisins mixture to the lentil rice pot, stir thoroughly until well mixed.
Add the fried barberries right before serving.
Combine the diced rhubarb and strawberry in a bowl, add the lemon juice, sugar and tapioca or corn starch. Mix well and let rest for at least 30 minutes, stirring every once in a while.
Combine the flour, sugar and salt in a food processor and mix.
Add the butter pieces, in batches, and pulse until mixed.
Add the egg and the water, 1 tablespoon at a time, until clumps of dough start to form.
Remove the dough from the food processor and knead it gently.
Mold the dough into a flattened thick disc, and chill in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes.
On a floured sheet of wax paper, roll out the dough into a thin sheet that is a couple inches larger than the tart pan you plan to use

Carefully flip the wax paper and the sheet of rolled pastry dough on to a lightly greased tart pan. Gently press the dough with your fingers onto the mold, start at the center and move outward. Use a rolling pin to roll over the edges and remove any excess dough from the edges.
Prick the tart shell with a fork and let it rest in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes or until ready to use.
Carefully transfer the rolled out tart dough onto a flat baking pan lined with parchment paper.

Use a slotted spoon to transfer the rhubarb and strawberry filling to the center of tart. Try to avoid adding any of the liquid at this moment, but save it for later. Leave the outer 2 to 4 inches of tart dough free of any fruit filling. Next fold the edges of the tart dough over the filling.
Refrigerate the rustic tart for at least 30 minutes.
If making the classic tart, then pour the rhubarb strawberry filling into the tart and place it in the pre-heated oven.

If making the rustic tart, brush the edges with the egg wash and sprinkle with some sugar. At this point, you can also use a regular spoon to add the liquid from the fruit filling back into the tart. Place the tart in the pre-heated oven.
Bake the tart for about 35-40 minutes or until the crust is golden.
In a 10-inch ovenproof skillet heat oil over medium heat. Add onion, shallots and cook for 10 minutes or until tender and golden, stirring often.
Add in the dates and cook for another 5 minutes.
In a bowl beat together eggs, water, salt and pepper. Stir in ¾ cup of the cheese. Pour into the skillet.
Bake at 375 °F for 15 minutes or until completely set.
Top with remaining cheese and the rest of the onion/date mixture.
Top each bowl with toppings of your choice from the ingredient list.
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F.
Peel and cut the potatoes into fries with the help of Big Chef.
Spread the fries out on a baking sheet and toss with the oil and a pinch of salt.
Place the fries into the preheated oven, and bake bake for about 15 minutes, or until they are all golden brown. You will need to flip them halfway through baking.
While the fries bake, warm the gravy in a saucepan on the stove over medium-low heat.
When the fries are done, place them on a large plate
Sprinkle the cheese all over the fries.
Help Big Chef ladle the gravy all over the fries and cheese. Enjoy!
Mince the shallots or small onion.
Add the meat to a bowl and mix in the shallots, the egg, the mustard, nutmeg, salt, and pepper. Knead a few times.
Cut the crust off the bread and soak the bread in the milk til it gets soft.
Add the soaked bread to the meat. Throw away the rest of the milk.
Make sure that the soaked bread is well mixed into the meat mixture.
Divide the meat mixture into four pieces.
Roll each piece into a ball and then roll the meatballs through the flour and set aside.
Heat the butter in a dutch oven or frying pan. Sear the meatballs on all sides until brown.
Lower the heat and place a lid on the pan and let simmer for about 20 minutes. Then turn the meatballs over in the grease and simmer for another 10 minutes.
Add ½ a cup of water to the pan, cover and simmer for another 20 minutes. Remove the meatballs from the pan and set aside.

Add ½ a cup of beef stock to the pan and stir to loosen up the meat bits from the bottom of the pan. Taste and see if you need to add more salt or pepper. Or to add some flour if you need to bind the sauce.
Serve hot with mashed potatoes and the sauce.

Heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a skillet and saute parsley and fresh mint over medium heat for 2-3 minutes. (If using dried mint, saute parsley first, and add the dried mint at the final minute.)  Set your parsley and mint mixture aside for now.
Wash rhubarb stalks.  Peel off the thin-film-outer-skin and strings. Cut stalks into 2 inch pieces. Set aside for now.
In a big pot, heat oil till it sizzles.  Add onions, sprinkle with salt and saute over medium heat until nicely golden and translucent.
Add turmeric and pepper.  Stir to mix.

Add meat to the onions, saute over medium heat until each piece of meat is browned on all sides. If you are using the optional grated ginger and garlic add those half-way through this step of browning the meat.
Add 2 1/2 cups of water to the pot, add salt to taste, and bring to a boil.  Cover and cook over low heat, stirring occasionally, until the meat is tenderly cooked.

Halfway through cooking the meat, add the sauteed parsley and mint mixture prepared earlier.  Now is also the time to add the dissolved saffron. Stir gently to mix with the meat, cover, and continue to cook until the meat is done.
Once the meat is cooked, add rhubarb, gently mix, and adjust seasoning. Partially cover pot with the lid ajar, and cook for another 15 minutes or until the rhubarb is done.
Taste and adjust seasoning to taste. If you so desire, and only if you must, add 1 to 2 tablespoons of sugar, just enough to balance but not drown the tart flavor.
Arrange the filled pieces on a lightly greased baking sheet.
Place in the oven and bake 25 minutes.
Put the potatoes in a medium pot and cover with cold water by at least an inch. Add 2 tablespoons of salt, and bring to a boil.
Boil until the potatoes are fork tender (15 to 20 minutes). Drain in a colander.
Return the pot to the stove and set over medium-high heat. Melt the butter in the pot and once it's hot, Add the greens.
Cook the greens for 3-4 minutes. Add the green onions and cook 1 more minute.
Pour in the milk or cream, mix well, and add the potatoes. Reduce the heat to medium.
Use a fork or potato masher and mash the potatoes, mixing them up with the greens. Add salt to taste.
Slice the eggplant into rounds. Coat the frying pan with enough oil to cook the round eggplant slices. The eggplants are done when they are soft and lightly browned, about 15 minutes.
Put the eggplants and the rest of the ingredients into a food processor or blender and puree until smooth.
Assemble bread slices and put the puree on the bread. Create a sandwich!
Assemble bread slices and put the puree on the bread. Create a sandwich!
Using a cookie cutter of your choice, press into the bread and create a fun shape.
Store and refrigerate any leftover puree.
Combine all ingredients in a large bowl.

Beat on low speed with an electric mixer until all the ingredients are combined. Increase the speed to high and beat until smooth. The feta cheese will not be completely smooth, so ignore a few lumps.
Spoon the cheese into a serving bowl, cover and chill for several hours to let the flavors blend together.
Bring water to a rolling boil.
Add the salt and butter, stirring to melt. Using a wooden spoon, gradually add the cornmeal while constantly stirring in the same direction.
Simmer over low heat, stirring frequently until it thickens and starts to pull away from the pot, about 35-40 minutes.
If desired, while mamaliga is still hot, add more butter, cheese, sour cream, and herbs.
Fried Eggplant with Sour Cream Garlic Dip
