Fried Eggplant with Sour Cream Garlic Dip
Cut the eggplants into thin slices.
Fried Eggplant with Sour Cream Garlic Dip
Fried Eggplant with Sour Cream Garlic Dip
If the eggplants are bitter, put them under a press for about 30 minutes; then drain the liquid.
Fried Eggplant with Sour Cream Garlic Dip
Fry the eggplant slices in a large skillet. Fry each side until golden brown and translucent. Place on a paper towel to get rid of the excess oil.
Fried Eggplant with Sour Cream Garlic Dip
Prepare the dip. Crush the garlic. Combine garlic, sour cream and salt and mix with a fork.
Fried Eggplant with Sour Cream Garlic Dip
Place dip in a small serving bowl. Place the bowl on a serving dish and spread the eggplant slices around. It is ready to serve.
Julienne or cube the carrots and set them to boil with the butter, salt, sugar, and 2-3 tablespoons of water.
Let simmer, covered, occasionally adding 3-2 tablespoons of water as the liquid evaporates.
When the carrots are tender, add the sour cream mixed with the flour.
Put the eggs in a pot with cold water.
Bring the water to a boil and simmer for at least 20 minutes.
Drain the water and put the eggs under running water for 2-3 minutes.
Cut the eggs in half lengthwise.
Pop out the yolks and put them in a bowl. Mash them with a fork. Mix the mashed yolks with mayonnaise until it becomes creamy.
Grate the onion into a paste. Add the onion paste and season with the horseradish mustard, salt and black pepper.
Fill each half of the white egg with the creamy mixture. Use parsley leaves for decorating the eggs.
Wash the rice. Mash the soaked bread.
Mix the ground meat, chopped onion, bread, rice and pinch of salt and pepper.
Wash and drain the sauerkraut cabbages. Squeeze them.
Fill each leaf with the ground meat mixture and roll, tucking in the ends of the cabbage leaf.
Finely chop the remaining sauerkraut. Put a layer of chopped cabbage and a layer of chopped onion on the bottom of a large nonstick pot. Add half can of tomato paste and the olive oil.
Arrange the stuffed cabbage rolls in layers. Add the chopped onion, remaining chopped cabbage and remaining tomato paste to the top. Add water to cover everything.
Season with salt and black pepper. Bring to a boil and simmer at medium-low heat for about 45 minutes. Add water from time to time to keep the stuffed rolls covered to the top.
Preheat the oven at 375 degrees and put the pot in the oven for about 10-15 minutes. The dish is better served the next day after baking.
Roast the eggplants and peppers in the oven at 425 degrees on a foil-lined pan. Blacken each side, rotating ever 10-15 minutes until cooked throughout. Alternatively, you can grill them.
Cut the eggplant in half and place them in a colander to allow the excess juices to run out.
Place the peppers into an ice bath. Peel, core and remove the seeds from the peppers.
Place the peppers into an ice bath. Peel, core and remove the seeds from the peppers.
Scoop the flesh from the eggplant. Pick out whatever seeds you can.
Mix the eggplant and peppers together and chop into fine pieces.
Finely chop the onion and boil in the water for about 5 minutes. Strain.
In a large saucepan, heat the sunflower oil. Add the onion and cook until translucent, about 5-10 minutes.
Add the eggplant, peppers, tomato paste and garlic. Simmer for 30 minutes to 1 hour. Add salt and pepper to taste.
Using a small, sharp knife, cut off the top of each tomato.
Using a small spoon, gently scrape out the insides of the tomatoes. Place the tomatoes, cut side down, on a paper towel to let the juices drain out, about 10 minutes.
While the tomatoes are draining, combine the goat cheese, sour cream, onion, dill and salt in a bowl. Mix together until it is smooth and creamy. Add more salt if necessary.
Turn the tomatoes over and spoon 1-2 tablespoons of the mixture inside each tomato. Garnish with parsley if desired.
Place the tomatoes on a serving platter.
For the nut filling: In a saucepan, melt sugar in milk. Add walnuts and stir frequently until thickened (abut 10-15 minutes).
Add cocoa and flavorings. Continue cooking until the mixture is paste-like. Set aside to cool. It will continue to get thick.
Split the mixture into two bowls and set aside for later. Be sure the mixture is cooled to room temperature before putting it onto your dough.
Prepare the loaf pans by spraying with non-stick spray and placing parchment paper along the bottom of the pan.
In a saucepan, heat milk, butter and sugar. Let cool until just warm.
Add 3 beaten eggs and mix it all together. Add lemon peel, orange peel, rum and vanilla.
In a mixer bowl, add 2 cups flour and instant yeast. Mix to incorporate the yeast into the flour. Add the wet ingredients and knead for 3 minutes on medium speed.
Add the rest of the flour and knead for an additional 7 minutes using a dough hook.
Cover with plastic wrap and let rise in a warm environment until dough has almost doubled. This can take 1 ½ to 2 hours.
Sprinkle some flour onto the counter top and place the dough onto it. Cut the dough in half to make two equal parts.
Roll one part into a large rectangle and spread nut filling (or other filling of choice) to within ½ inch of the edge.
Start tucking one end of the rectangle and roll the dough in a pinwheel fashion. Place the rolled loaf into the prepared pan and repeat with the remaining dough.
Brush the top of the loaves with a beaten egg.
Let rise in a warm oven until the dough reaches the top of the pan, around 45 minutes. Do not let it over rise or it will deflate when it is baking.
Bake in a preheated oven at 375 degrees for 10-12 minutes. Then place aluminum foil lightly over the top of the loaves and bake for 30-35 minutes.
Let the bread cool completely in the pan before trying to remove it.
Sprinkle with powdered sugar, if you’d like.
Deseed, peel and cut the pumpkin into chunky cubes or rectangles about 3” long.
Line the bottom of a large baking pan with the prepared pumpkin pieces and sprinkle the sugar over them evenly. Layer the rest of the pumpkin pieces and sprinkle remaining sugar over evenly.
Cover the dish and let it rest overnight.
Bake the pumpkin for 1 to 1 ¼ hours. Every 20 minutes, spoon the liquid in the baking dish over the pumpkin so they absorb all the syrup.
After 45 minutes of baking, check the sweetness. If it is not sweet enough, sprinkle a few more tablespoons of sugar. Turn the pumpkin pieces.
The pumpkin pieces are ready when all of the syrup is absorbed.
Let the pumpkin cool. Roll the pumpkin in the crushed walnuts when ready to serve.
Prepare your fruit by cutting into slices. Use a knife, or a mandolin if you want uniform slices. Slice the quince, apple, limes and cucumbers.
Get the seeds out of the pomegranate. Score the top and remove, then score softly along the webbed flesh. Use a little pressure to pop each section out and begin to pop the seeds into a bowl.
Cut the rind from the watermelon.
When all of the fruits are sliced and prepared, place them into the pitcher.
Pour the sparkling cider into the pitcher until just filled.
Let the drink sit in the fridge to chill. The longer it sits, the more flavor it will have.
Heat olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Cook and stir garlic, onion, and green bell pepper until softened, about 5 to 7 minutes.
Crumble ground beef into the skillet. Cook and stir until browned completely, about 7-10 minutes.
Combine coriander, 1 tsp cumin, paprika, garlic powder and salt in a small bowl to create the sazon seasoning.
Stir olives, raisins, capers, tomato sauce, sazon seasoning, cumin, sugar and a pinch of salt through the ground beef mixture.
Cover the skillet and reduce heat to low. Cook until the mixture is heated through, about 5-10 minutes.
Heat olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Sauté onions until soft.
Stir in garlic, and sauté about 1 minute. Add tomatoes and cook until they begin to soften.
Stir in wine, olives, capers, and red pepper flakes. Heat to a simmer.
Place sea bass into sauce. Cover, and gently simmer for 10 to 12 minutes, or until fish flakes easily with a fork. Transfer fish to a serving plate, and keep warm.
Increase the heat, and add butter to sauce. Simmer until the sauce thickens. Stir in cilantro.
Rinse and dry each fillet. Place on a plate and squirt juice from one half lemon over the fillets, turning to coat well.
To create the sazon seasoning, mix 1 tsp of each: ground coriander, ground cumin, paprika, garlic powder, and salt.
In a large zipper-top bag, combine flour and 1 tablespoon of sazon seasoning.
Heat oil in large skillet over medium heat.
Place each fillet individually in the bag and shake to coat with the flour mixture, then add to the skillet.
Repeat until all the fillets are in skillet. Discard remaining flour mixture. Fry fillets on each side until golden brown, about 3-4 minutes each. Remove to a plate.
Add onion, pepper and tomato to hot skillet.
Stir and cook vegetables until onion begins to soften, about 3 minutes. Add remaining juice from lemon half, remaining teaspoon Cuban seasoning and wine. Reduce heat to low.
Place fillets back in skillet over vegetables and cover. Stew 5 minutes to allow fish to heat and absorb flavors from vegetables and juices. Serve over rice and garnish with parsley, if desired.
Wash the carrots and the cabbage.
Peel the carrots and then slice them thin.
To  make  the  dressing,  add  the  vinegar,  mustard,  cream, mayonnaise, salt, and pepper to a small bowl.
Whisk together the ingredients until everything is well blended.
Add the carrots and cabbage to a large bowl and toss with the dressing.

-Soak bulgur in cold water for 3 hours.

- Drain; mix with remaining ingredients

-Garnish with lemon slices and serve with lettuce leaves, which can be used

astabouli scoops

-Cook the onion and butter in a covered casserole for 4 minutes. Add 1 cup beef broth, the rice, and the lemon slice.

-Cook, covered, in the microwave oven, stirring occasionally, until the rice is tender (12 to 15 minutes).

-Add the remaining broth and heat to a simmer. Stir a little of the hot soup into the yogurt.

-Then stir the yogurt into the soup and mix until it is creamy. Season.

-Ladle into soup bowls and sprinkle with the chopped mint and parsley.

1. Remove the skin and peel tomatoes
2. Small dice onion and mince garlic. Saute in olive oil until translucent.  Add 1 tsp of turmeric and two tsp cinnamon.
3.Small dice meat and add to the pan. Pan fry until browned.
4. Place tomatoes in a food processor and puree.
5. Add 1 tbsp of tomato paste to browned meat.
6. Add pureed tomatoes, season with salt and pepper
7. Cover and cook for 30 minutes.  Remove cover and further cook for another 30 minutes.
8. Add oil and water as usual to the bottom of your pot and built the rice layers as usual.
9. Add a bit of the meat and tomato stew and Top it with rice.
10. Then some more stew until all the meat is gone. Make sure that too much juice is not mixed with the rice.
11. Cover rice and cook on high for 10 minutes.
12. Take 1/2 cup of stew juice, 1/4 cup water, and 1/4 cup oil and mix together. Gently pour over the rice
13. Place the lid in a towel and then put it back on the pot and cook on low for one hour.
Cook the macaroni based on the instructions on the box. When the pasta is cooked, drain the pasta. Set aside.
In a large skillet, heat the olive oil on a medium high heat and sauté the onions and garlic until the onions are golden brown.
Add beef, pork, and bacon into the large skillet.
Add crushed tomatoes, nutmeg, salt, pepper, and mix well. Simmer for 10 minutes on medium-low heat.
Pour half of the drained macaroni into a well-buttered baking pan.
Top macaroni with half of the meat mixture. Add remaining macaroni and top with meat mixture.
Using two wooden spoons, fold meat and macaroni together gently in a tossing motion. Smooth the mixture in the pan.
In a small bowl, mix the two eggs, yogurt, and half of the Parmesan cheese with a fork. Mix thoroughly and pour over the entire casserole. Sprinkle remaining cheese on top of the casserole.

Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Cook for 30 minutes until the top becomes golden brown. After you take the casserole out of the oven, allow for it to cool for 15 minutes, and ready then it is to serve.
Put flour in a mixing bowl.
Add enough water to make a stiff dough.
Beat with an electric mixer on medium speed until smooth. If the mixture if too sticky, add more flour.
Flour board and spread shortening over the whole surface.
Roll out the pastry out 1/8” thick.
Mash the ricotta with a fork, add the salt and the unbeaten eggs.
The pastizzi may now be made into little tartlets in round tartlet cases or they may be cut in the same way as ravioli.
Bake  in  the  oven  at  425  degrees  for  20­ to 25  minutes  or  until risen and golden brown.
Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F. Cut the pumpkin in half, stem to base. Remove seeds and pulp.
Bake in the preheated oven, foil side up, for 1 hour or until tender.
Scrape pumpkin meat from shell halves and puree in a blender.
Strain to remove any stringy pieces.
Stir 1 cup pumpkin puree into yogurt.
Mix the water, sugar and lemon juice in a small sauce pan.
Boil the mixture on high heat.
Reduce to medium heat, and cook until slightly syrupy (about 5 mins).
Reduce heat to low, and cook until the mixture is very thick (about 10 mins).
Remove the figs from heat, stir in the chopped nuts and anise.
Cool the jam and store it in a jar.
Mix yeast with warm water in a large mixing bowl and allow to stand until a creamy layer of foam appears, about 10 minutes.
Whisk in ¼ cup olive oil, then gradually stir in flour and ½ teaspoon kosher salt.

Transfer dough to a floured surface and knead until smooth and just a little bit sticky, 10 to 12 minutes. Place dough into an oiled bowl and turn dough around in bowl to coat surface with oil. Cover bowl and refrigerate dough overnight.
Coat a 9x13-inch baking sheet generously with 2 tablespoons olive oil; place dough in the center of the baking sheet and flatten into a thick disk.
Cover dough with plastic wrap and let it double in size, about 1 ½ hours.

Use your palms and fingers to gently press and stretch dough to the edges of the oiled baking sheet, making the flatbread as even in thickness as you can. With fingertips, make small indentations in the dough. Brush dough with remaining 2 tablespoons olive oil.
Stir za’atar and ¾ teaspoon kosher salt together in a small bowl and sprinkle evenly over flatbread. Let dough rest for 30 minutes uncovered.
Bake flatbread in the preheated oven until golden brown, about 15 to 20 minutes.
Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Place pita pieces into the skillet without crowding. Fry in batches until browned; then remove to paper towels.
Place romaine lettuce, tomatoes, cucumbers, bell pepper, green onions, mint leaves, parsley, and cilantro into a large bowl.
Pour lemon juice and white wine vinegar into a small bowl. Season with salt, lemon pepper, onion flakes, celery salt, and garlic powder. Stir in olive oil.
Gently toss salad with fried pita pieces and dressing. Adjust seasonings to taste.

Place the yogurt, water, lemon juice, vinegar, olive oil, onion, and garlic into a large mixing bowl. Whisk in the salt, black pepper, cumin, nutmeg, clove, mace, and cayenne pepper until evenly blended.
Mix in the lamb strips to coat. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and marinate in the refrigerator for 12 to 24 hours (the longer the better).

Heat a large skillet over high heat. Cook the lamb strips in a single layer in batches until the fat melts and the meat has browned and is no longer pink on the inside, about 5 minutes, turning occasionally.
Place cracked bulgur wheat in a bowl and cover with 2 cups boiling water.
Soak for 30 minutes; drain and squeeze out excess water.

In a mixing bowl, combine the wheat, tomatoes, cucumbers, onions, garlic, parsley, mint, salt, lemon juice, and olive oil. Toss and refrigerate for at least 4 hours before serving. Toss again prior to serving.
Place chicken and potatoes in a large baking dish. Season generously with salt and white pepper.
In a bowl, stir together garlic, olive oil, and lemon juice. Pour over chicken and potatoes. Cover dish with foil.
Bake in preheated oven for 30 minutes. Remove foil, increase heat to 475 degrees and cook until chicken and potatoes are golden, about 30 minutes.
Place the semolina flour into a medium bowl, and cut in shortening using a pastry blender or a fork.

Pour in boiling water and mix into a solid dough. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface, and knead for a minute or two to be sure the dough is well blended. Cover dough and let stand for at least one hour, or as long as overnight.
In a medium bowl, mix together the sugar, ground nuts, and rose water so that the mixture is uniform. Set aside.
Grease cookie sheets or line with parchment paper. Knead dough again briefly, and form into walnut sized balls.
Make a hole in the center using your finger. Fill the hole with the nut mixture, and seal the dough up over it. Gently form into balls or crescents.
Place cookies at least 1 inch apart onto the prepared cookie sheets.
Bake for 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until lightly browned.
Dust with confectioner’s sugar while still warm, if desired.
Line a 9x13-inch glass baking dish with aluminum foil and generously butter the foil. Spread the tahini evenly over the bottom of the prepared pan in a thin layer.
Mix together farina cereal with 1 ½ cup of sugar and baking powder in a bowl. Mix in the yogurt and 1 tablespoon of softened butter gently with your hands until the dough is smooth.
Spread the dough out into the prepared baking dish. Pat the surface smooth. Cover the dish with foil, and allow to stand at room temperature for 2 hours.
With a sharp knife, cut the dough into 16 squares. Push an almond half gently into the top of each square.
Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Bake in the preheated oven until the dessert is set and top is lightly brown, about 30 minutes.
While the dessert is baking, make the syrup. Place 2 cups of sugar into a saucepan with the water, and bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly to dissolve sugar.
Stir in the lemon juice and boil the syrup for 5 minutes; stir in butter and orange flower water until combined.
Pour the hot syrup over the dessert as soon as it comes out of the oven. Let cool for 1 to 2 hours to let the syrup absorb before serving.
Preheat an outdoor grill for high heat.
If using wooden skewers, soak wooden skewers in water.
In a large bowl, mix together the ground beef, onion, parsley, cayenne, allspice, salt and pepper until evenly blended.
Divide into 6 portions, and press around one end of the skewers to form a log shape approximately 1 inch thick and 6 inches long.
Grill for 10 to 15 minutes, turning occasionally, until meat is no longer pink.

Heat olive oil in a large heavy-bottomed pot over medium heat. Cook and stir onion, celery, and carrots until slightly tender, about 5 minutes. Add garlic; cook and stir until fragrant, about 30 seconds.
Add water, lentils, 2 tbsp. fresh parsley, salt, coriander, cumin, black pepper, and cayenne pepper. Stir to incorporate. Cover and simmer until lentils are tender, stirring occasionally, 1 ½ hours.

Whisk butter and flour together in a small saucepan over medium-low heat; stir constantly until thickened and paste-like, about 10 minutes. Reduce heat to low, stirring every 2 to 3 minutes until light brown, about 20 more minutes.
Whisk flour paste into finished soup, a spoonful at a time, until smooth and creamy.
Peel the skin off the sausage and chop up meat coarsely.
Place oil in a pot, add onions and sauté until soft. Add the garlic and chili and sauté for 2 minutes.
Turn the heat up, add the wine and sauté for 2 minutes while stirring. Add the pumpkin and parsley, mix and cover the pot with a lid. Sauté over medium heat for 8 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add the sausage and the rice and mix. Cover the pot and simmer for 18 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Turn off the heat and mix 2 tablespoons of Pecorino cheese and let sit for 2 minutes.
Dissolve the yeast and the sugar in a small bowl of warm water until the mixture is frothy.
Mix the flour and the salt in a large bowl and add the melted butter.
Add the yeast mixture and mix well.
Add the warm water as you go along to ensure a doughy consistency. The dough should not be sticky.
Knead the dough on a countertop. Place it in a bowl to rest and rise, about one hour.
Knead the dough again and cut into small portions.
Roll out the dough as thinly as possible (about ¼-inch thick) and using a round cookie cutter, cut the dough into small circles. Alternatively, you can use a glass if you do not have a cookie cutter.
Sprinkle flour on a baking pan and place the circles on the pan.
Bake at 350 degrees for 15 minutes, or until they are golden brown.
Heat the olive oil on medium heat in a nonstick skillet. Add the onions and cook until translucent and starting to turn brown, about 6 minutes.
Insert the tomatoes and cook over low heat until the liquid evaporates, about 40 minutes.
Whisk the eggs in a bowl until well blended. Season with a little salt and pepper.
Add the eggs to the tomatoes and onions and cook over medium heat, stirring constantly and scraping the bottom with a wooden spoon.
Remove from heat as soon as the eggs begin to set but are still moist, about 3 minutes. Turn out onto a serving plate and serve immediately.
Remove the beans from the pods and discard the pods.
Cook beans in boiling water for one minute.
Ready a bowl full of ice water. Remove the beans with a slotted spoon and plunge into the ice water. Drain. Remove and discard outer skins of beans.
Place beans in a saucepan, cover with water and bring to a boil. Cover, reduce heat, and simmer for 20 minutes or until the beans are tender.
Drain and rinse the beans with cold water. Place beans and remaining ingredients in a food processor.
Cut the onions, garlic, carrots and potatoes into small pieces.
Slice the pork and bacon into cubes and put them in the frying pan with the olive oil.
Add the tomato paste and wine and stir well.
Continue cooking at a low temperature for 5 minutes before adding the tomatoes, onions, garlic, carrots and potatoes.
When the pork is tender, after cooking for about 20 minutes, add the peas, salt and pepper.
To prepare the dough: Sift the flour into a bowl and add the salt.
Rub in cubed unsalted butter and mix until texture is crumbly.
Gradually add the cold water to the mixture and knead into dough. Roll to form into a ball and wrap with cling wrap. Chill for at least 30 minutes before rolling it out.
For the filling: Mash the ricotta. Add one egg to the ricotta and mix well. Add the raisins and mix until well combined. Add salt and pepper to taste.
Cut off small pieces of dough and roll into a small disc. Flatten each to desired thickness.
Put a tablespoon of the filling into the center of each disc. Turn dough edges over the filling and seal.
Glaze the pies with the remaining beaten egg.
Bake in a preheated oven at 425 degrees for 30 minutes or until pastry is golden brown.
Peel the potatoes and slice thinly.
Brush the sides and bottom of a baking dish with some of the olive oil. Scatter the onions on the bottom of the baking dish and season with salt and pepper.
Layer potato slices to cover onions, then season lightly with salt and pepper. Alternate until all onions and potatoes are used up.
Put the tuna on top of the last layer, then cover with the tomato halves, cut side down.
Add the garlic cloves, then pour in the water.
Pour the remaining olive oil and red wine vinegar over the tomatoes, then sprinkle the mint and parsley over the entire top.
Cover the baking dish (aluminum foil works if the dish doesn’t have a lid).
Bake until the potatoes are fork tender (around 45-60 minutes).
Heat the oil and fry the onion. Add tomato puree and diced pumpkin.
Fry gently for 5 minutes, making sure to stir continuously.
Add 4 cups boiling water, salt and pepper. Simmer until the pumpkin is well cooked, about 30-45 minutes.
Mash the vegetables with a masher or use a blender for a finer texture.
Add Semolina gently to avoid lumps and cook on a low heat for 10 minutes.
